reviews.review: Worth to visit. Worth to visit if you want to know about history of Japan. Edo's time until Tokyo nowadays. Huge museum with free English guided tour. We spend 4 hours there to discover Tokyo's history. Cheap ticket is only 600yen/adult. Free for kids. Restaurant is inside with japanese foods such as udon noodle. Quite delicious although expensive. A must-see museum when visiting Tokyo.

Wonderful guide at Edo-Tokyo Museum. The Japanese are so thoughtful. We had a free tour from a very nice English speaking volunteer, Kunio Sanui, who put us through our paces for 3 hours. He was 75 years old and we could barely keep up with him. The museum is accessible on your own due to the English signage. But having Sanui gave us the opportunity to ask many questions that he not only answered but elaborated on. What was a one-hour tour became three hours! His love of his city made everything come alive. Afterwards, there was still more that Sanui didn't have time to show us but that we had to see, i.e. WWII.

An absolute must see attraction. This is a stunning museum that provides an excellent record of the history of the transition from when the city, previously known as Edo, became Tokyo, as well as some more recent historic displays. It is an extensive display, and an excellent free guide service is available in English to take you through it. Our guide was a well educated Japanese who, at 87 years of age, was impressively sprightly and very well informed on his topic. You need to allow at least three hours to do the Edo-Tokyo subject, and this will just be a basic introduction to this interesting topic.

Informative, Modern and Engaging . There are many museums in Tokyo however the Edo Museum provides a superb overview of how people live in Tokyo...their homes, technology and culture. I am not a great fan of Museums showing small trinkets and ancient fabrics. Edo has examples of housing, cars, mobile phones etc. The building is superb from an engineering perspective.
Best Museum in Tokyo. This museum is very nice a lot of models and replica of old buildings and environment. Everything is well explained in English.

Excellent Museum -- No Need for a Guide!. Good permanent collections -- well presented and great special exhibits. Most exhibits have some English explanation The current special exhibition on Dr. Siebold is very interesting! If you're in Tokyo, don't miss this museum. You can go to Akihabara Station on the Yamanote Line and change to the subway. The museum is a short walk from Ryogoku Sation. Please note that the museum is closed on Mondays. If you qualify, there's a senior rate. Anyway, tickets are reasonable. The gift shops have nice quality merchandise.

Having a Guide Makes All the Difference. Volunteer guides are available at many tourist sites in Japan. I advise you to connect with one whenever possible. They have studied and know their information very well. I had an English-speaking guide at this museum. Even though there is English signage throughout the museum, she told me things that weren't on the display materials. More than half of the museum is devoted to the lifestyle of people during the Edo period of Japanese history (1600-1868). The rest is about modern Tokyo, from about 1920 to now. There are artifacts, of course. There are life-sized examples of houses from the Edo period and exhibits on culture, business, urbanization, the war, and Tokyo in the 21st century. There are many dioramas of the castle and the city as it developed. One of the best dioramas showed Western style fronts of buildings around the time the Edo period ended and Japan opened to trade with the West, and behind the fancy facades the local people still lived in houses that were the same as a hundred years earlier. The museum style is new and varied. I was with the guide for almost three hours and then went back and quickly took a few more photos.

Brilliant museum. This is a really great museum in Tokyo. Full of history. Permanent exhibition over two floors so not too big. Gives a great understanding of what is and where Tokyo has been and is going. Great exhibitions within the museum. A must go

Good learning experience. This museum was part of our tour planning, at first I though it was going to be boring but I have a teenager and she is very much into history. I was glad we made this stop in is a hand on Museum you can actually get on the bikes and go into the old style Japanese home and get pictures. Is a very beautiful museum.

Excellent museum. Really enjoyed our trip to the museum. Really informative - enough English language explanations as well as the chance to sit in a palanquin and a rickshaw!Tickets can be used all day. We arrived in the morning and got a bit exhausted so left and went to the awesome tea shop on 1F for seasonal Udon, then went back in refreshed and ready for more. (Afterwards we went back to the tea shop for sencha and cake! I highly recommend the tea shop!!!)

Good to know edo history here. we learned many history about edo period here and all tiny village shows the picture of living in edo period so clear
we spent almost 3 hours here listened to all history, great to know more about Japan ;)

Cool museum. We visited the museum on a rainy day and it was much better than I expected! Firstly the building is like a spaceship - going up in the never ending escalator is great! Inside the exhibition at the top has a selection of maps, artefacts, scale models and also life size reproductions of buildings. There were also a couple of performances while we were there, music and entertainment. A surprisingly good day out!

Pretty good!. This is a very spacious museum, though the approach and entrance seem quite dark and it felt more like going to a big US library or government building.Once inside there are some great miniature models of old Tokyo and life-size replica houses from lots of different eras. I loved the display of old books and the twentieth century buildings and exhibitions. There is information in English as well. I'd have liked there to have been more/ better cafes and it did feel a bit like it was off-peak season, but it was worth the trip. Fun seeing real Sumo wrestlers outside the station too!

a definite must-see. Impressive and, at times, charming presentation of the history of Edo and Tokyo. Nice shop and restaurants. Until November 6, there is a special exhibition entitled Revisiting Siebold's Japan Museum which is well worth the additional charge. Discount for senior citizens upon presentation of proof.

Great city museum experience. A brilliantly designed exhibition, the Edo-Tokyo Museum provides a comprehensive and fascinating journey through Tokyo's environs beginning when the city was founded in the 12th century, right up to the early twentieth century. Hands-on exhibits like the 'honey-buckets' and various tools give the visitor a good visceral sense of what life was like in the 'old days' while a walk-in model of an early 1950s home gives a great sense of what has recently passed. The different periods are portrayed by models of cities, artefacts and explanatory texts in Japanese and English. Particularly moving was the exhibit dealing with the fire-bombing of Tokyo toward the end of World War 2. A combination of war relics, including unexploded bombs, weapons and other relics of the destruction, with multi-media (light-up maps, video and radio from the time) was truly immersive and saddening. But Tokyo has a rich history and culture beyond war and a life which is very humane and cultured, witness the small cars from the early 1960s and parents and children can enjoy the exhibit of school lunches from the 1970s to the present.The Edo-Tokyo Museum is a wonderful place to get to know Tokyo's story, and worth devoting the best part of a day to thoroughly explore and learn.

Excellent Museum for both Edo period and modern Tokyo. Didn't expect too much thinking it was just another museum. Well, I was wrong. Although called Edo museum, it also has the modern Tokyo history on display. You get a very good insight to the history and culture of Tokyo and Japan. I even saw a copy of the of the letter of surrender from World War II. All display were well explained in English text and there were many interactive things for both adults and kids. The souvenir shops at this Museum were really good too, make sure you spend some time there. We spent a good 3-4 hours at this museum and think this should be on everyone's must do list for Tokyo.

Quiet, interesting, family-friendly. A bit off the beaten track but worth the trip, especially if you're tired of the crowds at most other tourist attractions in Tokyo. Lots of interesting displays, hands-on exhibits, and incredible dioramas.It kept my teen/tween daughters engaged and interested for a couple of hours.

Time slip in to the middle of Edo!. You will time slip into the middle of Edo, the mega city of the time. The Edo culture is the core of current Japanese culture - Kabuki, Ukiyo-e, Sumo, Oiran - you will stand in the restored Edo city at its full-bloom. The museum also shows the transition from the time of samurai and ever growing people (Edo period) to democratic Japan (Meiji, Showa). You could also spend hours in the museum shop filled with collections of Japanese traditional accessories, cloths, gadgets. Take a break at chic Japanese restaurant and cafe with traditional interior. I particularly loved cafe "Sarara" for afternoon sweets and tea.

Great family friendly museum. Excellent. This should really be near the top of everyone's "to see" list in Tokyo. Beautiful 360 degree exhibits in meticulous detail, showing the history of the Edo period in Japan. There are cutaway models of a theatre, houses of the rich, poor and artisan craftsmen and dioramas showing how the town would have looked. On the other side of the building is the story of 20th century Japan again featuring cut -away houses and all the artifacts. All in all it's a fascinating insight into Japanese history and really brings it to life. Recommended.

Outstanding treatment of historical Tokyo (Edo)!. This museum is everything a museum should be. Fascinating exhibits with lots of explanations (in English for tourists!) I was charmed and entranced by the dioramas with tiny figures that became three dimensional representations of famous screens. Full scale rooms showing various occupations, a ship, a float, a theater. And surprise, photos are allowed!

Awesome insight Edo period Tokyo. Awesome insight to the everyday life of early Edo period all the way up to Meiji Restoration. Also some great stuff and info on WW2 Tokyo. Amazing how this city changed from one era to the other and how its people always evolved with it. The technology and innovation of Edo period Tokyo is fantastic and its beautifuly depicted at the museum with dioramas, large scale replicas and lots of original artifacts.

A great intro to Tokyo history and culture. Visited this museum while on a two week trip to Japan. Went with a friend who lived in Tokyo as a child but who hadn't been back in a while and we all found the museum an insightful and enlightening visit. We didn't see the special exhibition and stuck to the permanent collection and we had a light meal in the upstairs restaurant. Nice views of the city from up there. The first floor restaurant has only tea/coffee and sweets, but the upstairs one has a full menu including noodles, set meals, etc. Good for a half-day visit easily accessibly by train (like almost everything in Tokyo). The Senso-ji Temple complex is only one or two train stops away and could be easily combined on the same day, as well as the Sumo trophy museum right next door.

Valuable introduction to Tokyo History. A very important stop to understand the history of Japan. Great didactics, models, and displays. The English coverage was good. We could have spent more time. Note here like other museums seniors can enter free.

Of course, almoust a must. Interested in history?Go and get more knowledge about ancient Japan and EdoGives good background and interestingly built, should get attention.One of mainvisit points in Tokyo.

Fascinating and informative. This is well worth a visit.It gives a structured and interesting insight into life in the Edo period, following through up to modern times.Presentation is well done with English subtitles and the attention to detail in the exhibits is top notch stuff.Entrance fee of 600 yen and there is a cafe and shops. Allow 2-3 hours but we could have stayed longer.Close to Ryogoku station and next to the Sumo museum which is free and only takes 15-20 minutes.

Amazing museum!. Tokyo offers a lot to a tourist and this museum is one of the best! It tells the city's history going back to when it was a shabby fishing village of 20 families and all the way through today, with a population of over 13 million!

Educational and enjoyable . And so now I know a bit about Tokyo's history, the Shogun, life in old Tokyo, concubines, kabuki theatre and more. Model and miniature scale facilities (from those used by commoners to the Shogun and the Emperor) are all meticulously presented with great detail. Interactive exhibits provide good relief from just the visual senses being stimulated. We arrived to find no free volunteer English guide, so set out by ourselves to read the plentiful English descriptions for all the exhibits ... But we decided after about 10-15 minutes that we'd go and rent some audio - the exhibits' plaques are detailed and contain many Japanese place names that can make you lose focus on what you are reading about (as one seeks to pronounce the multi-syllabic place names correctly !). Upon returning to the front desk, we found an English speaking guide had just finished an earlier tour ! And what a treasure he was. Far better experience to have someone whisk you through (1.5 hours) and tell the key stories and share the important information you need to know (and then you just toddle back through at your own pace to fill in any gaps, or take a second look, take photos). Highly recommend this museum - the 2-3 hours will fly by, especially if you get yourself a free guide.

A really interactive insight . One of the best museums I've been to especially with the audio guide. The permenant exhibits provide a real insight into the cultural and historical development of edo and Tokyo. Manageable in half a day easily. Would recommend well above the Tokyo national museum.
Perfect One. This Museum gives a perfect picture of Tokyo during Edo time. I really liked various cycles as one can seat on them.

Very interesting worth the visit. The museum tells the story of he development and history of Tokyo from its beginnings as Edo. There is plenty to see with large exhibits and very interesting information.

Great overview of Edo Tokyo history in a splendid building. Evolution of Tokyo very well explained in text and displays, different languages are available "onscreen"; furthermore this museum offers free service of tour guides in some foreign languages(best check this ahead); the displays and maquettes are wonderful, with so much eye for detail. Staff is very friendly, they have nice museum shop.. Really worth the visit.
Pretty good . Had a decent overview of the time period. Was quite small but still probably the best museum in Tokyo for this part of history.

You must go here. Simply one of the most interesting museums around. Focus on last few hundreds years of Japan, especially Tokyo. Houses are recreated as they would have been. Models of castles and town life are there to experience. History through WW2 to today are brought to life with artefacts, photos and displays. Young and not so old will have fun and appreciate the interactive museum. You can easily spend several hours here and be enthralled. Don't miss it.

Edo Education . Just next to the Sumo Wrestling Arena (Ryōgoku Kokugikan) easy access from Ryogoku Station. There's costs for the permanent exhibition or the special exhibition which they change each season or so. The cost of ¥600 for just the permenant or ¥1200 for both if I remember...We just did the permanent exhibition and went up the elevator to that floor. There is no eating or drinking anything but water allowed. But there's heaps of interactive features throughout the whole area. On arrival of the area they have some people standing by for languages such as French or English and so on to take you on a guide, because most is just in Japanese. But there's still heaps of English translated plaques. The tour guide answer heaps of questions and took us around the whole two floors and it was amazing. Learning about before the end of Edo Times and after. Also she suggested places and things to do while on our trip here. Good price and amazing destination to do some educational opportunities in Tokyo, especially if you're sick of shopping. Highly recommended and need to save 2-3hours especially if you're able to get a guide.
Very nice Edo museum. Very big and nice museum. It's a great museum that show the history of japan and information of Edo period.

A fantastic museum, very low admission fee. We loved this museum! For starters, it's contained in a huge space, kind of like a indoor soccer stadium. Very dramatic when we walked in.The history of Japan was presented in the most visual ways. Displays ran from detailed, small-scale replicas of an Edo village (home of the shogun) all the way to a full-sized Japanese farm house from the 1930s where we could walk into the rooms. Many hands-on opportunities. And a gigantic full-sized bridge that replicated one from the Edo village display was amazing and gave us a sense of walking through history. The information about the fire-bombing of Tokyo and the horrible conditions for those Japanese who survived the war was disturbing, but important to learn about.Overall, the place was fun and kept our attention till the end, unlike many static displays found in more traditional museums. We learned so much and enjoyed every minute.Afterward, we went to the museum cafe on the first floor and had ice cream, cold tea, and some traditional Japanese desserts that were really gooey. We didn't like them much, but hey, at least we tried them.

Very nice museum. I coupled this trip with watching a sumo match and, although I was expecting it to just be an additional extra, I really enjoyed it. It's a pretty big museum and you can take a free English tour guide to explain everything for you, although there are English explanations on everything. I loved looking at the little models of old Japan and there are also a lot of places where you can pose for photo ops. At only 400Y this is totally worth it, the gift shop is also really affordable with nice souvenirs. I would recommend this, especially for families.

Great museum!. Great Museum that shows you Japanese Life and the development of small town Edo to Capital City Tokyo. A lot of miniatures, art and objects show you the fascinating history. We had a fantastic English speaking guide who lead us through the big museum. Take at least 3-4 hours.

Great Info about Edo-Style Tokyo. This museum is dedicated to the Edo-style Japan. If you're interested in history about Japan during the edo-period, this is the place to be.You can spent a couple of hours there easily and get to know the life of people during edo era. It's very close to the sumo-museum and Skytree and can be combined with them to save time.

Interesting museum on the history of Tokyo. This museum does a really good job of giving you insight into what life in Tokyo would have been like in the past. The exhibits were very detailed and well done.

Great, great miniatures! :). Really, really impressed by the greatly detailed miniature models of Edo city (as Tokyo was known back then in the Tokugawa period) on the 7th floor (the highest floor) - main streets with people walking along, bridges & boats, a daimyo's house with a big courtyard, a castle & its nearby city all surrounded by a moat, etc.; and on the 6th floor are "life-sized models" of a theater house with life-sized performers on a stage, a two-story Victorian-styled house which is also pretty much life-sized (imagine a real two-story Victorian house inside a museum!) and houses of ordinary people (saw life-sized figures of a woman giving birth with some people around her in one of them), and also to be seen on the 6th floor is a nice sculpture of the first Tokugawa shogun.They close at 5 30 pm, and I suggest to do this museum starting from the top (the 7th floor where those amazing Edo City miniatures are) and making your way down; I personally got to do only 7th & 6th floors since I got there only at 4 pm, so yes be mindful of the 5 30 closing time and start from the top because that's where the best things to see are (the Edo City miniatures).I walked about half an hour from the Asakusa area by crossing the Sumida River from its west side (the Museum is on the east side) and going south. But there's Ryogoku Station (Toei Oedo Line) pretty much like right beside the Museum, and there's also a McDonald's nearby where I had my dinner of burgers.

Small and interesting place. Anyone fan with Edo will enjoy a pook around this. Dont expect too much for the price is a little high for whats offered.All the same its great to see some things in real life instead of internet and books.

A must see.. We have visited this museum in Ryogkoku area while traveling through Tokio. It is a pretty big facility with an exposition on Edo and Tokio periods. Exhibition is organized on two floors, with great examples of architecture and cultural objects. Well described in English, offers private, free of charge guided tours in several languages. Surprisingly, it takes about three hours to walk through and read all the materials. Gives a good grasp of what Tokio development looked like. Worth a try.

Perfect rainy and extremely hot day event. Museums in Japan are good hide out spot when it rains or extremely hot day.It is so not only the temperature inside of premises is comfortable but also what they exhibit is interesting and time consuming. Particularly this museum is time consuming but positive way. By visiting here, one will be well informed history of Tokyo and its postwar fast development.

Must See Museum . This place is really special and If you had one museum to visit, make it this one please There are beautiful models of everything described well in English . This is a perfect place to stay with a family or to understand what Tokyo use to be and how it is now .The permanent exhibition at the museum is well design and a good introduction to Japanese culture through time. I actually spend more then 2 hours and I managed to see all of it . I think I have almost 100 over pictures if you are interested in the Edo period like me you will love it . The whole place is giant space with reconstructed bridges, houses, and other structures from the Edo era, as well as miniatures and artifacts. It's interesting to see how people lived those days . It's really mysterious the era ... I was like a child excited , curious , confused and mystified with this amazing museum and just wanted to see , know and understand everything : Please do visit if you have the opportunity but make sure you have patience and the time ...:Cheers

Huge building. Museum that walks through the history of Tokyo. There wasn't an English tour guide available when we were there but presumably this would improve the experience. It was a bit tough to learn too much with out help as much of the text isn't in English (and why would it be?). We did enjoy walking through and experiencing the size/space of the building and the various art.

Educational. The Edo museum depicts many aspects of Tokyo from the Edo period until fairly modern times. The scale models were beautifully made and interesting. But overall the emphasis of this museum is educational. I think it would be most appropriate for school children, not adults who have read any history of Japan.

Informative and fun. Children enter for free ( my son is 10) and my ticket was around 600 yen. Lovely place and children with enjoy it as well many interesting no models about life from the Edo period and then how life evolved. Highly recommend this museum.

The Edo Exhibit. This ornate-shaped, fairly modern museum is a must for an understanding of how Edo was born and how it developed into modern Tokyo. Lots of artefacts and explanations of culture and lifestyles. Although exhibits had multi-language plaques, I found things a little difficult to follow and would have benefitted from an English-speaking guide (there were volunteers about to do this but they were overwhelmed by visitors requesting their services when we were there. Good for a rainy day - rain was belting down the day of our visit.

Free for Seniors the day I visitted. This is an interesting collection mostly of model of how Edo looked before it became Tokyo. There are also significant cultural artifacts including a couple of palanquins one of which visitors can be photographed in. I particularly like my ticket which show zero yen admission charge. Though I wasn't carrying any proof of age, my wrinkles, white hair and grumpy demeanour were accepted as evidence of seniority.

Japan in 7 days. Day 4 Part 15. Just like our other visits to museums before, we embarked on a time travel back in time to old Tokyo with our visit to The Edo museum. The museum is very detailed. As you move from one section to the next, you feel as if you are also moving through the years as Edo the small village is evolving to become bigger and bigger into modern Tokyo.The transformation of culture and way of life provides a quick and interesting history lesson. After 2-3 hours of browsing and looking at dioramas, artifacts, exhibits, and reconstructed models, you are back in present day Tokyo. This time with a clearer understanding of how Tokyo life came to be. Japanese culture is indeed rich and unique. This short visit will surely enrich your knowledge.

A Must Visit for Those Interested in Art and History!. My first visit (in 2014) was arranged through the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Visitor Center that provided two very knowledgeable guides who pointed out many high points that I would have missed without a guided tour. In my second visit (in 2016), I took a family member and we spent more time seeing what we wanted to see in more detail. Signs are very good in English (and of course Japanese). With the right camera, good pictures can be taken without flash in most areas. The museum is divided into two parts: the Edo Period prior to 1868 and western influence, and the Tokyo Period after 1868, which shows architectural changes and other inventions. Selection of items is outstanding, and whether a long or short period of time is spent in the museum, you will learn a great deal about the history of Japan in all of its phases. There are also activities for children.

Beautiful exhibition. the exhibition is large and beautiful I've spent around 4.5 hours there and still didn't had enough.The museum contains large exhibition with models of Tokyo at the Edo era (1603- 1868) including beautiful models of the shogun and emperor palace, also include samurai armor and katana (sword)and so on.after words go into a real size model of the daily life (houses instruments and so on...) and than it keeps going and advancing (time periods) until it arrives modern time...really feels like some kind of time travel..this place is suits with anyone- single or a whole family.

Amazing building - life-size exhibits bring the era alive. If you are at all interested in the history of Japan and specifically Tokyo, this is a must-see. The edifice itself looms high over the city and its enormity allows the recreation of entire buildings inside. The displays cover chronological history and thematic topics as well. Tucked away on one side of the fifth floor is an insightful array of exhibits that cover Tokyo's challenging 20th century - floods, fires, and of course World War II and its difficult aftermath leading to Japan's later economic rebirth. Several cafes are available as well as the ubiquitous gift shops. Lots of things for kids to do as well.

Good choice on a hot or rainy day. AT 600y for adults and free for children it is a bargain. Historical exhibits from Edo, Mejei and post WW2 periods which interested our children. Frequent performances (ranging from comic fiddler ro magician and traditional juggler) provided good balance to exhibits to keep children interested. We took a 10 minute ferry there from Asakusa which was a worthwhile change from subway (300y). Near to Sumo stadium which also has a museum open when there is no competition on. (We did not go there)

You could spend the whole day here . If you're a student make sure to bring your student card with you as you get money off. Normal fare is ¥600 for students it's ¥480. The actual museum is 2 floors of Edo culture and traditional with a brilliant display of information and interactive exhibitions. I could of spent the whole day here but I arrived at 3pm and got kicked out by 17:30pm for closing !

Very informative. We appreciated very much this museum, because it's not only about the past, but there are many live shows (we attended one about Japanese magic for around 45 min - where everyone was involved! - plus we saw another theatrical performance in Japanese).Many free English-speaking volunteers (plus in other languages) willing to show around to foreigners. Unfortunately, some exhibits did not have English translation.I liked the sections about the daily life of locals throughout the last several centuries, with plenty of charts / stats (distribution of expenses per household in 1800s vs now, for instance). Also I was impressed by the part about the life (and death) in Tokyo during WWII: very detailed and often emotional.All in all, it's definitely a place to check for lovers of history or only of this city.

A must :). If you are visiting Tokyo for the first time, you should visit this museum. It gives a quick bit detailed idea of Tokyo from the edo era to modrrm Japan. The perminant collection is on the 7th and 6th floor. Once you exit the museum through the long escelator contiue to the ground floor to check a coffee shop, an italian resturant and a gift shop on your way to the metro station.

best museum in Tokyo for the entire family. If you are interested in the history of Edo-Tokyo, this informative museum will keep you and your children busy for the entire afternoon. The miniature daimyo residence with all the architectural details was my favorite. Other miniature models depicting different periods of lives of Edo-Tokyo were equally fun to observe. Docents offer English and Japanese explanations of the exhibits.

Good way to learn local culture. If you have 2-3 hours spare, this is the best way to get to know better the Japanese culture as you can enjoy the full history of Tokyo. There are also interactive attraction for the youngest ones,

Fascinating place for Edo-Tokyo history ! . This is one place you shouldn't miss! Edo-Tokyo museum has elaborate dioramas, life sized displays and massive architecture that will impress the pants out of you. Unlike other museums where you just look, here you get to interact with a lot of things (as in touch or listen) to really imagine the kind of life that the Japanese had in the yesteryears. The permanent exhibition was already worth it, and you can take as many photos that you like to remember the occasion. If you're a tourist I suggest you get an English speaking tour guide which is free, because they can explain a lot of interesting facts and give you access to places - like playing with old style instruments for sound effects in kabuki theater which was so cool. We were fortunate enough to also catch the Yokai exhibition which was also fascinating, creepy and sometimes humorous. It's an awesome place ! Worth every yen :)

Good museum, leave plenty of time. Very nice museum, although English information is more limited than Japanese. We had to rush through it somewhat in order to make our flight home. The permanent exhibit is quite cheap to visit considering its size. We also visited an excellent special exhibit on old Japanese monster drawings that was fascinating but overcrowded. This added to the cost but was worth it. Wish we had had more time here.

Excellent history overview of Tokyo !. We had an excellent English speaking guide assigned to us at the Edo museum which made all the difference to truly understanding the exhibits. The exhibits were lovely but lacked detailed explanation. She provided the in-depth knowledge of the shogun, feudal lords, emperor relationship and gave us insight as to the customs and culture of the Edo period. Highly recommend !

Excellent view into Edo period Tokyo. The museum features very large displays of Edo period models, art, scrolls, and more. There are very detailed recreations of lots of different aspects of the culture during the period.

Excellent!. A nice place to understand and learn about the Edo times.Comprehensive, easy to access and quite educational. I would definitely recommend it if you can read Japanese (you experience would be enhanced by reading the original texts)

Good source for history enthusiasts!. Enjoyed this museum--just enough history for me. Models and English explanations were available! I learned some of Japanese history in a short period of time. There is a nice shop for souvenirs inside too.

way more interesting than my history class!. Wish I had a chance to visit a museum like this in my young age. I did not like history ever but made me want to restudy it again. Low admission, plenty of space to rest, great English free guide.
Great introduction to history of Tokyo . Nice popular introduction to the history of Tokyo. Always an English translations, but not everything . You can get a free guide too. Take your time

Thoroughly fascinating displays of Edo- and Tokyo-related history. While it's understandable that this museum might not be on most folks' list of what to see on a first trip to Tokyo, I would rate this museum as one of Tokyo's best attractions. As it's name suggests, the focus is on the city of Tokyo and its predecessor, Edo. There's plenty to cover in the permanent exhibition with fascinating examinations of Edo Castle and its environs, the lives, activities, celebrations and tribulations of Tokyo's citizens, as well as the events that marked the transition from old Edo to modern Tokyo, Exhibits had good explanations in both Japanese and English. A quick 1-to 2-hour visit would be fine if time is a premium but to really do it justice, at least 3 hours is needed. Much as the permanent exhibitions can be very engaging, don't forget to check out some of the temporary and/or special exhibitions. While an additional admission fee may be charged for some of them, the themes can be very fascinating and complement well the permanent exhibits. On a previous trip, I managed to catch a fabulous display of ukiyo-e prints of Hiroshige's 53 stations of the Tokaido Road. At the same time, there was a special exhibition which resonated strongly with local visitors featured the history of the Battle of Sekigawara.Some tips which might be useful: Firstly, try to avoid weekends as the crowds can be incredible. I once visited on a Sunday, and while the queues to purchase admission tickets moved fairly quickly, they did snake all around the ground floor of the museum. And secondly. while there are three restaurants/cafes in the museum, more economical options for meals may be found at the many restaurants located under the train tracks on the south side of Ryokogu station (located right next to the museum).

Very Insightful. Spent about 3 hours in the permanent exhibition on level 1 highlighting the Edo and Samurai periods. We used a free tour guide that was offered at the museum who explained every piece in the exhibit. The flow was really good and lots of visuals so wasn't boring at all. A must do in when in Tokyo.

Busy, busy, busy!. Came here to see the special exhibition of monsters, ghosts & demons in Japanese art. Very well curated but SO busy we barely saw a thing. Lessons to be learned about visiting Tokyo museums on public holiday weekends. Other exhibits less crowded and our 3 year old enjoyed the history of Tokyo exhibition with old bikes, carriages, phone boxes etc.

Nice museum focused on Tokyo history. Those is a novelty laid off museum with prices starting at $6 for three permanent exhibits and doubling if you wish to include the current temporary exhibits. The museum consists of refrained of like in Tokyo emphasizing the Edo period and had models of typical hostess, communities, transportation, entertainment and dress. Free tours with volunteers are offered in English and other languages. A nice understanding of the history of Tokyo for those of us unaware of its background. It is reasonably priced and easy to see. Highly recommended for families as there are many things which interest children.

The best museum in Tokyo!. We first came here five years ago and having visited many more since we returned here today as it still remains for us, 'the one to beat'! It has more information about the Edo period and people than others and although it isn't full if artifacts it is full of facts. Great for children too.

Look for the Spanish-fluent guide.. The museum guide are volunteers, meaning that you don't pay for the guidance. We had a Spanish-fluent guide and spent three amazing hours listening to stories about Edo (old Tokyo), Tokyo, its emperors, shoguns, dynasties, feudal lords, samurais and commmon people. Priceless.

Free guides many languages. Really great permanent exhibition. Two floors of history with full scale building facade replicas on the bottom floor. Guided tours are offered for free in a variety of languages and can be booked in advance. Alternatively you can borrow an audio guide for ¥1000 deposit which is returned when the device is returned.The audio guide have slightly more in depth information than the basic signage but it was very slow.There are lockers available to fit a day-pack for ¥100 which is returned when you are finished using it. Was really good value for money and we enjoyed our visit.

Fantastic museum . We had a great visit at the Edo -Tokyo museum. The museum gave us much knowledge about the fascinating history of the city. The exhibitions were excellent and the museum building were a prime example of modern Tokyo architecture. The highlight of the visit was the interesting guided tour led by one of the excellent volunteer English speaking guides. I can warmly recommend this museum and I warmly recommend to take a guided tour while visiting the museum since it gave us greater understanding of the history of Tokyo.

Very Interesting Museum. This museum tells the story of the development of Edo, a small village, to becoming the political capital of Japan during the Tokugawa shogunate, and then becoming the political and imperial capital Tokyo during the Meiji restoration in the 1860s. The museum has several models of the city as it developed, with miniature buildings and figurines of people, as well as life size exhibits. We did not have reservations, but were still able to get an English speaking tour guide who was very knowledgeable, and really enhanced our experience. We enjoy museums, and this was an excellent one.

Excellent museum and amazing building. The building housing the museum is a sight itself - like a giant frog. The museum follows the history of Tokyo with reconstructed buildings, hands on displays for kids and interesting models of streetscape a. I'd recommend an English tour or get the audio. There was even a free magic show. great!!

Friendly volunteers. We spent a very informative and enjoyable 1.5 hours with a lady volunteer named Seyama Reiko. The museum brings to life the Japanese culture and traditions in the edo period. Would strongly recommend spending some time there. The guide service is free and the volunteer was very committed.The museum has some nice cafes where we ate lunch.Loved it.

History of Toyko. Definitely a must do when you visit Tokyo. A lot of history to absorb and experience about the city. Learned a lot of history about Japanese culture in general. The miniature displays of townships were excellent. Not a lot of natural light inside the actual building though, felt somewhat dark in some parts.

Experience Edo. Experience the first period of Japan ruled by Shoguns, Daimyos and ronins. Do engage a volunteer museum guide to take you around on a 1.5 hrs tour in English. Audio sets are also available. You will visit Edo Tokyo and modern Tokyo - their way of life and housing. Many of the original buildings can still be seen in downtown Tokyo such as the Imperial palace and Nihonbashi. Be prepared to spend 2-3 hours. Special discounts for 65+

Worth a brief look if you're interested in history. I am a big history buff and so I found this place to be somewhat interesting. I particularly liked the area with displays about the WWII era in Japan. A unique (although not necessarily anti-American) view for someone educated in the US. The dioramas of what Tokyo looked like in centuries past interested my children but I thought they were not worth more than just a brief glance. Some of the displays were just sort of strange (school lunches in Tokyo in 1950 vs 2000 - interesting, I guess).

The best museum in Tokyo -- learn the history of Edo-Tokyo in this awesome place!. I've been to this museum a number of times. Whenever my friends and family visit me in Tokyo, we make sure to visit this museum. It's a great place where you can learn the history of what is now the city of Tokyo. I've done about 1.5-2hour tours with volunteer guides and we never have enough time to see and learn about all of the exhibits. Some of the best points of this museum are :-- very reasonably priced at 600yen-- there are volunteer guides (Japanese, English, Chinese, Korean, French, German and Spanish) who provide you with a wealth of information. In order to reserve a guide, make sure you get to the museum between 10am and 3pm. -- permanent exhibits are visually stunning. There are handmade and crafted figurines throughout the museum. Each of these according to our guide costs between 100 to 1,000 USD! Don't forget to use the provided binoculars to check out the figurines closer. You'll be astonished to see that each one has unique clothing and facial expressions.-- The museum is located in Ryogkoku. This is the area which is associated with the traditional Japanese sport -- Sumo. Even though you might not have a chance to attend a sumo match as they are only held 3 times a year in Tokyo ...and the tickets are expensive and hard to get! You will be able to enjoy traditional sumo wrestler's dish while you are in Ryogkoku -- Chanko Nabe a hot pot dish full of yummy surprises! Looks and sounds quite peculiar, but it tastes great!. Especially recommend for the cold winter season. This museum is one of my favourite sightseeing attractions in Tokyo. Give it a go!
Nice place. A perfect place to visit and see edo period Japan that Lao within the city ..nicely maintained and you feel as if not in modern Tokyo

Great dioramas. This gives an overview of the history of the Edo/Tokyo area. The models and dioramas are very impressive. Plenty of English explanations. Nice cage for tea, coffee and Japanese sweets. There is a nursing room for those with babies.

So many amazing things to see, so little time.. We're a family of history buffs. It is always a neat thing to see the history of where you are visiting. Japan has such a long and interesting history that this place is a great day trip. Even with a little kid (6) he was still interested in all the different models and recreations. Who doesn't like miniaturized figures??? It also happened to be raining that day we planned to go so we were glad for an indoor activity.Granted because this is Japan, there is mostly Japanese signs but you can take an audio tour in your language. We opted to pass on this since we weren't sure how long our son would let us linger and read each display. There was just enough English in all the places we read that we still learned a great deal here. Surprisingly he was pretty interested in 85% of what we saw. There are all sorts of displays to see and the different areas offered a good mix of replicas to help you visualize what older Japan was like. My son especially liked all the old models of bikes and carriages of transport that you could try and take pictures in. There are models and replicas of everything and anything...from actual buildings and houses-to different artifacts. Everything was done well and the layout was easy and not confusing. There was so much history to soak in that I wish I could have stayed longer!

Puts your trip to all the temples and shrines in perspective. I think this museum is a must in order to understand Japan.! It tells the story of ancient Japan through the twentieth century with models, dioramas and artifacts. There are good English translations. It is appropriate for folks from 6-60.....

Lots to see, very interesting . We spent at least a couple of hours exploring the museum. I particularly liked the numerous traditional prints, the old bike and carriages you could climb on and the war section. Even the escalator outside was fun as it went on forever. A great place to visit.
Tiny everything!!. Must visit place if you are fan of knowing history of Japan. Better you take guide with you, we had a friend who helped us in everything. So many things to see, things to learn.

Not our cup of tea. We ended up going here because it was raining hard and our guide cancelled our boat trip on the Sumida River. It was not a equivalent replacement! There was some interesting exhibits detailing historical Edo and Meiji periods. In all honestly my son and I found it quite boring. We were out in 30 minutes. This is more suited to locals or those specifically interested in the aforementioned periods in Japanese history.

Great find in Tokyo. I visited this museum on a stay in Tokyo and was really pleased. The displays are really wonderful and give a great sense of the "old" Tokyo - Edo town as well as the history and transition to more modern Tokyo. The museum offered a free (yes - free) English-speaking guide who was extremely knowledgeable about the history of Tokyo and that really added to the trip. You just have to ask for a guide when you reach the entrance on floor 6 (where the exhibits start). The exhibits include a full-sized kabuki theater and many detailed dioramas that give you a real feel for life back in those times. I would definitely put this on your list. It is very easily reached by the subway (Ryogoku stop on the Toei-Oedo Line). Kids would have a great time here as a number of the exhibits allow you to touch and try different types of objects, tools, etc.

Boring!. If you are japanese-speaking, you might have a different opinion but as an english-speaker this museum didnt have much to offer other than making you bored. There was supposed to be english-speaking guides at the museum, but when we arrived they were all occupied, there was also supposed to be audio-guides which we didnt realize til later, cause the man at the ticketcounter failed to inform us about this.As far as the exhibition goes, there seemed to be no logical explanation to the order in which you were supposed to walk through. It seemed to be just a bunch of random items displayed that absolutely failed to catch my interest. It also wasnt clear If any of the items whatsoever were original items? It was as If they focused on the most boring parts of tokyo history! (which i think probably is a lot more exciting, depending on how you present it)I have visited far better museums depicting the historys of major cities than this. This museum felt dated, unrealistic, non english friendly and boring. They should really take notes from other countries that have more modern city-museums.On the plus side: Close to public transportation and reasonably priced admission cost.

Highly recommended to visit. The museum is near Ryogoku station and the atmospher of this area is different from other bustling areas such as Shinjuku or Ginza. It is peaceful and kind of retro. The museum is well-organised to separate the exhibition from Edo era and Modern era. There are some interactive facilities and collections making the exhibition more interesting. You can understand more about Japanese culture and history for the recent 300 years in one hour tour. Definitely worth a visit!

Entertaining. Back in Time in a Modern Architecture.. Spent a few hours in this fascinating museum which was easily reached (5 minute walk from JR Ryogoku station). Through its interesting, detail rich displays, guests were brought to the past of Tokyo during the Edo period (16th to 18th century), how people conducted their daily life, the trade, buildings, politics, etc. It also has shops, cafe/restaurant (but didn't try it) and English-speaking voluntary guides during certain hours, shops and cafe/restaurant. Ample of places to sit and relax too. Many tourist groups but not crowded as the building was quite spacious. Should have allocated time to visit the Sumo Hall next to the museum.

I Highly Recommend The Most Popular Museum Among TAs in Tokyo!!. Many foreigners are interested in the history of Edo-Tokyo, because of the unique history and the rapid modernization after late 19th century of Japan. Thus, this museum is the most popular museum and the 10th most popular attraction in Tokyo among TAs. Actually, I have taken many of my foreign friends to this museum and they all liked it: the life-size model of Nihonbashi Bridge, the old Kabuki Theater, the small replicas of old Edo towns, the chronological model houses and pictures of Edo-Tokyo. There are good Audio Guides and English-speaking volunteers to help you understand. Thus, I now suggest all foreign visitors to go to this museum and also to the Sumo Stadium (Kokugikan) in Ryogoku!!

Great way to know the history of tokyo. This history musum cover the edo period of tokyo up until modern time tokyo. It was fun and can take up to 3 hours most and its right next to the somo stadium and musem (kyoguken is the name i think ? ) so visiting both is a good a plan for the day

Expected a lot more. For being a museum dedicated to Tokyo´s great history, this place is really disappointing. Yes, there are models of houses, theaters and bridges, but the whole display fails to convey a picture of what the Edo period was like. There is as much reality in it as in a model train set. The museum building itself is downright ugly, but the inside does not make up for it with a poorly designed layout. Even the lobby is just confusing. Or are there two lobbies, maybe? And how to you get to the exposition? Well, follow the crowd. And, apart from models, the entire museum seems empty, with some scattered displays of random things. Tokyo is a world class city with a city museum fit for a small town. This is not a museum, this is a theme park gone wrong.

Japan Through the Eyes of History. We visited this on our last day out in Tokyo because we wanted to learn more about Japan from a historical perspective. There are audio guides which are very helpful for a deeper understanding of the exhibits. You just need to give an additional 500 yen deposit which you get back when you return the unit.Our favorite part of the museum were the scale models of life of towns during the various periods (Meiji, Edo, Showa) that showcase a recreation of typical life then. They were truly impressive in their detail and scale. If you want to learn more about Japan beyond their shrines and food, this museum would be worth a few of your hours.

save money by just doing the permanent display. The special display was ok. Mostly written materials and painted wall board displays. I moved through it quickly. The permanent display was more interesting to me, especially the exhibits on the 5th floor. Takes you through the edo period to more modern times. Give you a feel what life was like in old Edo-Tokyo.

Highly recommended !!. Very interesting and beautiful museum. There's alot of things to see in just two floors. Amazing and outstanding architecture. The models and structures are fascinating. I especially love the exhibit where you can walk inside and explore a traditional Japanese home. It's a must see when you visit tokyo.
Great overview of Edo history. This museum is well worth visiting. Performances were great and the models and displays interesting, informative and professional. Seniors over 65 receive a discount.

Must see, take your time!. The museum is very intersting. You can male a smale tour but i recommend you to take your time and visit with a guide. The museum has volunteers that speak many languages. We made the tour with Tomoko. Since we were with a baby we couldn't pay atention to everything but we learned a lot

with Sumo Muesum. I went to this Edo Tokyo Musesum in Saturday afternoon.As lots of visitors including tourists from overseas, I reccomend to go on weekday.In this museum, it is available to learn Japanese historocal culture or life in various periods, espacillay Edo era.It is lacated near by Ryogoku station and Ryogoku Kokugikan, and it is possible to visit both Edo museum and Sumo museum.

Outstanding museum of the social history of Tokyo, well laid out, fun and interesting. Easy to find next to Ryogoku Station (local railway Chuo Sobu line). We found more than enough to keep us entertained for two hours in the main exhibition although there is a special exhibition which I'm sure would be interesting. Two enormous floors - sixth and fifth - filled with wonderful models and full scale replicas of houses, bridges, and shops in the Edo period, bringing history to life. Just the right amount of information in English and Japanese with other language options available. It is pitched at the right level for the interested amateur. Very informative, colourful and spacious in spite of being busy. English guided tours by volunteers are available. We had lunch in Finn's restaurant which does nice crispy pizzas.

Brilliant. A wonderful look at old Edo and modern Tokyo, with replica building façades, and even a life size version of Nihonbashi bridge. Lots of info, stories, models, objects... Outside the theatre façade there are free shows every so often too.

Fantastic Museum! One of the best things we did in Tokyo.. Such a wonderful place! We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Edo Tokyo Museum. The building is amazing- before you even walk in! There is so much to see and lots of interactive exhibits. My favorite was the 'period rooms' which took you through Tokyo living in different time periods, and the walk through Japanese house with tatami mat rooms. There are many different types of displays here- this museum really appeals to everyone and all placards are written in both Japanese and English, which is a plus. The gift shops are great, too- with many unique native items available, we ended up buying some of our favorite souvenirs here. We also ate in the Italian restaurant on the ground floor- which I highly recommend for a quick(ish) easy meal.

Amazing museum where you can learn the Tokyo history!!. This museum building is huge. You can buy the ticket at the ticket counter on the first floor and then proceed to the escalator which is located near the counter. Staff will check you ticket before letting you into a very long escalator that will lead you up to exhibition zone.This museum is amazing and the exhibition area is very large. You will start with Nihonbashi bridge which is reproduced from Edo period. After that, the route they've prepared will lead you to go through the history of Tokyo from Edo period to the present, such a nice plan.You're allowed to take the photos in this museum but just don't use a flash to disturb another visitors.

Very informative. Beautiful architecture of this museum, in- and outside! Take the suggested tour and you will see everything . Regular performances in front of the kabuki theater . Nice overview of tokyo from the restaurant on the 7e floor!

Unexpectedly amusing!. I went to visit this museum without high expectations because I thought that it's going to be just another historical gallery. Furthermore, knowing that the permanent exhibit is located on the 6th floor made me feel less excited. But upon entering the museum from the 3rd floor, I started to become impressed. For some reason, I liked the chronological pictures on the walls of the escalator.My impression just got better once I entered the main exhibit. I thought the life-size model of Nihonbashi Bridge was just stunning. The small replicas of the old Edo towns were also quite impressive. I thought that these would just awe children but I was wrong. The artists behind these displays did a very good job depicting old Tokyo.The other exhibits were also worth seeing. I particularly liked the way they put things in chronological order, which clearly showed how Japanese fashion, architecture, and their way of life changed from pre-war to post-war times. - Highly recommended for families. - Better add a visit to the Sumo Stadium, especially if there's a match. - If interested and willing, a chanko nabe for lunch would add to the experience.

Please go, it's the best in Tokyo!. This place is AWESOME! The museum is very easy to get to from the metro station; just follow the signs that say 'Edo-Tokyo Museum', and follow the crowds; they're all going to the same place! The structure of the museum itself is fascinating; it's a massive raised building, and you can see the Tokyo Skytree from underneath the showfloor of the museum (in that weird open-air part). The entry fee to the museum was nominal; I just paid for the permanent exhibits, not for any of the temporary ones. I also recommend hitting the gift shop at the entrance FIRST, since it's possible you'll leave from another exit. The gift shop is great and has some unique gifts if you're looking for that sort of thing.The staff will escort you to the top floor, where you're to start your tour, by guiding you to the escalator. Once you're on the top floor, it's amazing, and let the fun begin! There's plenty of hands-on activities; amazingly detailed models, and entirely relocated buildings. There's plenty to learn, see, and do, and I can't emphasize enough how grand this museum is. This is the only museum I visited in Tokyo, and I'm glad I chose this one, because I had an absolute blast!

Really enjoyed our visit. We spent a good 3 hours in the museum with the free English speaking guide. It is very I testing and had some great exhibits of the history of Tokyo. Would recommend.
Also we had lunch at Finns Cafe which was also good

Take a tour with a volunteer guide. An interesting museum about Japan and Japanese culture. I suggest to take about two hours to visit the museum and between 10am-15pm there are volunteer guides offering a complimentary private tour (their English is perfect).

Hands-on history. After a wander through the Ryoguku sumo district we stopped at the Edo Museum - a huge, weird-looking building that starts with an escalator to the top floor.It was a really interesting journey through the Edo period of history but it brings you right up to the present day and the more recent (second world war, 1950s, 1960s and 1970s) displays were also fascinating.The mixture of displays, interactive items, miniature landscapes, full-size replica rooms, replicas of old furniture you could climb on or into, clothing, and more meant it was much better than a traditional 'dry' set of displays.We spent two hours there and could have spent longer except our feet were tired.

Huge and interesting . Huge structure and interesting exibitions for this beautiful museum that explains the story of Tokyo from the origins of Edo until today. The reconstructions of ancient buildings are impressive and bery well done. Absolutely worth to visit!

Fascinating looking into the origins of Tokyo. This is a very large museum - stepping into the main hall with a life-size reconstruction of half of the original wooden Nihombashi bridge sets the scene for the scale.The museum essentially comprises two halves: the history of Edo, and the history of Tokyo - Edo is the city that Tokyo grew from.There are lots of exhibits of artefacts to see, as well as models of how the city of Edo used to be. Fortunately the information presented is in English as well as Japanese making this museum very accessible to tourists. The museum does get quite busy though so be aware.Photography is also permitted and there are some great opportunities.Highly recommended as a great introduction to one of the greatest of the world's cities.

Great City Museum. Edo-Tokyo Museum located just next to Ryogoku Subway Station Exit A3 Elevator (Oedo Line Subway), if you are using JR Pass, just around the corner for the Ryogoku JR Station (less than 5 minutes walk). Entrance fee is 600 Yen for permanent exhibition. The museum provides "volunteer english guide" & audio guide, but I decided to skip it. I was skeptical at first, and worried that I wouldn't be able to understand the exhibitions. But, if you follow the markers based on provided map (E1 = Edo section 1, and T1 = Tokyo section1), it takes you step by step thru the evolution of the city. There are english signs and explanations everywhere, easy to read and make sense of it.There are interactive items/objects for photos, and tryouts, also watch out for scheduled presentations. One of the presentations was "Behind the scene of Kabuki", pretty cool to watch.Took me 2-3 hours to finish the tour, and hang around the souvenir shop.If you want to know about the city, this will be your stop.

Interesting place to visit. The Edo Musuem was part of our group itinerary and I am glad we visited.It gave us a valuable insight into the Edo heritage. There is much to see and it is very well presented.We happened to visit at the same time as a large school visit. It was great to see the boys and girls in their smart school uniforms and the interaction between us was fun. Hope we did not distract from the teachers purpose of their visit - to educate their kids. We certainly were educated as to this part of their history.

Recommended to people fascinated by cities. You can learn a great deal about Tokyo by visiting this museum. It also has a good restaurant with excellent views over parts of Tokyo. It is easily accessed from Ryogoku station.
Visit from Edo thru Tokyo history. Edo Tokyo Museum provides a panorama of Tokyo history from it's Tokugawa Edo period to WWII Tokyo, thru Meiji restoration.

Very well presented and informative. You are at risk of information overload here. There are so many exhibits. But there is also the fun side with many photo opportunities. Volunteer guides available in different languages as well as audio guides. A great introduction.

Very interesting, and very elegant meseum. There are a lots of reprouction of the life and the tradition of the old Tokyo. Elegat kimono are exposted and a big ship. Bfore the exit there is a very big shop full of every kind of japanese souvenirs.

Educational Yet Fun. I thoroughly enjoyed my recent visit to the museum. 600 yen for an adult admission was very fair. Extra if you want to see the special exhibits. You can request for a guide for your group in English, Chinese and Japanese. Even though I was by myself, I received given a personal guided tour of the permanent exhibit. My guide was wonderful! You can easily go through without a guide. But I learned so much from the guided tour. Models and replicas of the Edo period life and neighborhoods help you understand what it was like living in that time. Many displays are hands on like riding in a rickshaw and carriage or living in a traditional Japanese home. I think the museum is very complete in touching on so many sub-topics of the Edo period. The exhibit halls are spacious and open. Very comfortable even when busy.There was also a life show in the performance stage area. Very entertaining. Part of the exhibit was also about the history and evolution of one of the first and biggest family owned department store in Japan. Great gift selections in the gift shop. I spent over an hour there. Very happy I came to this museum.

Terrific Museum. My wife and I really liked this museum. It had great exhibits about Japanese history, culture, and life. I would go early in your Japan visit because of how much you can learn. The exhibits are very accessible and English is prevalent.

Great Place to Visit. In the Edo Tokyo museum, you'll learn about how Edo transformed itself from a small village to the modern day Tokyo. There are many exhibits to see. You are allowed to take photos while visiting the permanent exhibition. The current special exhibition features Sanada Nobushige, or popularly known as Sanada Yukimura. I would not suggest this exhibit to anyone who is unable to read Japanese or is unfamiliar with the Sengoku period. The special exhibit is mostly in Japanese and has minimal English descriptions.

real size nihon-bashi(nihon bridge) and miniture of edo castle!. there's a lot to see and experience of edo/tokyo and helps to understand how people used to live. their diorama of the part of the castle and city are really fun to look at. at the giorama of ryogoku in summer, the speaker tells stories of what's going on in a giorama but it's all in japanese so ask the volanteer to explain to you if you could find anybody..there're so much going on and well planned too like: thief is pick pocketting on a bridge, rich man having a party on a boat with geisha, a shop girl calling for customer..etc. the sushi back in days were much more bigger and how tiny the each family space was..if you enjoy this type of museum, i'm sure you'd like fukagawa edo museum, edo-tokyo open archetectual museum(tatemonoen). also furukawa teien(garden), tokyo metropolitan teien art museum and kyu-iwasakitei-gardens for maiji archetect lovers to recommend.

In. The museum is located very close to the subway station Ryogoku. The building is modern and the museum is very interesting and gives much information about the history of Tokyo. I especially liked the part of the 20th century history. There was a school class of children about 10 years old and it was obvious that they found it very interesting.

Beautiful and fun!. This is a really nice museum with life size buildings and houses. It was so interesting to see life in Tokyo up to the present day. Kid friendly and tourist friendly. Worth the visit!

Edo Tokyo Museum. If you have an extra day and interested in history, culture and way of life in the past, I highly recommend this museum. Life size models of local interior homes are realistic. Getting there may be a chore but it is worth it. You need a good 2 hours to enjoy everything on display, excluding travelling time.

So much to see here!. The museum has two full floors of exhibitions that tell story of Japan from Edo to modern era. Many types of items are chosen to display here from amazing scale models to real size home model to prints to many things that will make you go wow! This place is totally worth the visit. Spare lots of time to explore the museum!

A must visit. This is an excellent museum with lots to see. Life size buildings, scale models and so interesting. As a plus there is plenty of comfy seating so you can sit and view some of the exhibits.

Super City Museum. One of the best city museums i ever visited. The epic Nihonbashi bridge greets visitors. You see Tokyo then known as Edo being founded by the Tokugawa family. You will see their opulence through the model of the Edo Castle and various houses of Lords. You will encounter many Tokugawa Edo era paraphernalias. You will have a glimpse of the daily lives of the people of old Edo. After visiting the model of Kabuki Theater and its life sized mannequins, you will be transported into modern Tokyo. You will see Edo as it evolves into Tokyo. Western influences start to permeate Tokyo through the western dioramas and old Ginza. You will see development of the clothes of the people, heritage houses, life in war times, toys, games, fashion trends in the modern era ending by visiting another simple Japanese house. Great museum, too much to see, you should alot 2 to 3 hours at least to see everything. You can find time to relax on the third floor balcony just after you descended from the museum for fresh air. Gift shops can be found ground floor. Surely a great alternative to the TNM in Ueno Park.

It is a great intro into Tokyo and it's growth over the years. A very well thought out and displayed in a way to entertain people of all ages and interests. This is not your typical stuffy museum. From the spaceship invoking design of the building, with the reproduction of several ancient buildings and miniatures aplenty of various stages of Edo's (Tokyo) development. It opens a window into the lives of the people over the past few centuries.

more than miniatures. First of all, Edo is pronouced "eddo" with a short "e", not "eedo". We found out when asking for directions. It is right next to the subway station and is extremely accessible. The fee costs only 600 yen. Special exhibits will cost extra. The services include free volunteer tour guides in different languages. Edo museum has alot of interesting facts explaining everything related to Edo life, including social ranks, royal residences, living quarters of common people, occupations, art, entertainment, disasters, fire fighting, water way systems, etc... It is very informative, but more fun than a typical museum. You can walk up close or into replicas of the living quarters, pick up the box of silver coins that the merchants carried, get into the palanquin and pose for a picture, and learn what's behind the stage of a Kabuki theater. Even if you are not typically a museum kind of person I think you will still enjoy Edo museum.

The absolute highlight of our Tokyo trip. One of the coolest museums I have ever been to. We went here with our 2 boys (ages 6 & 9) and they were rapt the entire time. One half of the museum is all sorts of miniatures depicting life in Tokyo over the centuries. The other half is highly interactive and informative displays (in English and Japanese) about life in Tokyo. I cannot recommend this place enough!

If you like miniatures, this is the best place I have ever been. I have not been to the miniatur wunderland in Hamburg but so far this is the best. see pictures I attached, a picture is worth a thousand words.

No need of too much reading.. A very well laid out museum with great artifacts-replicas without a need for too much explanation or reading. Very interactive as well. To enjoy Not only behind the glass but to actually feel and and touch and sit and walk ... Etc etc.A must when in Tokyo !

Great Miniatures. A fantastic museum with plenty of great displays. Awesome miniature models and full-size replicas of what it was like living in Tokyo from the Edo period through to the modern day. It was interesting to see how quickly things changed for the average Tokyou family with the industrial revolution and then the post-war rebuild. While not every sign is in English, there are enough translations to cover most of it, and you can also get an English-speaking guide (and other languages) for free!
Really interesting museum from Edo period. Learn so much during this visit, how the society has been organized, with wonderful miniature presentations of houses, villages, community...

Worth it. This museum was super easy to get to, right off the Chuo-Sobu local JR line, Ryogoku stop. It's got a great gift shop. The museum has both life size replicas and miniatures. Don't get the English audio guide -- it just repeats the information available on English signs. Many of the smaller pieces/displays don't have English explanations, but there is enough that do to make it really interesting if you like history. I spent a couple of hours here.

Stunning . Wow.. This museum blew me away. I spent several hours here and I am so glad that I did. Learned so much more about Tokyo and Japan- from the Edo period. Wonderful presentations and even saw a musical performance.

One of the best museums to visit. The Edo Tokyo musuem is divided into the Edo period (1603 to 1868)and Tokyo period post 1868. The artifacts, particularly for the Edo period were fascinating. The attention to detail was great. All exhibits are explained in English and a free English audio guide is provided on request. Very reasonably priced and even kids will be engaged. Strongly recommend. Keep minimum 3 hours. Saturday is best as the musuem has extended hours on Saturday.

Excellent museum. The museum provides an excellent historical look at Tokyo with plenty of signage in English. A highlight is the exquisite scale models of the city and various important buildings. There are a number of interactive exhibits, including some full-size replicas of rooms in houses. The restaurant on the top floor serves great food. We enjoyed the seasonal bento boxes.

江戸東京博物館 Edo Tokyo Museum. Of course I can't recommend a visit here more than enough for history fans. I learnt a lot about life for Bushi during the Edo period at this museum, although there is also stuff here from ancient Japan as well as modern Japan (Meiji era onwards). It's also ideal for tourists as there are plenty of English explanations on the exhibitions as well as pamphlets. The models alone here, some of them life-sized, make Edo-Tokyo worth a visit.

Wonderful Experience!. This was definitely one of the highlights of the trip! You are able to get the feeling of how living in the Edo period was. Information is available in english. Lots of history to learn in an interactive way. You can find life sized models of towns, villages, people and more! There are many picture opportunities here. I loved the bridge and the theater replicas inside as well as all the vehicles used back then.The gift shop there is also amazing and prices are fair. It is a must-see for children and adults.

This place was okay, not totally what I was expecting. I probably should have had a bit more insight from the name, but this museum is actually about the city of Tokyo. I'm not totally sure what it was, I'm usually a big museum person, but I didn't really find this one particularly interesting as a foreign tourist. Maybe if I was Japanese and had more context it would have been very interesting, but I found myself moving through quickly and not being too interested.

A must experience. We cannot exaggerate how much we learned at this museum. Much of that was due to our guide, Kunio Sanui. He was waiting at the desk that said free tours in English. He immediately came forward to provide a private tour for the two of us. This wonderful gentleman took us through the museum for about three hours. We covered the history of Tokyo which used to be called Edo. We are still touring Japan and every day we refer back to what we learned at this.museum. It has enhanced all of our other experiences. Even without a guide the museum has an incredible amount of information to offer. We hope you have a guide as wonderful as Kunio Sanui.
Worth your while.. A very interesting view of ancient Tokyo, its way of life, traditions, culture, old vs modern. A very strong must. Vacate at least 2 hours to tour this extraordinary establishment.

Muita história com um acervo impressionante. . The Edo-Tokyo Museum (江戸東京博物館 Edo Tōkyō Hakubutsukan?) is a museum of the history of Tokyo during the Edo period. It was established in 1993. The main features of the permanent exhibitions are the life-size replica of the Nihonbashi, which was the bridge leading into Edo; the Nakamurazatheatre; and scale models of towns and buildings from the Edo, Meiji and Shōwa periods. The museum is adjacent to theRyōgoku Kokugikan. It was designed byKiyonori Kikutake. The distinctive elevated shape of the museum building is modelled after an old storehouse in the kurazukuri style.The Edo-Tokyo Open Air Architectural Museum is a branch of the Edo-Tokyo Museum.

A lovely treat. We took the kids to the Edo-Tokyo Museum today after a full morning exploring the backstreets of Tokyo in the rain. Upon first sight of the impressive building, we were all excited to take a look inside.We were not disappointed with the visit. The Museum features the rich history of Tokyo during the Edo period. We stuck to the permanent exhibitions and all enjoyed the exhibits of the Edo, Meiji and Shōwa periods. Despite being tired and a little hungry, it kept our children well amused and interested for a good few hours. The chance to explore the different homes and buildings, and a good mix of hands-on displays were effective ways of both informing and amusing us all.As English speakers with virtually no Japanese, we had no problem understanding the bulk of the features, and the volunteer guides were very friendly and helpful. Given the very cheap entrance fee (the kids were both free), I could not recommend it more highly!

Great cultural and historic site to visit. We chose this over the other museums at Ueno park because many travelers suggest this museum has the best resources for a foreigner to understand the exhibits. It was a good call - the exhibits all have Chinese, English and Korean translations at all spots in addition to Japanese. The museum talks about the Edo period up to the modern Tokyo and is very lively because it has some big architectural remakes almost live size and the whole space has a good, open atmosphere. You can almost take photos of everything, some even with flash, but be aware than some side exhibits have special non-photo rules. This is easily a 3 hours stop. Must see if you want to choose a museum to visit in Tokyo.

Delightful Afternoon. The Edo-Tokyo Museum is a delightful way to spend an afternoon. There are pieces of art, historical artwork and interactive pieces throughout the permanent exhibit. The exhibits were had placks in Japanese, English and many had a tablet with multiple translation in other languages (Chinese, German...). Our family really enjoyed the museum. My son, 11 year old boy, had a lot of fun with the interactive bikes and rickshaws. Recommended for families and people who want to learn more about the Edo period of Japan.

Enjoyed it. It was raining in Tokyo. What better activity there is than this wonderful learning experience. The models were very well made. By the time we went, there were no English speaking guides. I am sure if there was one available then, the experience would be more meaningful. By all means engage a guide who can explain the history of Tokyo. Getting a guide is free.

First Rate History. This museum sets a standard that is hard to beat.It covers the period when Japan was effectively ruled by the Shoguns, whose power base was Edo Castle, and Tokyo was then called Edo, up until it changed its name in 1868.The life styles of both the upper ruling classes and the ordinary populace are illustrated through detailed models of streets, buildings and even individual rooms. Some of the models are scale models, but others are life size, such as the frontage of a Kabuki Theatre.
