All the exhibits are clearly described with detailed captions in Japanese and English, as well as six other languages (French, German, Spanish, Russian, Chinese and Korean) giving the same information via a computer screen.In addition to the models, there is a wealth of information on the Edo period in the various displays around the walls of the museum. Free volunteer guides are also available to give turs, if requested, whilst other practical displays occur from time to time. Of the museums I visited in Tokyo, this was the best one.

Fun museum and informative!. This is a great museum to visit to learn about the Edo Tokyo. There are wonderful models of buildings and historical areas including first department store. There are a lot of information on the history, culture and daily life in Edo although most of the details are in Japanese. I think there's an audio guide for rent too. There are quite a few things you can touch and try out for yourself. The best part is the free show on juggling in front of the first newspaper building. The traditional performer was fantastic and very skilled! We spent over 2 hours there and still couldn't see everything. It's open until 7 pm on Saturdays. We didn't do the temporary exhibit which costs extra.

Excellent History/Culture Museum. The main exhibits detail life during the Edo period. Additional or temporary exhibits are usually very good, as was the Da Vinci exhibit in early 2016. Allow 2 hours for your visit (main exhibit) or more.

Wonderful. Wonderful museum with lots to see. Talks about the different periods that Tokyo went through (trade, war etc). Was good to see more on World War Two as well which the Hiroshima museum lacked. We didn't go to the special exhibit but there was more than enough to see in the regular sections. Lots was available to be translated in other languages as well through little screens where you could select your language choice. This was very helpful for us as we couldn't read Japanese. Definitely one of the better museums in Japan.

A wonderful museum. We traveled to the museum on the train from Shinjuku station. Very easy to do with no changing trains. The rappong (sp?) station was easy to navigate with signs to the museum. Simply loved the museum. Very well laid out with wonderful exhibits. Several were interactive for kids. Make sure to wander back and around the lower floor as several of the largest exhibits are hidden behind other exhibits. We are big museum people and this is one of best. Enjoy!

Old Japanese Culture Captured. Had 2 hours n only visited the permanent exhibits; 5 & 6 floor showing old Japanese villages, castle n Edo period way of life. From these exhibits, can really see how meticulous Japanese have been since Edo era!!

Very interesting. Do go to this museum. It will take about 1-2 hrs. Good for children as well as history buffs. There are impressive dioramas with hundreds of tiny figurines (and binoculars for detailed viewing) as well as full sized replica buildings and life size models so it gives a really good feel for Tokyo of the past. There is lots to see, touch and experience. Look for the painting depicting a samurai getting dressed showing the many layers of clothing required.
Lovely museum. Very informative I like the fact you are allowed to touch things and go into buildings. The small figures in the village scenes have amazing details ideal for all the family

A "must" for Japanese History geeks. Every guidebook and website recommends this museum for a reason. I can't say anything that hasn't been said. You pretty much have to go here if you want to know how Tokyo became such an awesome city. History geek central.

Great museum!. My family really liked this museum. The miniature dioramas of historical scenes were wonderful; the binoculars to peer at the little people were a nice touch, my six-year-old loved it. Lots of hands-on stuff, too, like being able to get on an old bike, try to pick up water-carrying baskets, walk through a typical '50s house, etc. Really an interesting overview of Tokyo history, including a good section on World War II. We spent almost three hours here, could have spent more. A well-curated little gift shop, too. The permanent exhibition seems to be on the top two floors of the building; there was a special exhibition on the ground floor when we were there. Note for seniors: they had a free-for-over-65 admission day when we were there; it's apparently called "Silver Day" and it's the third Wednesday of every month, though would check that before you go to make sure it doesn't change!

Good history musuem. Interesting museum filled with miniature models depicting Edo period. Museum steps you through this history to modern day Tokyo. Pretty expansive, if you stop and read it will take several hours to go through. Good for a rainy day activity.
Interesting museum. You can find a lot of informations and miniatures of Edo then Tokyo in this museum You can spend time of course but you can see the essential in 1 hour

Amazing Building and exhibits . There is enough in this museum to keep you busy for a day.The evolution of Tokyo was fascinating as were the life size displays.However very few of the displays are properly or adequately translated. So if you go either pay for a tour or the audio guide.

Good exhibits, and a complete bridge and facade of Kabuki theatre. The museum has a typical house with tatami mats as well, and the day we were there, had a couple of performers playing traditional music on the stage of the Kabuki theatre. It is a good size to see most in a couple of hours, and has a good restaurant on the top floor where you can sit. Typical Japanese cuisine.

Very Informative History of Tokyo. I really enjoyed this museum which provided a very informative history and evolution of Tokyo from the time when it was called Edo to present day Tokyo. The museum is quite spacious and well-laid out. Even with the many school children visiting, it didn’t feel crowded. There are enough signs in English to understand the displays.The unique design of the exterior of the museum is also worth seeing. I had combined my visit to this museum with a visit to the nearby Skytree.

Excellent place to visit. This museum is one of my most favorite place in Tokyo. You can spend all day since there are so many things to see/learn and enjoy. If you get tired, they even provide nice restaurants inside of the museum. When you visit Tokyo, visit this place, especially, if you are a traveler and have a rainy day, this is definitely a place to spend time.

Excellent and fun discovery of the city history!. This museum is actually bigger than what I first thought and my only issue is that I did not take time to read all the information available.More out of laziness than anything else (it was the last museum visit of our Japan trip). It displays all you might want to know about Tokyo, its past, and its organization. Whether it concerns politics, business, arts, or daily life, everything is explained there. My favourite part is the one showing how drawings were printed (one wooden block for each colour)! Everything is presented in a fun way so children can enjoy the visit as well. There are some activities in the museum and seats if visitors want to have a break. There is also a nice shop with cards, jewelry, decorative items and various accessories. Good place to visit if you are in Tokyo!

Great Way to Learn About Evolution of Tokyo. Visited this museum by accident last year when in Tokyo and found it very informative. They have volunteer guides with many language skills so that they can explain the evolution of Tokyo in your home language.Very informative and interesting as it not only covers how Tokyo evolved but also the history of Japan.Well worth a visit.

Not as good as it is made out to be ... lots of local school kids ... some interesting history but that is it!!. Not as good as it is made out to be ... lots of local school kids ... some interesting history but that is it!!
There were some interesting exhibits set up reflecting Tokyo-Edo history but honestly it is a pretty small museum and really touristy and crowded ... I liked the Tokyo National Museum much more.

Unusual and interesting. The whole story of the fascinating and ancient city of Tokyo in an interesting and easily digestible layout. The building is a crazy sight in itself and you will almost certainly spot some sumo wrestlers on your walk from the train station. Allow 2 hours for a good look at the main collection only, 3 hours for an exhaustive one.

Interesting collection, well resented. Visited the Edo-Tokyo Museum together with familly and friends. There was (I admit) a slight reluctance on the part of our teenager to participate on this excursion but out fears were unfolded when we discovered there were English-speaking guides available at no extra charge. We were assigned an elderly gentleman who's English language and knowledge of the exhibits was very good, and with an excellent humor to match! These together proved to be a winner and we could enjoy a very pleasant couple hours learning about Edo and Tokyo.

Great museum for Japanese history. At the entrance of the museum there are staff members that volunteer to give the tourists a guided tour, I really recommend that for people who aren't able to read the Japanese explanations, even for those who can. The volunteers give you a guided tour with a lot more information than what is written down, small anecdotes and small stories that can change the perspective from which you see things.

Fascinating history of Tokyo, great exhibits. I'm not usually much of a museum person, but this one I really enjoyed. Exhibits were interesting -- I especially loved the miniature dioramas and the life-size displays of the streets and homes.

Spacious, with well-arranged exhibits. The exhibits were mainly large and interesting dioramas of the Edo-period. (The tiny human figurines make the dioramas more interesting that it sounds. They're actually posed in "action" - talking, quarreling, doing stuff - it's not just hundreds of tiny stock figures standing upright.) There are also more standard museum-type exhibits - old scrolls and documents, old clothes, etc. Some displays are interactive, meaning it's good for kids or for those of us who don't like just reading info. I rather liked the old radio that was programmed to play specific radio clips from pre-war/wartime Japan. Many of the displays had English descriptions, which was also useful.

Must go if you want to know Tokyo's history. I recommend this museum on the first day of your visit to Tokyo, if you really want to understand Tokyo. It's a unique museum, and there are live performance of music and/or dance twice a day. I strongly recommend this museum.

Fascinating history. I stopped here on my way to the airport but I should have budgeted much more time. This museum provided fascinating insights into Tokyo's development into a modern city. The exhibits were beautifully done.

Amazing Museum. I arrived at 4 o'clock and the museum closed at 5:30 and I was only half way done with the museum, the displays are fantastic from scale models to life size reproductions of buildings inside the museum itself. Tons of artifacts and hands on exhibits as well. Has to be my favorite museum in Tokyo so far.

Slightly underwhelming despite its focus. I must admit to being underwhelmed by this immense museum after visiting the small Shitamachi museum in Ueno the day before. The Edo Museum is too huge and trying hard to be modern, innovative and clever that it sort of ruins the message of history and tradition that they are trying to convey. The small and intimate version of the Shitamachi museum is much more effective in its retelling of the story of Tokyo in the Edo period. In the Edo Museum, the dioramas of Edo/Tokyo street scenes are impressive both in terms of scale and detail, but too huge to be appreciated fully (you literally need the binoculars provided to see individual figures! That is, if you can get hold of one amongst the crowd around the edges). The displays were hard to interpret and the lighting made it difficult to take photographs. It was nice to see a reconstruction of the Edo Castle in relation to the surrounding streetscape and we really wanted to relate what we saw of the remnants of the Imperial Castle compound earlier to the diorama of the same area, but it was so difficult to make sense! All the historical information on the wall displays would have been interesting if only there were more details in English - only the very basic information is translated and seems pitched to school children. The Edo period is very interesting but we were left wanting to know more. The building replicas also looked just too clean, too crisp, too new. This is a museum for locals with local details in a spacious modern style. I am so pleased we went to the Shitamachi museum first. I will certainly go back to the Shitamachi in Ueno - the Edo Museum may be worth a visit if you are in the Ryoguko area for the sumo wrestling or if it is raining.
Worth visiting !!!. A nice museum which you can visit in 1,5 hours. There are beautiful Japanese rooms and different plans of Edo.

Fascinating insight into the Edo history of Japan. This is a really interesting museum located within walking distance of Kuramae. Loads of information and displays of various aspects of life during this period. Well worth a look if you are interested in Japanese history. Allow more than 2 hours if possible. We were there for 2 hours as we were limited with our time and found it engrossing. We didn't quite get around all of the displays. We visited just the permanent display. They have visiting exhibitions as well, however we didn't have the time to view the current one.

For those who love Japanese Culture History and anyone whose interested to Learn.. I am not a museum person but this is my favourite museum from all my travels, if you are into Japanese Culture and History you’re going to love it here. Japan has an interesting culture going back centuries this museum shows the Edo period which goes back to ancient times showcasing ancient Japanese people from their ordinary daily lives to commerce and business. The museum shows descriptions written in English and Japanese, there are a lot of artifacts and small scale of castles and structures, and a lot of artworks and maps of ancient Japan. The Museum also shows the modern Era from the Meiji Era. The museum is a must see in Tokyo, it’s easy to find close to the Ryogoku Station.

Great museum . Was great to be able to learn about Japanese history. It covers the edo period up until the modern days. I was fortunate enough to get a English speaking guide which made it more interactive and easy to learn about as he went much more in depth than what was explained on the boards. That is not to say the English explanation which is on just about every display is sufficient but I just like fun facts. There are also plenty of interactive displays so you can experience what people needed to carry on their day to day lives. The translating guides are fully volunteer guides which are available from 1100 - 1500 so they're not always going to be available right away or outside those hours. And at 1500 that is when the guide ends so if you need a guide arrive early.

Maybe the best city history museum in the world. I've been to Japan twice and this museum 3 times, it never fails to impress. As a museum for the history of a city, I think its only competition may be the City of London museum. The exhibits cover the Edo period through modern times (2000). The models of the early city are incredibly well-done. The staff are friendly, you might be able to catch a free tour guide in your language (eg. English) at the start of your visit. To cap things off, the gift store is a great place to get souvenirs, particularly Japanese towels and handkerchiefs, at a good price. We ate at the Italian restaurant on museum grounds. Not the best Italian ever, but food was good, reasonably priced, and low hassle for an English speaker. Only 1 of my 4 photos is NOT of a model.

Hands on Museum Experience . Our family of four spent a morning in the engaging Edo-Tokyo museum. The special exhibit was on Leonardo DiVinci and had numerous sketches and art pieces. The fee was 1600 per adult and 700 per child for both the special exhibit and the permanent exhibit. I believe the Di Vinci exhibit lasts until April 2016. It is worth the time and money to visit this exhibit. Overall impressions of the permanent exhibit:Child #1 "I enjoyed the interactive parts of the museum and the models". This museum has a number of exhibits that kids (and adults) can climb into, pick up and touch. Wear clean socks- shoes have to be removed at various hands on portions. Child #2 "I enjoyed climbing on the big bicycles and rickshaws." He was also shocked to see the model homes that lacked a television. He also spent a great deal of time learning about the Tokyo air raids. There is a great deal of English, explaining about the exhibits! We did not eat there, but the museum has a cafe and several gift shops. There is always a ton to do and see in Tokyo but we recommend this museum!

engaging exhibits and explanations of Tokyo history and culture. The museum offers well-staged exhibits and descriptions (written in English and several other foreign languages) of Tokyo's past and present. There is much to see, read, and absorb: scale models (e.g. Edo Castle), artwork and crafts, maps, re-created building facades and typical residences, etc. For people (both young and old) interested in the city and its history, the museum is a worthwhile visit.

Loved this museum. We planned to go to the Sumo museum but on arrival discovered it was closed during the tournament weeks, so we went to Edo-Tokyo instead. We were lucky enough to be offered a one hour guided tour with a lovely lady who spoke excellent English. Her charm and enthusiasm for the artefacts ensured that we both enjoyed our visit and learnt a lot.After the tour we explored some more on our own, it really is a stunning museum with so much to discover and even when the signage fails, there are English speaking staff who will be able to fill in the gaps. The cafes are ok too, one does a sort of tea ceremony but I think you need to prebook as it was full when we went.

Best museum I have visited in Tokyo. If you're interested in Japanese history, then I would recommend this museum over some of the others located in Ueno Park. I really enjoyed the numerous models and various displays throughout the facility. If you're into WWII history, there is a large section dedicated to what it was like to live in Tokyo during the air raids, and gives perspective on how much Tokyo has flourished since then. This was my favorite attraction in Tokyo and recommend it to anyone visiting.

Wonderfully presented history of tokyo. This is a very impressive museum. Lots of small and large scale models, including a bridge, houses etc, and artefacts charting the history of Tokyo from the Edo period to now. Impressive collection, and many English signs, don't really need the audio guide, though it is free. There are also guides who will show you around, we didn't have one but listened in on occassion. We spent three hours wandering around. Reasonable price to enter at 600 yen.

An entire day at the Edo Tokyo Museum. What a wonderful museum from start to finish!After the purchase of my ticket, I took the escalator up to the 6th floor and what met by the signs...free Guide ( in many languages). They asked me from what country I was from and what language I would like from the Guide.Thus, we started on almost 3 hours of interesting displays and history about the formation of Edo...the current Tokyo right up to today.Excellent and interesting from start to finish.One must gets there early in the day before all the children come with their school classes...

Good for some history without taking your whole day. This museum shows the development of Tokyo from feudal times to the modern day. The building alone is worth seeing from the outside. Inside is a big open floor plan, with good display, many interactive. The displays and accompanying information are informative without being overwhelming. Recommend for those that want to get a sense of how Tokyo became what it is today, but don't want to spend their entire Tokyo visit in museums looking at fine china collections.

Great museum for all ages!. Very impressive exhibitions of Edo-Tokyo and its history. Interactive opportunities that will entertain kids young and old. Seemed to appeal to both Japanese and international visitors.

Great look at early Tokyo . It was great to spend a couple of hours wondering through the museum. Currently there is a special exhibition of Italian art on the first floor associated with Leonardo da Vinci which is worth a look before heading to the 6th floor and the Edo-Tokyo history. I would suggest putting a couple of hours aside otherwise you will miss some of the history.

Good historic view of early Tokyo.. We enjoyed the Edo portion of this museum. There was sufficient english signage to make it enjoyable. The woodblock print section was also excellent. It would have been nice for some of the big signs to have a little more english.

Very educational. This is a very educational museum with lots of structures, models and buildings rebuilt inside the museum including a section of the Tokyo Bridge. Each exhibits are carefully documented and most of them have been translated into English for foreigners. You may need 3 hours at least inside this museum. So make sure you time yourself right. The museum can be reached by JR or by subway. JR station is closer if you don't have the subway pass (3 days unlimited subway pass - ¥1,500). The station to get off is Ryogoku Station. On the side, the sumo stadium is next to the museum. So if the season is correct, maybe you want to visit the stadium to watch the sumo matches. But tickets go fast. Get in online in advance and if not, 350 tickets will be sold in the morning at the door. Unless you go really early, otherwise you might not be able to get one (just like me this morning). A very educational museum if you want to brush up your Japanese history if you have 3 hours. Highly recommended.

This is a great history of the city. I visited here one afternoon and was impressed by the detail and history on offer in the museum. It covers the time from ancient Edo right through to modern Tokyo with plenty of models, photos, displays and some live interactions. There is plenty of English translations as well. It's perhaps not dynamic enough to capture the attention of the kids but, for anyone older, its a great account of the history of one of the world's most important cities.

Interesting museum. I visited the museum with my Matsudo friends, Mari and Yuko. The exhibits were thoughtfully presented and I am most impressed with the interactive ones where a visitor can experience each one in action.Followed by Leonardo da Vinci's exhibition.

A time capsule of Tokyo history. 1. For those who want to have some understanding of Tokyo history, the museum is the best place to come. With real-size models, people can know more about the history of Tokyo city even though your Japanese is not very good.2. Via online reservation, visitors can join English introduction guided by some Japanese seniors. They can speak simple English and they are friendly.3. There are some models which can be experienced by visitors like the ancient fire-fighting instrument and food stands. A fun place for both adults and children.4. No food and drinks during your visit. Eating and drinking are only allowed at the resting area.

Absolutely worthwhile. Very close to the Ryogoku Kokugikan, the Edo-Tokyo Museum throws you into the Tokyo area history in a very interactive, interesting and detailed way. Artifacts and graphic panels lead the way to interactive activities and reproductions - miniaturized and actual sized - of historical locations and scenarios, both of which are unbelievably executed. Particularly interesting the section dedicated to the modern japanese life through the different decades, which gives you a clear idea of the chronology, linked to everyday items and lifestyle. Don't miss this if you are visiting Tokyo.

Very worthwhile visit!. This is a delightful, modern museum that is laid out in a very open and spacious way. If you have the time, be sure to ask for a free (your language) tour guide at the entrance to the exhibition area. They are volunteers and have great knowledge and passion for the museum and Tokyo's history.We (a couple) had a guide to ourselves and learned so much. The exhibits are interactive and interesting, giving great insight into the city's culture, people, and historical evolution in a very accessible and entertaining way. Our guide was excellent and spoke perfect English. It's very popular with school groups, but is not childish at all. Plan for 2 hours to take everything in on your own or if with a guide.We enjoyed pastries and coffee at the onsite café; the museum shops are also very nice. Visiting both the National and Edo-Tokyo Museums during our time in Tokyo were very worthwhile, highly recommend!

Best museum in Tokyo. This smithsonian style museum is surely worth a visit. This museum has a lot of hands on and interactive exhibits which are entertaining for all ages. The history presented here is largely unknown to those who have not studied Japanese history and presented in an easy to learn way. Also there is great food in the museum restaurant

Interactive and detailed look into history. I've never had so much fun as I did in the Edo Museum.From crossing the replica of the Nihonbashi into a feudal Edo where we scrutinize the detailed miniature scene of a day in the business district.Here you don't only glance at it, but it also invites you to look for certain scenes that they've described in the clue cards for you to find with their readily prepared binoculars. It was so much fun, I competed with my husband to see who could find all the scenes first.There were even replicas of fish monger baskets and war banners so you can experience the actual weight of it all. Plus even life sized cottages you can peek and walk in to.Overall it was a very informative, eye opening and fun museum visit.

Visit if you have spare time.. The building has poor programme that tie the activities together. Some interesting stuff and history but was hoping to see more artifact. The museum is however within the sumo zone with practice stables, wrestling stadiums, shops etc.

Good insight on Edo culture . Most of the displays here are recreated artifacts for educational purposes. Ask for English guide and staff is very helpful. You can see numerous miniature castles from Edo time and get a great insight on political and social structures. Living style of peasants, markets everything recreated with miniature. Life size kabuki theater, actors, nihonbashi bridge are highlights. Can't recommend this for a traveler visiting Japan but keep this on your list definalty if you are in Japan for school or long term work.
Edo Museum. Edo museum near many place to travel, u can see Sumo stadiam, many things.. 1 day is never enough....

a bit of history. Great little museum that is easy to get to by subway or train. lots of information and dioramas about the edo period in Japanese history, as well as Japan through the second world war. loved all the costume displays from the past to modern times. interesting to see how clothing has changed. well worth a visit. There are two cafes on the ground level available in the complex if you want to purchase food or drink after your visit.

History of Tokyo, illustrated. Your first treat is the architecture of the Edo-Tokyo museum - a huge bubble era building opened in 1993.The collection is amazing. Everything works together to reveal the story of Tokyo and of Japan. The models of Nihonbashi are real highlights -- whether it is the full scale one you walk across, or the tiny model with the human figurines to offer a glimpse of the Edo era city. In fact the miniature models of various cityscapes and buildings are fantastic.There is enough English to get a sense of what is being shown - though some of the more detailed panels are Japanese only.Dedicate three hours and learn all you can about the history of Tokyo.

Definitely worth a visit. We came here as we'd read good reviews and are avid museum goers and we were extremely happy to find out it was free to enter (3/01) It isn't usually and so it was a bonus. We thoroughly enjoyed our two and a half hour visit and found it sufficient. There are some extremely interesting Japanese artifacts and it's well laid out. It's definitely worth a visit.

Interesting historical museum but not special. I made a quick visit to the museum on my last day. I was able to walk through in about 20-30 minutes and while it was interesting I don't think I needed more time there. If you have to pick I say visit the National museum instead.

I learned a bit. I learned a bit about the history of Tokyo. I was not solo, so I stayed longer than I would have liked. For beginner Japan students like myself I think 1 to 1.5 hours is more than enough. For those with a deeper understanding of Japanese history and culture, they may get more out of this museum. I really loved the exhibition explaining the process of block printing.

A Great Look into the Past of Tokyo. We had a visit to the Edo Tokyo Museum on our list as a must see - reviews had shown it was a great insight into Tokyo of the past - but unfortunately it was closed when we went apparently due to a holiday? I still don't understand why the premiere museum in Tokyo would be closed in the prime tourist season - strange but unfortunately true. What could be seen from outside indicated a vast collection that no doubt would have enhanced our visit to Tokyo. Very easy to get to as a train station is located almost next door. This museum is also situated right next door to the Sumo Museum so it could very easily be combined in a visit at the same time.I will definitely make the effort to get inside on my next trip.

Great museum to learn about Tokyo's past. An excellent museum and is worth the visit. Prepare at least half day because of the extensive information and artefacts explaining the city's history. There are lots of school children so expect it to be a bit noisy and crowded.

Educational. This was the biggest museum I've gone to. There were so many life size replicas that I appreciated. I enjoyed learning about the Edo era and have more knowledge of the Japanese culture. I would definitely recommend this museum to everyone visiting Japan.

Good Overview of Tokyo History. The Sumo Museum thats nearby was closed so we went here instead. Its a good Museum with a few interactive bits. The kids were a bit bored but we found a great little pack across the road where they had fun feeding the Koi and Turtles

Love love love. I first came here with my 7month old daughter, then dragged my husband there. 13 years later, I still felt the magic of the displays. The entry to the exhibits took my breath away and while there are now more displays and eras on show, the history of Edo (old name for Tokyo) is still the highlight. We spent a happy morning here.

Bigger than expected, allow full half day and eat well before. Large and comprehensive museum describing the history of Tokyo from the Edo period to today. Highlighted the progressive nature and resilience of the Japanese people in the face of repeated decimation by natural disasters and wars. Make sure to allow lots of time and eat/drink well before as they don't allow eating in the building and there is a lot to take in.

Great History. I think everyone should start their vacation to Tokyo with an open mind and a stop here at the Edo Tokyo Museum. Our volunteers knowledge was very intriguing and detailed. You realized how every bit of info ties into modern day Tokyo. His name skips my mind but I do remember him mentioning he was born in the 20's and went through World War 2. So he himself was a walk history book. Starting at the bridge and ending at the layers of dirt/earth over Edo-Tokyo's history along with the multiple replicas was astonishing. Would go again because of the amount of information I'm sure I missed..

Educational and enlightening. I love to see museums and experience culture when I visit another country and this museum was amazing. I would definitely recommend it to any tourist but be prepared for a LOT of school children running around everywhere. They weren't an issue though as they were extremely polite. I was actually amazed at what was on show in the museum, including the surrender document signed at the end of WWII

Rainy day activity. Cool museum. There's a lot to see and learn about the history of Tokyo. It's also a good rainy day activity. We were here for half a day and we saw everything but you could easily spend the whole day here as well.

thoroughly enjoyable. we liked the way this museum was laid out, considering a relativley small footprint (dont expect the Louvre or Nat History London) the museum managed to pack in quite a lot of items and especially the tiny but very detailed models of old Tokyo which very accurately depicts life in the early days of Tokyo that we really enjoyed. the english descriptions are adequate and layout was well thought out going through a one way route. there is a nice japanese restaurant on the 7th floor which serves a pork free menu which was a nice welcome. well worth checking out.
Amazing place. A great place to learn a lot about the history and life of early Japan. allow plenty of time. Guides are available for many languages and ours was extremely knowledgeable.

Great museum with live performances!. The museum was really interesting in showing Japanese life from the Edo period to now. There were lots of displays that you could sit on, such as rickshaws and palanquins. Then to top it off, at the replicated theatre there was a Japanese dancing and singing performance! Fantastic! We also had a lovely lunch at the restaurant on the 7th floor with a view over the Sumo stadium.

EXCELLENT HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE. This museum and the surrounding area is well worth a visit for those wishing to get an overview of Tokyo history in an encapsulated location. the building itself is impressive but the real attraction is the attention to detail in the various models which represent different stages of Tokyo's history. This museum appeals to young and old and has headphone sets with accompanying verbal information. The sumo arena is right next door and, while we did not go, is allegedly very interesting. It's on the list.

Great history leason. Easily accessed museum with great range of exhibits. The museum is stroller/wheelchair friendly (though we did have to ask to use the service lift as main one was out of order) and would be great for older children with lots of interactive exhibits. There was a small contained area where small children could crawl around but not much else targeted at the age. The life size exhibits of everyday life through the ages and dioramas of original city layouts were very interesting. The volunteer guide service is recommended - avoid lunch break which seems to be 12-1pm.

Genuinely fun museum. The Edo-Tokyo museum is easily accessed from the Ryogoku station of the Oedo line- it's 50m away from the subway exit and very well signposted. It is a genuinely fun museum with hands-on exhibits, beautifully detailed dioramas and full-sized recreations of a Kabuki theatre and newspaper office. We were brought around by Keiko, a volunteer guide who was friendly and enthusiastic. We spent an enjoyable two hours there and ended with a tasty and reasonably-priced lunch at the Sakura-Saryo restaurant on the 7th floor.

Fantastic models and volunteer guides. An excellent museum built to look like one of the temple gates you find all over Japan. The museum is split over two floors with areas dedicated to different periods of history.Many of the exhibits use dioramas to show how life would have been for different types of people during these different periods. The illustrations and accompanying information are interesting and informative.English translations are everywhere.Well worth the visit. Try some soba on the 7th floor for lunch after you've looked around. A fantastic traditional Japanese meal.

Must do in Tokyo . The Edo Tokyo museum is a must do before you head up to discover the city it makes more sense to know the history and culture of Japan the volunteers guides are doing an excellent job wish the will be in every museum through every aspect of Japanese history is put in a very creative way making easy and enjoyable for the tourist to know Japan culture

Great displays and picture opportunities!. There are two kinds of exhibits: the permanent exhibit and the special exhibit. I think it costs about $1,500 yen if you want to see both. The permanent exhibit is pretty large and interesting, though, and if you like to read everything and take pictures like I do, you will need at least three hours for that part alone. My brother skipped through a lot of the reading and only took a couple of pictures, and finished in about 90 minutes. You will probably need 5 hours to do both exhibits--or go on two separate days. I didn't have the chance to do it, but the Ukiyoe exhibit looked like it would have been really nice to see! Anyway, the permanent exhibit is cool because they have scaled models of what different parts of Tokyo looked like during different time periods, as well as lots of art, and full sized models of houses and everyday items that people used from 1600s right up through the 1950s. You can even take pictures of yourself inside of a palanquin, a rickshaw, and a giant 1920s (?) bicycle, or carrying fish baskets on a pole over your shoulders. My brother typically hates to go to museums with me, but he enjoyed this one!
Enjoyed the models and displays. Well worth a visit and could walk there from Hotel Tobu Levant. Would need at least a couple of hours to have a close look at all the exhibits.

Edo-Tokyo Museum Great volunteer guides. The Edo Tokyo museum has a fabulous program offerings free guided tours in several languages. At 2 o'clock one afternoon When we went to the tour desk to ask about a 3 o'clock tour ,Yuko , who was Staffing the volunteer desk told us that she would take us right away for an hour and a half. In very easy to understand English Yuko gave us the history of the Edo period and told us many things about Japan. The 1 and 1/2 hour we spent with Yuko was the equivalent of a semester course in Edo Tokyo history! She was so knowledgeable and gracious.  If you go to the Edo Tokyo museum (which I recommend ) go to the volunteer desk. And if Yuko is there, take her tour because you will have a fabulous hour and a half experience.

Good to visit for history buffs. Lots of displays about Tokyo's history from the Edo period to the present. The museum would be of most interest to adults and older children (10 years and older). Younger kids may not find it as interesting as there are not many interactive exhibits. English language guides are supposed to be available, although there were none when we visited.

Old Buildings and The GrandTea Ceremony. This is a great area to stroll around for an afternoon. A little tricky to get to with public transportation. Take the JR train to Musashi-Koganei and then a bus. It lets you off right at the park. It is a large park, be prepared to walk. This is an open air museum. We took a packed lunch/Bento box with us. For the Tea Ceremony we paid 300 yen each and booked for a 12.45pm time slot. We are not able to kneel for a long time so they kindly gave us a small stool to sit on and provided and interpreter for the ceremony. There were lots of ladies wearing kimonos for this event. The buildings on the site have been brought here from different parts of Japan and are very interesting to stroll through. A souvenir shop is in the museum and also a few places are available for beverages and eating.
Ancient Edo. Super place. Lots to see and charming folk to show you around. Real sense of peace. Tea ceremony is hard to take seriously

EDO museum in Tokyo Japan. Museum has exhibits about life during the Edo period, both the town people, and the Shogun 'upper class'. There are life size and model size replicas of towns, a typical residence and Shogun estate, Kabuki theater. To get the most interesting information, sign up for a volunteer led tour. On the day we went, there was a live concert of three sting instruments, very lively.The special exhibit, for which there was a significant extra fee, was of photographs. These photos were poorly labeled, just names with no explanation as to who the person epwas or why the photo was important. For this reason, I suggest the special exhibit be skipped.You get a discount on the 'permanent exhibit' only - with the Tokyo tourist booklet.Lunch on the 7th floor Japanese cafe included a lovely view. udon noodle soup with tempura cost 1700 JYen.

Teenagers will love it! Take Guided Tour. The museum covers history of Edo-Tokyo but also several aspects of Japanese history and culture. It is definitely worth the visit. I strongly suggest to ask for a guided tour. Kids will enjoy the interactive displays. The tours are ministered by volunteers and are free of charge. They have it in several languages. It makes all the difference, specially if you have the kids with you. Best museum so far.
Great fun!. You can find the volunteer guide in many different language.It is so exciting to know about history of Tokyo.

Great museum to visit!. This is a beautiful museum that tells the story of the Edo period. Where so much of Tokyo is modern, this museum brings visitors back to the past to get a glimpse of Edo. The exhibits are carefully curated and informative. A must-go for visitors who want to learn more about Edo history.

Very well done exhibition!. Excellent reconstructions of buildings and people's lives in the Edo period. Also features a modern Tokyo exhibition. Although I didn't try any, free voluntary guides speaking several languages are available. The only downside is that the Japanese descriptions sometimes are more detailed than the Korean, Chinese and English.

A must see for history enthusiasts! . Edo Tokyo Museum is a great place to visit if you are very interested in the history of Tokyo or Edo. The life size scale of the exhibit is also a way of seeing how the Japanese lived during the 1920's and so on. Entrance fee is not expensive and worth the price of admission (less than 1,000 Yen). There were tour groups when we went but it was still not crowded.You can also have the option of getting an English volunteer guide or just getting an audio guide which is available in various languages. Although, I found the speaker in the audio guide too slow when speaking. Also most of the information mentioned in the audio guide was also written in English write ups in front of the display.A must see place if you are very interested in Japanese history and way of life. An exhibit done with utmost excellence.

Very well done history museum. This museum has many English explanations. Though we were with a guide, it would be fine to visit without one.
There were some life size structures, and also many models, dioramas of Tokyo life through the centuries. Here were also artifacts. THe museum helped me to visualize the way Japanese communities looked.

Fantastic down to the smallest detail. This permanent exhibition in this museum is probably one of the best that I've ever been. From the minute you enter you are greeted with with replica of a section of the oringial Nihonbashi bridge, as well as the façades of Edo and pre-1945 Tokyo era buildings. The best bit for me are the life sized replica houses for the Edo period, as well as miniature models of Edo and Tokyo that come to life every 15 minutes or so (with a guide who'd give an introduction of the models in Japanese). The detail they put into creating these models simply amazing. Not too many English explanations for the exhibits but I think it's enough to get by if you can rent an audio-guide. You can easily spend hours here soaking in the history of this great metropolis, and all for a good price of 600 Yen (adults).

A trip down memory lane. This is a must do on your first visit to Tokyo. It gives a tremendous insight in to the Japanese people and their interesting and complex history and culture. I strongly recommend you avail yourself of one of free English speaking volunteers to take around the museum.
Impressive knowledge of Edo-Tokyo history. A very interesting place to learn how was the life of the past years in Tokyo. One of the best museum i've ever visited in my life.

A trip down Tokyo's memory lane. We chose this attraction because it was a rainy day and we needed an indoor activity. The museum was interesting and informative, giving us a glimpse of Tokyo's past.We especially liked the small scale exhibits, very detailed work done on it. A nice bonus after we exited the museum was seeing up close several sumo wrestlers coming out of the tournament hall next to the museum.

Fantastic history of Tokyo from Edo to modern age. Went with my sons aged 11 & 12, they loved the hands on exhibits.It is easy to get to and is just round the corner from the ryokugan station, just set behind the sumo stadium.iThe exhibits are amazing, the nihon bashi bridge that you walk across, The models that you look through binoculars, bring them to life, fabulous attention to detail.The history is amazing starting from when Edo became the capital, right through to world war 2. They have reconstructed houses so that you get a glimpse of how people lived during those times. I was amazed to see Victorian costumes.Unfortunately, we were too early for a tour, but a guide was very keen to talk to us when he knew we were English.I love Japanese history and this is a fantastic museum.Would highly recommend.it also has a gift shop which was reasonably priced.
History of Edo-Tokyo. Interesting to learn how the Edo period was, and how it evolved over the years to become Tokyo. They also have beautiful models of how Edo looked like in the past.

Excellent guided tour. We were very impressed with the wealth of knowledge displayed by our English-speaking guide, offered (free-of-charge) by the Edo Tokyo Museum. He made Edo history come alive, and interacted well with us. We left the museum with a better understanding of Japan, her people and the culture.

History of Tokyo in a Nutshell. I took my two adult sons to this museum and I was totally blown away by the size of the exhibits. The museum is in a huge building and the museum has distinct sections like earthquakes, transportation. living style, design, etc.We rode the Oedo Line to Ryogoku Station and the museum is just around the corner from the station. Entrance fee is only 600y, but I was 300y since I am over 65. What a bargain. We spent about 2 hours looking at the exhibits and probably would have spent more time there is my sons wanted to go to Akihabara. The exhibits are great, but one has to know a little more about Japanese History in order to link things and times together.
Back to the Edo era. This building itself is an attractive structure and this is one of the great museum to visit in Tokyo.

The most interesting museum I saw in Tokyo. The entrance was nothing much but the exhibits were fascinating. You can even try to experience what it was like, for example, riding on a rickshaw or palanquin. A pity I couldn't wait around to see the special effects for some exhibits which were programmed to show every 15 mins.I also enjoyed a Japanese udon lunch at the museum's coffee shop. They had English menus so it was not difficult to order.

guide or no guide. You can go 1st floor and buy ticket from the window and use elevator to 6th floor museum. Or you can go to ticket vending machine in exterior and use escalator directly to the museum on 7th floor. We asked free guide in English and our team was 8. He guided us for 2hours, but he explained histories and stories according to his filed book. There are so many precious things must see, but he passed without telling about them. There are pros and cons. I suggest not guided.

Well designed museum.. Well laid out museum in design specific building. Good English explanations around many of the exhibits. Can be completed comfortably in 90-120 minutes. Everything from models of Edo in 1700 to examples of how locals lived in the 1950's.

Excellent . This museum is well worth a visit. It has models of what Edo was and how it came about. It was good to see how Tokyo developed through the times. I learnt a few things!Some exhibits are hands on. Great for the kids.I especially enjoyed the display around 1920's Tokyo. Definitely go if museums are your thing or if your after something different from the standard museum experience.

Such history. The exhibits are amazing. There is some sort of celebration when we went and there was 2 ladies who played the Japanese Violin. Fascinating. The Nihonbashi bridge looked awesome. You can also go on a guided tour for free and English is available.

Excellent!. If you have time only for one muzeum during your stay in Tokyo you definitely choose this one. For exploring whole exhibition you shoul book approx 1,5 h. Also there is nice park nearby, good place for relax.

Excellent detailed museum about the history of Tokyo (Edo). This museum has great historical information in multiple languages (Japanese, English, Korean, Chinese, Spanish, and one other I have forgotten). Unfortunately not all the information is translated from the Japanese, but the displays are very visual so you can usually get a good sense from the diagrams.There are also many dioramas and lots of hands-on displays or things you can get close up to.

Learn a lot of Edo(Samurai) Period to Tokyo historical events and culture!. This is the first time for me to visit here even living in Tokyo, but it is so fantastic to learn how Edo Period looks like and Tokyo has been established. There are both Permanent Exhibition and Special Exhibition area. For foreign visitors volunteer guides are available as for the permanent exhibition area. Permanent exhibition: Edo Castle, Life and town peoples, Four seasons entertainment, how villages and island linked with Edo(merchants and stations) , aesthetics of Edo (Kabuki), Kabuki Theaters and pleasure of Edo period. Tokyo: how Tokyo urban culture established. When I visited, special exhibition: "Ukiyo-e to photography" Cultural Awakening in Japan's Visual Field; Ukiyo-e, which features famous places of Edo, which continued to increase as the city developed, and the popular beauties and celebrities of the time, who were singled out from the crowds that populated genre paintings to be depicted independently. Picture and Photograph, Nishiki-e, Mud pictures, Glass pictures and oil pictures has been developed after Meiji Period civilization. It is wonderful to learn about our own culture.

Very interesting history of Edo (now Tōkyō). Just behind the Sumo Stadium and with easy transport connections the Edo Museum is a great place to get a handle on the history of Tōkyō when it was known as Edo. There are some great reconstructions and miniature replicas of some of the older buildings in Edo which no longer exist, Edo Castle, a Samurai Lord's Edo residence, the old Nakamuraza Kabuki Theatre to name a few. The exhibits cover Edo generally whilst there are usually special exhibitions on which give a glimpse into some of the more niche elements of Edo era life - an exhibition of Tokugawa castles was on this September. Admission to both the general exhibition area and the special exhibitions can be bought on a dual admission ticket. There are tours run by English speaking volunteers (as well as tours run in other languages). There are also a few cafes and restaurants for a convenient meal. The museum shop sells some very nice souvenirs.

Excellent social history museum. We wanted a museum that would show us how Tokyo developed and how the people used to live and the Edo -Tokyo museum was recommended. We loved it and learned so much about the Edo period and also how modern Tokyo evolved. A very good visit.

Favorite museum in Tokyo. This museum is great to learn about Edo and Modern Tokyo. You can get a free tour guide who explains everything with so much detail I definitely recommend using the service. I learned so much more than just walking around. The small models they use are so well created and just incredible. I absolutely recommend going to this museum!
Good place. We love this place,this museum is an interesting place to spend a few hours learning about japannese culture

An overview of the history of Tokyo. This museum contains models and objects telling the story of Tokyo and informing visitors about how people were living over here over the centuries. It is also a good place to learn about the history of Japan.

Edit Tokyo Museum. Well designed museum allowing for a walk through the history of the region from the Edo period. The volunteer English speaking guide was indispensable for the family to get a better understanding of the changes in Tokyo over era. Recommend highly.

Great insight to Tokyo history. We were spoilt to be with a an elderly guide who lead us through a great insight to Edo, Tokyo history, the displays were well set out for english speaking tourists and the figurettes on some of the models were amazing. This really gave a good background of Tokyo history right through to the recent past including WW2 and further on. An enjoyable way to learn about Japanese culture and history.
polite staff, life size and miniature exhibits. easy to find, half price for over 65s. has simple english translation, colourful and spacious stroll, not for the serious museophiles

Very educational!. Loved this beautifully and thoughtfully constructed museum. We booked a free volunteer guide weeks before (info about that is in their website but I called directly to the museum) and I highly recommend this. We got a super nice Japanese lady that told us things and details we would have never found out about otherwise. We had a 2 hour tour although you can also choose the 1.5 hr one. In order to understand many things about contemporary Japan you have to start with history and this is just the place to do that

Great snaphot of Tokyo / Japan history, very well presented.. This was mainly set over two large floors. There is an option of an English speaking volunteer guide, but I personally found that it was enough to rely on the English explanations by most exhibits. The re-created houses / buildings / street scenes were great and the whole museum was interesting, informative and highly recommended for a visit. I wasn't fully aware of the absolute devastation caused to Tokyo in WWII until I saw some of the exhibits, quite shocking !! The EDO period exhibits were also very interesting and well laid out and interactive in places. An entertaining and interesting couple of hours.

Visit of Edo Museum. The main Features of the permanent exhibitons are the life-size replica of the Nihonbashi, which was the bridge leading into Edo as well as scale models of towns and buildings from the Edo and Shôwa periods. I liked Edo Museum, it give different, varied impressions of Edo's periods, historical based. It's not a MOMA or sth. like that, if you like to see modern exhibitions or paintings, it would be, of course, the wrong museum.

Brilliant!. I think this is the most interesting museum I have ever been to- avail of the free guide... Our one was excellent. it covers such a long period of time with enough detail without boring you. The models, pictures and dioramas were fascinating- loved the houses to scaleA definite on a wet day and personally I'd make it a definite anyways!

Great museum. We had gotten up early to buy day-of tickets for the sumo tournament but had time to kill before the real action so went next door to the museum. We were told there was a free guide and we got a lovely woman to be our own personal guide. Not only did she spend 1 1/2 hours with us, I got a chance to ask more general questions about Japan. We ate lunch there so spent about 4 hours but could've spent motor time.

Fantastic! Highly recommend!. I hadn't planned to visit the Edo Tokyo Museum, but we had several days of pouring rain during our stay in Tokyo, so I was looking for something to do indoors. This museum is so awesome, you must go! Lots of displays and hands on features bring you back in time to old Edo. Many life-sized buildings to explore alongside miniature models. The exhibits progress in time bringing you to modern Tokyo. Great information on WW2 and the bombings and rebuilding of the city.The gift shop is A+ as well. We spent about 2 hours here.

Unusual feel to this place. Massive building near to Ryogoku subway and also the JR station.There is a mezzanine 2 floor set up on the 5th and 6 th floor and most of it comprises beautiful little models of old Edo and newer Tokyo. The exhibitions are well labelled in English and there are a few "hands on" type things but really all wasn't too interesting overall. I was interested in a small section towards the bar which highlights the end of WW2 and all the allied firebombing of Tokyo . Seemed to me that although it would have been over a few months of bombing, there was probably more loss of life than the A bombing of Hiroshima!Also some 60's electronic appliances and even an Atari console interested me as well as info on the '64 Olympics. A lot of effort has been put into the museum and the facility including the lockers are superb but something didn't quite make it a "must see" for me. The 3rd floor has a great terrace but surprisingly no food or drink places there!

My second on the "favourite" list in Japan!. Been a couple of times and the entire family love the exhibitions. Some hands on items, lots to view and learn or just hang out and listen to an edo period recital that sometimes comes up. The English translations are somewhat "huh, what is it trying to say?" but can still get the gist from all the visuals. Adding to the experience is the getting there. Can get a peek at the Sumo Stadium on the way from the station. After the museum we took a stroll down the nearby streets where there are some Sumo style meals on offer and interesting sumo statues. Also, try catching one of the River Cruise boats as an alternative to get back to your hotel. All the above makes a full but fun-packed entire day. Start early!
A "first-timer" must see in Tokyo.. Really wonderful museum, especially if it's your first time to Tokyo.The miniatures of life in the Edo period are astounding. Spent an entire afternoon here.

Excellent museum of Tokyo history. Museum contains a lot of exhibits regarding middle-age and modern history of Tokyo. It looks like some part of city where reconstructed to feel the epoch by visitors. Very interesting.

Good for the whole family. The museum's focus is more on giving people a feel for what living was like in Edo (Tokyo) from ancient times until the 20th century. That's why they have several replicas of old buildings and several displays that can be touched. The museum has some artifacts (paintings, ceramics, sculptures, clothes, armors, swords etc.) on display, but they do not come close to what the Tokyo National Museum offers.Long story short: This museum gives a good feel for what life was in historic Tokyo. It is more of a family oriented museum and many displays can be touched. It complements well with the Tokyo National Museum. I would give it 1-2 hours.

Amazing Museum of the Edo Period. The architecture of the museum is unusual, it is like a spaceship on stilts. We saw the special exhibit, which was mainly maps of the Edo period. I would skip it. The permanent exhibit is reached by going to the 6th floor. Once you get off the 6th floor, you understand why the tour starts on the 6th floor. You cross a wooden bridge as you would in the Edo period. The bridge and the 6th floor overlook reproductions of a building from the Edo period on one side, and a more recent building on the other. The entry to the permanent exhibit is very unique. On this floor are elaborate scale models of villages from the Edo period. It was very unique. Downstairs you can get close up to the reproductions and there are other exhibits. There are plenty of seating throughout and the bathrooms are good. It was easy to get to.

Shogun history. I have visited this museum 2 times and I always enjoy every minutes of it.You will find the story of Tokyo history here and details of Shogun family back then in Japan.Many people are interested in Shogun and this Museum will satisfied your curiosity.

Wonderful visit!. It was a great choice to start a visit of Tokyo with this wonderful museum. The museum was very interactive, where you could touch things and participate. It is a great choice if you are traveling with kids! We spent there 2 hours.

Impressive, interesting, informative and fun. Life size exhibits chart the history of Edo up to the present day. Explanations are clear and informative. Some of the models are fabulous. We spent a lot of time on the older stuff and had to rush through the modern exhibits, which was a pity because for westerners Japan is still an unfamiliar culture. We went at the end of our 3 week stay in Japan, which was good as it drew together everything we had experienced. Lots of hands-on exhibits for the young (and young at heart) and plenty of space so everyone can see everything. The Italian restaurant is good, and you do need sustenance!

A great interactive museum with lots to learn that you may not know. A wonderful museum which is above the others for its setting and interactivity. Really enjoyed this and one of the better gift stores in a museum. Lots to take pictures with and lots of interesting information about things such as the occupation of japan by the allied forces after the second world war.

Great mix of ancient and modern history . Definitely worth a visit to when in Tokyo. Provides a great history of Tokyo from its roots as Edo. I suggest booking a tour guide (free) prior to arriving. I failed to and they were too busy to fit me in. The audio guide (free) was good though, but given the great displays it wasn't essential.The special exhibition looked interesting but the staff member selling tickets was good enough to tell me it was all in Japanese so I didn't waste my money buying that ticket!

Excellent free tour guide. This is a very nice museum that I have enjoyed a few years ago. This time I chose to have some advice from a free volunteer guide. Our friendly guide was wonderfully knowledgable about Tokyo, and able to unpack for us many things not immediately clear to casual observers such as us. He was also aware of time, so did not result in us spending much more time in the museum than planned. A retired gentleman, he spoke excellent English. A terrific service in a very good museum, and thoroughly recommended.

Well thought out floor plan!. Come here if you want to experience Japanese history and cultural evolution since the Edo period. The well thought out floor plan brought us from one section to another section so the experience flowed seamlessly. Love the life-sized replica of houses which you can enter and touch the items in display!

Well organized and good information . A very well organized and clean place to spend a couple of hours. Nice information about Tokyo and a good gift shop. Very informative with a particularly strong collection of 20th century Tokyo city life images and objects.Be careful about using elevators and escalators--the elevators are pretty slow and some escalators go down but not up. You can therefore get stuck looping through corridors and exits (se of which have one-way turnstiles) searching for the proper way to get to your desired level. The restaurant on the top floor was especially irritating to get to. Once there, the views were nice but the food a little underwhelming for the cost.Other than that a nice calm museum.

A treasure trove. This museum is a must see for anyone who wants to learn about the culture and history of Tokyo and Japan. It's huge and there are so many fascinating and interactive exhibits, one hour will only scratch the surface. Pictures are allowed in designated areas and of course you can purchase souvenirs before you leave. The facility can be accessed through the metro stations as well. Tickets are fairly priced.
Calm and nice museum. Edo museum was a very nice surprise! Our teenager boys loved it, so did we. Explains the old Tokyo and the life before.

For Learning Edo and Tokyo. 江戸東京博物館This is a wonderful metropolitan museum in Tokyo’s Ryogoku district. The area is best known for the sumo arena (Ryogoku Kokugi-kan) and the museum is located right next to the sumo arena. It’s best for you to get to Ryogoku by using Japan Railways (JR) Sobu-sen Line (a light yellow one).Once you get off the train at JR Ryogoku Station, you walk out to the sumo arena side (easy to spot as the building is so prominent). Then walk past the sumo arena to the east for a few extra minutes. The entrance to the Edo Tokyo Museum leads you to the upstairs where the main floors are located.The museum is quite comprehensive when it comes to historical Edo and Tokyo-related exhibits. It shows from the Tokugawa Shogunate (17th-19th centuries) days when Tokyo was called Edo to today’s Tokyo. With lots of most well-known early modern features very popular in Edo such as the ukiyo-e (wood-block printmaking), the kabuki theatre, mercantile and industrial activities together with town people’s life displays, this is a must museum for everyone visiting Tokyo.

Excellent, informative, fun. The museum is very spacious, and allows for a nice stroll.Got a free guide, the excellent Mr Yasuda, who was very helpful throughout.The model recreations of Edo castle were beautiful, but the real size recreations of the houses was excellent!Highly recommended.
Edo-Tokyo. It's good, seemed a little small inside compared to the big building it occupies. The small dioramas were my personal favorite part showcasing life in different eras

history of tokyo. If you like history and museum, this is a good visit. however if you are not that into museums this is not a place you should spend your time. the bulding itself is impressive and it shows the history of tokyo. takes about 1-2 hours. has free guided tours.

Wonderful cultural experience. A great afternoon visit to this museum to learn about the history and culture of Edo Tokyo. Some great exhibits (we especially liked the scale models) and an amazing building to walk through and at 600 yen per adult it is very good value. Tip: Present the tokyo tourist/visitor map and you will get discounted entry.

Learn How Tokyo Came To Being. This museum tells the history of Tokyo in considerable detail. It showcases how people lived, socialised, worked, how the city was constructed, the types of clothes worn, etc. It is a wonderful attraction deserving time to view and understand the various artefacts. Well worth a visit.

Phenomenal amount of detail on the history of Edo-Tokyo and the lives of its residents. The Edo-Tokyo Museum is an interesting looking building all by itself. The contents of the museum is just on the city of Edo-Tokyo but it has great detail with good English explanations, graphs, charts, dioramas, and reconstructions of the way parts of the city looked and how the people lived over the centuries. And in August, it is important to note, that it is air conditioned.

History of Tokyo . Many might think that this museum about Japan but it's not .. It's only about Tokyo! It will give you some information about the city and the edo family and some images of the American attacks to Tokyo during the world war 2.

Great Museum. On a hot Tokyo summer day, this is a great attraction to visit. For English speaking people, I recommend getting the portable English guide. It is ¥1,000 deposit which you get back when you return the device. The tour starts on the 6th floor and the permanent exhibit extends down to the 5th floor as well. You get a wonderful tour of all aspects of life from ancient (Edo period) to modern (Tokyo period). I found the ancient Edo exhibits the most interesting as well as the WW II information quite a different perspective.

A great way to learn the history of Tokyo!. My husband and I love visiting museums when traveling, and this one does not disappoint!The Edo-Tokyo Museum is great to pair up with a trip to the Senso-Ji temple for a day trip. My husband and I also fit in a trip to the Sky Tree on this same day as it's all in the same general area of the city. The Edo-Tokyo Museum is a hands on history of Tokyo from the Edo period to the present day. All of the information in the museum is in Japanese and English, making it possible for my husband and me to actually learn while exploring this museum. Pictures are allowed, which is quite uncommon for Tokyo, and really adds to the enjoyment. As a history teacher, my husband appreciated being able to read about World World II from the perspective of the Japanese and gleaned a lot of knowledge he will be taking back with him to his history class. I enjoyed learning about how the history of Tokyo shaped many practices see in present day Tokyo, such as wrapping books. It's always fun to see where cultural practices come from and to begin to understand the meaning behind them. If you're a lover of history, museums, or being able to learn hands on, this is a great place to visit while in Tokyo.Practical Info: There are many bathrooms throughout and even free English tours given at certain times.
Terrific way to begin visit. We began our visit to Japan with a visit to this museum which presented the history of Tokyo during the Edo period via magnificent replicas. Highly recommended.

Learn when Edo became Tokyo and lots more.... This is a wonderful modern spacious Museum. Inside you cross a replica of the Sumida bridge to get to see large scale models of the Imperial palace in the 1600's and as you follow the tour around past large replicas of a Kabuki Theatre and other buildings, past the swords and clothing from the 1600's to the air raid shelters of WW2......Its a facinating glimpse into Japanese History and a good place to start if you want to understand more about Japan.They have English speaking volunteer guides which i followed and can recommend this.

Good Museum. The museum is amazing overall, they offer free tour guide in different languages and it takes you trough the Edo Period of Japan. The Meiji period you have to do it by yourself but it is not long. We were surprised by hearing that a lot of the museum belongings are replicas and not the originals. And Overall the museum is interesting and nice, worth visiting if you are interested in the history of the Edo period and the development of Tokyo mostly.

Very Interesting and Informative. With a wonderful English speaking guide to take us through this museum, we gained a great insight into the cultural history of Tokyo. The displays are clearly set out and explanations are provided throughout. I would highly recommend this as a good starting point for your tour of Tokyo.

Must See on a Tokyo List. This museum gives a beautiful look at the transition from the shoguns of the Edo period to the current Tokyo. We were traveling with our young kids and the detailed dioramas and hands-on exhibits were a great way to spend our first morning in Tokyo. Plan to spend about two hours here. Make sure to use the coin lockers for any heavy bags you're carrying around - all you need is your feet and a good camera:)

Very Interesting. You'll certainly learn a lot about the history of Edo (Tokyo) with a visit to this museum. It was great to go here early in my trip to Tokyo, as it added a lot of background flavor for visits to other sites and made those experiences even more rewarding.
Museum. Very interesting museum about how has the japanese society been changing since the Edo period till now. Is probably the one I enjoyed the most in the city.

Excellent museum!. I am not a huge fan of museums, as so many seem to be rather dry and stuffy. However, the Edo-Tokyo Museum is well laid-out and interesting, featuring many hands-on and large-scale models and other 3D exhibits. The museum provides an excellent insight into the Edo period and the development of Japan itself, and its Westernisation. It is well worth visiting before you embark on a wider tour of the country. The museum includes various facilities, including lockers and a very popular restaurant that serves modern takes on Edo-period recipes. This is located on the 7th floor, from where there are good views over the city. No English was spoken in the restaurant, although it is easy to get by as there is a menu in English with pictures illustrating the various dishes available. I was at the museum for just over one-and-a-half hours, but could easily have stayed longer had my limited time in Tokyo permitted.
Wonderful. Fantastic museum that gives the history of Tokyo and Japan. Easy to get to and inexpensive. Allow several hours.

Closed on day after national holiday. No idea whether it is a good museum or not as it was closed when we went to visit. Very disappointing! Trip to Sumida was a waste of time except that we did get to see the Sumo museum. Such a key museum should be open every day of the year. There is some information that it is closed on Mondays but it is very obscure to be closed on the day after a public holiday.

Top notch reproductions, and tolerant of small children. A highlight among Tokyo museums. Get the free audio guide. Various things for children (anyone really) to interact with. Could have more English interpretive signage though,as many explanations of Edo period economics etc are only in Japanese
Amazing. This place will tell you roughly 70%-80% about Japan, very useful. One of interesting places you must visit. Location is easy as there is metro and JR station nearby.

Unique and Marvelous Museum. A Great Museum. Definitely worth a visit. It relays the history of Tokyo in a very engaging manner. Cross over the replica "Edo" bridge into a network of models, dioramas, and rooms. Sixth and fifth floors are well worth a visit. Good history overview in a fun, relaxed atmosphere.

I Thought I Was In The Edo Period. I'm not a history buff, I really enjoyed this museum. You enter the museum by crossing over a replica of the Nihonbashi Bridge, which was quite amazing. There are many "hands-on exhibits, life-size figures, models of historic towns, audio presentations and demonstrations of traditional crafts." (visitacity.com) I highly recommend fitting this museum in your schedule.

Well structured. Well laid out and easy to navigate, with interesting insights into Japanese history and culture. The museum is a little too large, however, and architecturally feels more like a warehouse than a museum.
Reasonably priced, however, and students can show their university cards for a discount.

Good history lesson. This is a museum about the history of Japan during the Edo period and how Japan has evolved in terms of lifestyle, appliances, arts, entertainment, clothing, transportation etc. Really amazing miniature structures and also recreations of 1950s housing that you can walk through. Definitely worth seeing if you like history. It has English translations.

Take your time - there's a lot to see.. Take your time - there's a lot to see. The permanent collection covers the history of the city of Tokyo before it was called that. You can follow the details of life in almost every aspect, including what the money was like and how water was supplied to the city. Then they go into the history of Tokyo as Tokyo. There are special exhibitions too, but I found that 3-4 hours for just the permanent collection. This is also a great choice for a rainy day, as it's easy to get to by the Oedo subway line to the Ryogoku stop and there is so much to see.The English language audio guide is free, although you have to leave a 1000 Yen deposit - you get it back when you return the guide. The only problem I had with it was the person reading the copy. She spoke so deliberately - I suppose in an attempt to be understood by those for whom English is the only language that they know in which they could get the guide - that she actually mis-pronounced words. It made the narration very stilted and a bit hard to listen to. Perhaps they should have two versions of the English guide. One for native speakers and one for non-native speakers.

Hands On Experience Not to be Missed. This is a museum that puts you back in time with hands-on exhibits that enable you to experience the touch and feel of old Edo-Tokyo not just read text at exhibit cases. You enter the museum by walking across a full scale wooden bridge, Nihonbashi Bridge, that takes you back in time. The museum gives one the opportunity to experience as much as possible the texture of old Nippon life. Great for children and adults. Try to schedule as much time as you can for this outstanding facility.

Other Museums Need to Take a Page from This One. This is best laid-out, well-designed museum I've ever been to. Highly educational, excellent use of models, and content completely translated into English. If you go to Tokyo, schedule at least half a day, if not more. Has three restaurants in the vicinity (the Italian one is lovely).
Edo museum. Very informative. Volunteer guides who speak English. Wonderful for kids-a number of hands on exhibits to touch and try.

Interactive and fun, with a good restaurant and gift shop. Ask at the front desk about the Special exhibitions - I was told there weren't English translations at the current exhibit so I just went into the main museum. I didn't engage one of the free guides but was able later on to ask a few specific questions that arose in my mind as I looked around the excellent exhibition. However, in the main, I found there was enough of an explanation in English for me to understand what was being shown. I really enjoyed the small scale street scenes - pick up the binoculars and marvel in the detail shown on the model's kimonos or faces. There's also life size models and interactive pieces that bring life in the Edo period to life. I would have liked to learn more about the 1923 earthquake and bombing from WW2 but there are other museums that cover these in more detail. A bento box lunch on L7 was excellent - they range from 1600-2400YenYou could time your trip here to coincide with a boat trip back down the river to somewhere like the Hamarikyu Gardens near the Fish Market but the boats don't run all that frequently so you'll need to plan ahead.
Want to learn about the Edo periode?. Then this is the place. It has some very interesting things that gives you alot if insight into how they lived in the Edo periode in Japan.

Start your Tokyo visit here - and get a guide. Tip number one: engage one of the Volonteer Guides when you enter.
