The hour-and-a-half we walked around with our english speaking gentleman gave us a really great insigt in the development of Tokyo during the Shogun period. the museum is modern with models and hands-on artefacts that tells you the story in a comprehendible way. So I would start my visit to Tokyo here to get more out of the other sights and attractions of the city. And we had lunch in the Japanese restaurant on 7th floor. A genuine experience and the tasty Bento Box set meal was good value at 1600 yen. (There are many other alternatives but all traditional japanese)

Worth taking the time to visit !. After several days of visiting Shrines and Temples in Tokyo we decided to visit the Tokyo Museum. It is located close to both the Sumo wresting arena and some very beautiful Shrines and gardens. The entrance fee is quite small (circa £2) and well worth the visit. it puts the history of Japan into perspective looking over the last 1000 years right up to and including WW11. You can easily spend 2 hours or more looking around the museum and puts many of the sights you will see into perspective. There are free guided tours, well worth taking, but these quickly fill up.

Good Museum. Really enjoyed the visit. This museum has a great gift shop in which I could have spent a small fortune. The restaurant is also worth having lunch in. Good food, excellent service (like most of Tokyo) and a great view down onto the Sumo arena next door.
Definitely worthwhile. After the longest escalator ride possible, descend through Tokyo history. Interactive, and informative for this visitor.
A must in Tokyo. Excellent overview on the history of EDO and Japanese Culture. Many of the "idividual streaks" of Japanese culture get understandable after visiting this museum
Good recreations of old Tokyo. interesting models (some life size) of Tokyo from about 1600-1900, but most labels were in Japanese. Nice gift shop.

Depicting life in this city. Museum in Tokyo depicting life in this city for the condition around 4 centuries ago to the forward estimates. Equipped with a variety of miniature that tells the conditions from time to time.

So much to see, well laid out. The main exhibit is really amazing, seeing the life-size building facades was so cool. And all of the interactive pieces were great too--like a display showing the way fish was carried that allows you to pick it up on your shoulders to see how heavy it was. We really could've spent a lot more time there but the kids were tired. The special exhibit was disappointing for us because it consisted mostly of written letters and poems that didn't have complete english translations, only short summaries. Perhaps the audio accompaniment would've made it better. So if you don't read Japanese maybe try to find out what's actually in the special exhibit before you purchase that option.

Great day to spend the day!. We wanted to go to a place to learn more about Japanese culture and history and our Japanese friend recommended Edo Tokyo Museum. It's a really big museum with lots of interactive exhibits where kids can try. The kids rode an old style bicycle, sat in a rickshaw, carried old containers with night soil, experienced how it's like to a fish seller in the past. They loved the kabuki exhibit show which showed how the ghost appeared and disappeared on stage. With slanted mirrors, we could see how it's like back stage. Great way to spend the day. My kids were complaining on the long train ride there but they had such a wonderful time that they didn't want to leave!

Miniture reproduction of Edo and some old artifacts new.. I was interesting to learn about the old edo and the more modern Tokyo with the different cars of earlier days. The bombing of Tokyo during the second world war. Is it a must see well depends on how many days you have in Japan. For us it was nice that the Kogikan the Sumo arena was right next door.

Very interesting and well done. We used the services of the free museum guide for the old part of the museum and did the modern part on our own. The museum is interesting for both children and adults. They also had a magic show for foreign visitors with a little geisha dance.

Well set out museum shows the Japanese history. A good starting point in your visit to Japan/Tokyo. The museum is huge and showcases the old Japanese way of life in great exhibitions. Not crowded so you can wander at leisure or do a quick tour to get a taste of Japan. Beautifully presented and the free guides are worth using.
Worth the visit. It was worth the visit. My friend and I took the whole day to really learn about things. It was really informative. Will go back again next time I am in Tokyo
well worth seeing. The history of Tokyo with fun exhibits for adults and kids. They have complementary interpreters but I suggest getting there before 1PM to catch these.

Great history museum of Edo period Tokyo. This museum shows the history and artifacts from the Edo period in Tokyo. Great historical learning experience. They have large replicas of the Edo Castle and other buildings. They show the Edo way of life and history of that period. They even have some fun interactive areas so fun along with the education. We saw hundreds of school children the day we visited so expect crowds. The cost is good too so ddo not miss this location.

one learns quite a lot and a good place for kids. First visit to the relatively new museum riht near the subway stop of Ryokogu. Lots to see, Mostly about history of Edo. Some wonderful artefacts. Would keep the kids amused, too.

Tokyo through time. This huge,multi-level museum gives you a glimpse of Tokyo's evolution as a city. Here you can see replicas of house, bridges, theaters, transportation, and buildings as well as dioramas of historical events that made a mark in this ever growing metropolis. Headsets are available for non-Nihonggo speaking guests. Guides are also available. Entrance fee is just ¥600 .

Just right . I chose this museum because I thought it would be good to get an overview of Tokyo's history before seeing the rest of the city itself, and I chose well. It gives just the right amount of information without being overwhelming. The hands-on exhibits are fun for all ages, and the 600yen admittance fee is quite reasonable. There are free guides for several languages. To find them, go the main exhibit entrance on 6 and they have a booth set up. There are also free (with a deposit) audio guides available at the ticket counter.

Fun and interesting Museum. More interesting than just rows of cabinets. Some hands on exhibits. Lots of model layouts of the city in bygone days. Some walk through houses. Good cafe upstairs. Well worth a vist.
No other place for History-Lovers. Better check for the opened days and times before you go, by the website. Nicely organized. Worth the money you spend.

Interesting perspective . A must see and experience for those seeking a glimpse into the Japanese culture and what it's like to have lived in Tokyo in past eras. It was larger and more interesting than I anticipated. Excellent concert in the central stage area.
A lot to see.. This is a very large museum. It is hard to describe as it covers so much. It provides a great insight into Japanese history and way of life.

Big Museum. This museum is a lot bigger than it looks when you first get in, so don't take too much time on the upper floor when there's so much to see on the lower floor. It's a well done museum, I would say allow 3 hours to visit. There are many life size models of houses and all the information is displayed in English. There are a few things that you can touch or get your picture taken on. The museum gave the history of Tokyo from it's beginnings to the present day. 600 yen per adult.

Well worth a visit. Never been to a museum like this before. Bright, open modern. Great exhibitions well laid out displays taking you on journey through the ages of Japan.Have a look in the shop small one upstairs with just a small selection wait and go to big store downstairs. A couple of restaurants but didn't try them as very busy.Make this a must do.

Friendly guide, informative & interactive!. Highly recommended. Even if you are not a history junkie, this place is worth so much more than ¥600 you pay to get in (or cheaper if you bring a student ID). They accept foreign student IDs also. I've been to Edo-Tokyo Museum in January when the 5-6 floors were under construction, without a guide.This time, I went with fellow expats/nomads and we got ourselves an English-speaking tour guide. She was a volunteer there and was very knowledgeable about everything.The remodeled 5-6 floors were very nice. They are designed as a walk-in exhibition where you can see life-sized models of townhouses and people who lived in them. It felt as if we time-traveled into the Edo period and the early days of Tokyo. On 5th floor, there is a huge theatre stage where concerts featuring traditional instruments and kabuki plays are performed.If you are in Ryogoku, you should stop by here and tuck some chanko-nabe hotpot in on the way home!

More interesting than a generic art museum. This museum is not really for everyone - people looking for a general art museum like the National Museum (which was honestly very disappointing) will not care for it, but if you are like me and love models and displays that give you a real feel for what Tokyo (Edo) was like through history, you will find this museum very interesting. There are numerous miniature, intricate models depicting daily life in Edo, as well as plenty of life-sized models of everything from a Kabuki theater to traditional artist's house. I was just impressed by the level of the detail in the miniature displays on even the kimonos of small figures. This is a pretty cool place pretty close by areas like Ginza and Tsukiji, so I would budget a few hours for it.

The history of Japan. Initially i wasn't too sure about going to this museum, but my husband really wanted to go . . . and I was so glad he stuck to his guns! This museum is nothing like a stuffy history museum . . .there are so many exhibits and the best part is that you can 'play' and interact with loads of them so you really feel as though you are learning a lot as well as having fun.The museum takes you on an amazing journey through Japan's history right through to modern day. We didn't use a tour guide, but did use a leaflet to show us the correct way to go round the museum and we didn't have any problems.The museum is huge and it took us a good couple of hours to make our way round. This is the perfect place to go on a rainy afternoon . . . and I learnt so much more about Japan. Very recommended . . . . . .

Great musem. Great palce to know more about the history of the Japanese people. Unfortunately thay don't have an Arabic translator so we took an English one. It gives new knowledge about the Japanese culture.

The perfect way to learn about old Tokyo. This museum is more like a time machine.Let me explain.Most museums I know of are the "walk around and look at stuff on the other side of a glass panel" type of museums.This museum has few glass cases too but a lot of it is more "walk in and feel the history".Let me say that the glass case displays are top notch displays so the whole experience is very, very enjoyable.The museum also has free guided tours in various languages. We were extremely lucky to tag along with one of their excellent English speaking tour guides. Seiichi Inoue is one of their volunteer tour guide and as well as being very knowledgable is a really fun person to be around. Having visited the museum and had such a wonderful guide has taken my appreciation where Tokyo is today to another level.Forget the Disneylands, go to the Edo-Tokyo Museum.

Great tour of Tokyo history. Worth strolling through this very large museum to get a taste of old Tokyo. The art, history, exhibits, lay out all make it easy to view and navigate. If you go in January/May/September, it's worth stopping over (get tickets) to watch sumo next door. Definitely worth a stop when in Tokyo.

Best laid out exhibition ever?. Seriously, few museums, if any, make a city's history into something so interesting.Real life models of so many things, from homes to a bridge! Scale models of the old Edo, from the castle to different areas of the city.It also shows so much more with interactive "please touch"displays.The best museum I've been to in Japan, out of 5.

Really interesting history of Tokyo . This museum is really worth it if you want to learn more about Tokyo. From its beginning, how it grew through land reclamation, was destroyed through fire, earthquake and war and rebuilt into what you see today. The exhibits are really great and the museum offers free multilingual guides on the 6th floor to take you around - and yes they are free! The facilities are great from umbrella and bag store, to an out door lounge, restaurants, all of which are easily accessed.

A Fun, Educational Glimpse into Tokyo's Past. On their own, the meticulously crafted dioramas showing life in Edo are worth the trip. But then, this museum has a lot more to offer. The moment we crossed over the replica of the Nihonbashi Bridge, we were transported right into Tokyo's history. Life-size and interactive replicas of vehicles and even merchant stalls were nice touches that helped bring the experience of old Edo to life.

Great Special Exhibit on the Battle of Sekigahara. The highlight of my recent visit was the special exhibit on the Battle of Sekigahara. My eight-year-old sone and nine-year-old nephew were captivated by the 400-year-old samurai armor and swords, as well as the short film that explained the rapidly changing alliances during the battle. Most of the exhibit was in Japanese, with some English translation but overall it was fascinating and worth the extra price. Of course the time ti took to go through this exhibit and a little time in the miniature area, most used up young boy museum patience, so we only managed to get through part of the remaining exhibit. The Museum is well worth the visit, especially if all special exhibits are this good.

this is what a museum should be. Edo-Tokyo museum sits in a very attractive building just beside the Sumo stadium. This museum is very attractive and interactive as well. You can explore how people in Tokyo live from time to time. Definitely worth to visit, especially if you are a first timer to Japan.

History of Life In Tokyo. It's been a couple of weeks since we visited the Edo Museum and I'm still not sure how I feel about it. On trips we've taken to other cities/countries we spent a lot of time in museums. Sometimes all day. But for some reason I just wasn't feeling the Edo Museum. There were certainly some interesting things to look at and we learned about the history of the city and what life was like for residents of various classes. But when I think back on the highlights and larger displays in the museum, most of them we're replicas or models. There are large scale reproductions of a typical Edo period home, a Kabuki theater, and the Nihonbashi Bridge. There are dioramas portraying the layout of the Imperial Palace complex and residences of Edo's elite class. All of those things were well done and had sufficient English descriptions. But I don't recall seeing anything in the museum that really piqued my interest. We paid extra to visit the special exhibit detailing the Sekigahara battle led by Tokugawa Ieyasu. There were a lot of official documents and letters without any translations that we just skipped over. But there were some great swords and suits of battle armor, actually used and worn in the battle hundreds of years ago. I guess those are the types of artifacts that I would have enjoyed seeing more of in the rest of the museum. Overall it was a good museum, but for most of our time there I was looking forward to getting back out into the city.

Educational museum. Our family (mom, dad and girls age 11 and 13) learned so much about the history of Tokyo in this museum. It is well laid out and there are English signs for everything. We spent 3 hours there and the girls were not bored. Well worth visiting.

Travel to old Tokio. The museum building is a bit odd and resembles more an industrial plant rather than museum. However, inside you get a feel of old Tokio through life-size buildings and other exhibits, as well as models.Quite oddly, the restaurant on ground floor is Italian cuisine...
History of Tokyo. Atypical museum in the traditional sense. It has lot of models and reproduction pieces. Very interesting visit. 25% discount coupon from at airport, Tokyo Metro building and JR Ueno

Truly inspiring and educational. If you have a keen interest in the Edo period and want to know more about the Tokugawa Shogunate period and the personal life of the shogun himself, this is one place that you must visit.Basic price is only 630 Yen but you get to see all that you need to see.Make sure you go with an interpreter or take an audio pack with you because some interesting exhibitions are only in Japanese.
Stunning modern museum. An excellently presented story with unusual presentation techniques. It has the most stunning entrance of any museum I know.

Loved the permanent collection exhibit. The special exhibit of Japanese woodblock prints from their permanent collection was the highlight of the whole museum. A complete history of Tokyo is presented with just enough English on the displays to keep us informed. We spent 3 hours in the museum and it wasn't even raining!

Unlike Any Museum. This place is just pure fun with amazing Japanese culture. With live shows, full scale exhibits, and unbelievable dioramas. You will spend several hours immersed in Japanese history and wonder where the time went, even the kids will find this museum engaging. Don't miss it.

great half day excursion for any age. this is a great museum for young and old alike not far from subway; also right next to the sumo arena. Sumo wrestlers seen around the outside, that's an eyeful right there! very nice permanent exhibit of old Japanese life and culture. There is option to buy higher price tickets for rotating exhibits but we skipped and went with basic ticket for permanent exhibit. Plenty to see for half day excursion- nice little restaurants inside as well. We had udon and sweets at the tea house, would return.

Staggering size, detail; worth visiting!. This museum is remarkable, and so extensive it very adequately covers the same area as two or three smaller museums in Tokyo. (This is just the permanent collection, mind!) This would be a great place to arrive mid-morning, explore for a couple of hours, take a break and then resume for an hour or two.

One of the best museums. The Edo-Tokyo Museum is one of the best and most educational museum I have visited. All 6 floors are entertaining. The 6th floor has various scale models of houses and how people lived in the old days. The 5th floor is interesting and fun as the left side shows the houses, activities, and culture during the Edo period while the other side showed more of the modern day Tokyo.Aside from the sights of scale models, antiques, and artifacts, there are also activities wherein the visitors can engage in, like writing using pen and ink, cool toys, etc, something to enrich the visitor's experience. The modern-day Tokyo side showed a timeline on the development of Japan ranging from houses to appliances to meals and education.A must-visit destination if you want to fully learn about Tokyo and the Japanese people.

We went on Monday 30th March and it was free entry. It was a last minute decision to go here, but I'm glad we did - it's a very informative exhibit.It's next to the train station and not too far from the Asakusa Kaminarimon Gate and Shrine, after this we walked over to the Sumida River Cruise. (Use google maps though as we constantly got lost).They have permanent exhibits of the Edo section of Tokyo laid out in minute detail - minatures and also large full-scale replicas of history buildings and entire sections of Tokyo (so much detail) and a lot of history. Plus you walk across this massive timber bridge as you enter the museum exhibits.There was a musical performance and "lucky dragon" show on at the time we were there, which the kids really enjoyed. There are a lot of exhibits to go and see, you won't need to go to any of the paid ones, the free ones are more than enough.

Impressive models but a bit stiff. This museum building is exciting from the outside as it appears to fly, but it does also contain an impressive exhibition on the inside. You will be guided through the history of Tokyo through very detailed models - real size as well as miniature versions. Parts of the exhibitions are a bit stiff and not as interactive as you would want. The top-floor restaurant, on the other hand, is a great place for lunch afterwards and provides nice views of the city!
Edo Museum. Super fantastic museum. We were led round by a fantastically knowledgable elderly volunteer who told us the fascinating history of Japan. We came out of this visit enriched.

Good rainy day venture.. Closed on Mondays, the Edo has a permanent exhibition and new ones for which you have to pay more. The standing one is enough to while away ninety minutes at least and the shop may bring the visit up to two hours. Lots of hands on exhibits, opportunities for photographs and scale models in exquisite detail of city life in the Edo period, plus a marvellous theatre and Kabuki costumes. Would recommend the free tour to gain a deeper understanding of the culture. My second visit in three years, enjoyed it more second time around as had my twelve year old with me.

A fascinating glimpse into history. A well laid out journey from the 1600s to modern day. Ranging from detailed dioramas to huge reconstructions of houses and theatres, lots of information and free English speaking guides to give very personal tours.

Modern museum experience. The Edo has only just reopened after refurbishment and was worth the metro journey across Tokyo to see it. The museum is housed in a huge building enabling it to present tableaux which it only in part succeeded in achieving, it could have used the vast spaces to better effect.The models were very interesting as were the detailed statistics compiled about life in Edo over time.As an English speaking tourist there was barely enough translation which the museum management ought to re examine.

Interesting historical museum. Some folks will love this place and others will be vastly underwhelmed. The premise of the museum is outstanding and well executed: tons of diorama's to show you what Tokyo looked like when it was founded as Edo. There are great exhibits that demonstrate how normal people lived: recreated homes, shops, kitchens, etc. The underwhelming part is that you only have two floors of real exhibits. Honestly, you could see everything here in under an hour. This place just screams to use more of the space to show what Japanese gardens looked like, fishing village recreations, what a Samurai holding looked like, you name it. Seems like they just aren't using the gigantic space that the building has.

Re-opened with amazing reconstructions. When I was told this was a folk museum I had visions of farmyards and workshops. You go to the top floor, and walk over a bridge to see a reconstruction of the old city together with various artefacts, including a wonderful Imperial sedan chair. You look down onto the next floor which is concerned with the way ordinary folk lived and you can see a variety of reconstructed houses.The children seemed to be enjoying sitting in the sedans, riding penny farthing bicycles and so on but I did not think it a particularly child-friendly museum - considering the upgrade they could have done more. There is a stage so I assume there are performances during the day.As it only re-opened over Easter it is currently very busy - we had to queue for 20 minutes to get tickets. I recommend looking for details on the internet before going as I had little time and can only give a short impression.There are plenty of coffee shops around but again, at weekends you have to queue.

A nice museum - not breathtaking but worth a visit. We enjoyed the visit to this museum. There were some nice exhibits and the models of Endo gave an interesting context to the city. There were a few outstanding artifacts and the museum has really tried to make it interactive and fun for all ages. The information that accompanied the exhibits were well translated. A very professional effort. Not breathtaking but worth a trip.

Not the Most Exciting Museum. I was quite excited about visiting the Edo-Tokyo museum considering the great reviews I'd read. We bought a joint Special & Permanent Exhibition ticket. The Special Exhibition was about the battle of Sekigahara - the exhibits were very good looking but there were no English translations on most of them (there were 4 boards overall explaining the battle that did have English versions), which made it not very tourist friendly. The permanent exhibitions were reasonable - there were some good replicas of older styles of living in the Edo period. However, I thought overall, the museum could have had more exhibits and information beyond the political situation then. Floor 5F, was definitely more engaging on this count - it had interactive pieces as well as models that people could play around with.

Fantastic interactive experience!. I'm a big fan of museums. My favorites are those that mix history with interaction. I feel it breaks from monotony of information.This museum's main exhibit was recently renovated, and its' fantastic. There are many videos to watch all in a variety of languages. There are tons of performances and plenty of activities for people of all ages.The majority of the museum is devoted primarily prior to the Great Kanto Earthquake. However there is still a large exhibition for both the earthquake and Tokyo Firebombings.I highly recommend visiting this museum. It's definitely worth visiting, and is very easy to travel to as the subway stops literally right below it.

Memorable. I watched the japanese drama Jin and was hugely interested in Edo history and culture. Edo museum happens to be one of the best resources i can find in Tokyo. Really enjoyable visit and loved the big and small models of Edo city.

main collection closed but small one summarized one open, & GOOD!. Unluckily, when I was in Tokyo, Edo-Tokyo museum was under renovations. So the access to the whole museum was closed. But they made a small collection with the main pieces and set it up on the first floor. To be honest it was great considering I was a bit short on time, and I got to see a bit of everything from Edo-era. Also quite interesting illustrations to explain each period and how everything was & how it was changing. It felt like a small time travel.Very nice!Also it has a room to experience Edo, which is super cool and you can go inside those things that carry people… palanquins? Any ways, super pedagogical and interactive!Since I love souvenirs I must say, GREAT souvenir store!! I bought some amazing paper to bring home.
evolution of Tokyo. Tells the story of Tokyo's growth from fishing village into one of the world's great cities, with massive scale models, extensive artifacts, several shows and pictures.
A space shuttle. When you see a space shuttle you know that you arrived there. It's one of the most well kept secrets of Tokyo.

Visit before taking in a sumo tournament. Our family with young kids visited for a change of pace before hours of sitting watching sumo next door and enjoyed it (and the sumo too!). Huge building and escalator to entrance feels like Star Trek, but the cavernous space is well filled with exhibits of all sizes, from streetscapes, homes, shops, cars and full-scale bridge replica to the most minute Edo items and even replicas of Edo neighborhoods. The museum presents a very good overview of life during the Edo period. Some reviewers comment that the museum which is traditionally curated should have a little more interactivity, but the huge space and the great variety of exhibits held our 6 year old's interest between the items such as an old bicycle, telephone booth or home that he could play on/in or explore. The visit prompted a lot of discussion with our 11 year old, so really well worth the visit.

Interesting for history buffs. If history is your thing, you will enjoy learning about how Japanese society and Edo/Tokyo developed. If you aren't into history, then you might not enjoy these attractions.

Don't forget the Sumo Museum next door... We visited this place after the Ryogoku Kokugikan. We found it was quite a pleasant stop to understand Japanese culture in Edo time. The museum itself has a very good collection to have a look at as well as trying your luck in carrying pales and going on bicycles.Good bits- Good collection Bad bits- most of the signs are in Japanese.

Nice place, check the sumo museum next door. Some of the museum was closed, but it was still interesting, you can have your picture taken in different Japanese things. There's also a big shop where you can but all Japanese things.

Partially closed for now. I enjoyed what I saw; very informative. However, most of the museum is currently closed. Looking forward to returning. While the tourbook suggested there was an audio guide, the ticket desk did not. Most of the signage is in Japanese so that limited my understanding.

Well worth a visit to learn about the Edo-Tokyo history and culture.. I was originally going to the SKYTREE but as the weather and visibility was bad I changed my plans and went to the 'Edo-Tokyo Museum' and I am so glad I did as I learnt much of the Edo period and the history and culture of Japan and its Capital City.The Permanent Exhibitions on upper floors of the Museum are closed at the moment (scheduled to re-open on 28th March 2015) so there is currently a special temporary exhibition on called "Explore! Experience! Edo-Tokyo" which is on the First Floor. The exhibition is not that large but is does give a nice introduction to the history and culture of the Edo era and the changes that Tokyo has seen over the centuries. There are some lovely things to see, including all sorts of artefacts from across the different periods in Edo-Tokyo's history and evolution. I particularly liked the Japanese woodblock printing exhibits and bought some nice postcards of images from Hiroshige's One Hundred Famous Views of Edo prints.The best way to get to the Museum is to take the Subway using the Oedo Line to Ryogoku Station (E12). Museum entrance cost was just JPY300 (about GB£1.75) and so it's amazing value and well worth a visit, especially on a wet cold day like the day I visited!!! I had a light lunch at "Finn's Café" at the Museum which was nice enough and also if in the area it is worth walking for 5 minutes over to the 'Sumo Museum at the Ryogoku Kokugikan' where the grand Sumo tournaments are held.

Fascinating - need a couple of hours. Really enjoyed this museum. We were encouraged to take the free Museum Tour. So glad that we did this. Our guide spoke perfect English and there were only 4 of us on this tour. He explained everything so well and because we were really interested he took extra time. The tour lasted 2 and half hours and we learnt so much. Right next to MTR Station.
Great. yes yes its undergoing renovations till March but it's still great fun and a real insight into the history of Tokyo

Main exhibit closed till late march 2015. The museum still had a lot on display, including paintings, kimonos, and even rickshaws and 1800's style bicycles that you could sit and take a photo in. Would have liked to see the main exhibit though.
Don't bother. The museum consists of some models of old Tokyo (Edo) and a few other random artefacts with minimal descripption in English.

Undergoing renovations. The two floors with the layout of old Edo are currently undergoing renovation. Some pieces have been moved to a lower floor for viewing and are interesting to see. In all, I'd give it a pass until the full exhibit re-opens.

Main Exhibit Closed Until March 2015. Even though the main exhibit was closed until March 2015, the special temporary exhibit was well worth the 300¥. The signs had limited English explanation, but for the most part the section markers did a good job of explaining the historical significance of the exhibit items.
Lots to see, worth a look. I usually avoid museums but this one was worth it. To see the history of Edo-Tokyo the large dioramas and other interesting period objects.

Fantastic place. Museums are not among the best places to see in Japan as compared to Europe. But this museum is worth a visit and a must-visit if in Tokyo. Beautiful and lively display of Tokyo's history.

Edo museum. Edo museum at Tokyo has good collection of exhibits dating back to edo period and enables us to grasp the history of the evolution of Tokyo by foreign visitors like be easily. It is a must see place in Tokyo.It is worth visiting such places than just looking up on concrete tall buildings which have nothing to enrich our knowledge.

Not thrilled by museums, try this one. One in our party was not very interested but as it was raining, he agreed. All 3 of us give it 5 stars.
Fascinating life-size and scale models from 1600's to 20th century. Interesting building too. We even had a very pleasant late lunch.
Tokyio from small place to great city. I like history very much so for me this place was amazing. I do not know what to say. I highly recomend everyone.

Not much to see while closed for renovation. Excited about this widely promoted and top rated museum, we found only a small "special exhibit" that took about 15 minutes to see (cost 300 JPY). The museum has been closed for renovations until some time next year.
The plans for the future displays look very impressive. Check the museum website for the opening.

Fantastic museum about Tokyo's development. This museum is the story of how Tokyo went from being a backwater fishing village in 1600 to the largest city in the world. Its exhibits cover daily life in town, regional economics, arts and theatre, and more. The main exhibition has so much content it took me two visits to really get through it all.

A must do overview of Tokyo and Japanese history and culture. A great blend of information, exhibits, performances and hands on activities.
There is a great deal of information to take in and I enjoyed it all. I am a museaum geek and have pretty high standards but this met them.

Interesting. I was really looking forward to visiting this museum. We went on Tuesday as they are closed on Mondays, guess what, the week we were there they were also closed on Tuesday. Just meant another day of subway travel to get there when open. The displays were interesting. I wish they would add English translation to at least some of the exhibits. I recommend going with a Japanese speaker.

well laid out & a live show !. If you are there at about 10;30am take up a position on the Nihonbashi to watch the drum show below. It was very entertaining although mainly orientated towards the many school kids in attendance. The building appears somewhat imposing externally but the use of space offers different levels & rooms for the exhibits. Definitely worth a visit, and, as already suggested, check out the nearby Sumo stadium & restaurants.

I liked this better than my teens. Heaps to learn but about to close for several months for refurbishment but if yiu like museums and interested in history than do visit and follow up with a chanko nabe sumo lunch at any of the many nearby restaurants.
Great museum. Good place to visit to get a better insight into Tokyo and its history. There are very good and pleasant guides. I recommend it.

Worth a visit, only some English though. What you're met with first is a very unique looking building (architecture enthusiasts will find the building fascinating in itself.) It looks like something out of Star Wars! There's quite a lot to see with heaps of scale models as well as life-sized bridges and buildings inside. It's really quite a large building!The tickets are quite cheap at 600yen or less if you're a student or child.There's several different types of food for sale with pleasant views of the city. There's also a library which is a nice place to spend a few hours if it's raining itself.My only real criticism was the lack of english explanation in some places. While most descriptions did have English text next to them, some didn't.

Great museum, great guide. This museum was fantastic. It was set up in an incredibly accessible way for all styles and ages of learners. Many exhibits - full-sized recreations of buildings and items lived in and used by Edo-ites over time - could be touched, pulled, and sat on. This made it friendly for kids and also engaged a lot of adults (myself included).There were good English language written materials and free audio guides but what really made it for me was our guide volunteer. She was knowledgeable, funny, and extremely nice! To give you an idea of the experience she brought to visit - she learned her excellent English from Canadian and American soldiers before the war. She could personally speak to the sweeping changes in Japan between then and now.

The best stop for a short visit in this area!. This Museum was filled with lots os older items and finds dated from way back. The building and the history was amazing! To see all those little towns, people and buildings built in miniture took a great deal of time to create. A true feeling of the Japanese culture. A must see!

Fun and informative. Here you can see how Edo's people living... The house, the economy system ,the plumbing system, and how its change to modern Tokyo. The day i visit there was a Taiko attraction ^^ .
Informative and accessible. I visited this museum with Japanese friends. I was impressed by the scope and accessibility of the information. It was a great way to learn a lot about Tokyo.

Great Japanese museum!!!. I spent a couple hours in the Edo-Tokyo Museum. I was amazed by the museum structure itself. With many directories in English and a friendly tourguide that helped me easily to learn a lot of information about the history and culture of Japan. Well worth your time and money! I would highly recommend this museum if you visit Tokyo.

A great experience.. The Edo Museum could be done quickly and would still be an experience worth doing, but if you enlist one of the free guides (in many langueages), the museum comes alive with commentary, both personal and canned. We had the pleasure of having an 80 year old guide who related his perosnal experiences both before and after WWII and it was quite moving. The building is also interesting and it is a cinch to reach on the subway.

My personal highlight. For me personally this was the highlight of my trip in Tokyo. Not necessarily because of especially unique exhibits but because of it being a central place to learn about Tokio and its history, going back to the times it was still called Edo. Just a couple of minutes away from the station you cannot miss this huge building. Whenever you're through, the Sumo-Arena Kokugikan is just around the corner. In the museum you can take either an audio tour or an actual tour, and I would recommend taking one of them on your trip throughout the cities' history.

Fantastic way to explore Edo-era Tokyo. A really great museum covering the Edo-era. The miniature scenes showing Tokyo at the time, domestic scenes, some landmark buildings are truly impressive (not to mention the real-size replica of Nihonbashi bridge and the Kabuki theatre).The free guided tours are a great initiative too - I was lucky enough to have a private guide all to myself!

Interesting Introduction. Some elements of this museum were interesting and informative, others a little kitsch. It gives a good high level background to the history of Tokyo and it is quite an interesting building. We went about 4.30pm and it was not very busy at all.

Great experience with volontary guides. A perfect museum if you want to learn more about the Edo-era. I strongly recommend that you take a volontary guide. The work at the museum for free and speak perfect english.

Great Introduction to Tokyo. This is a beautifully done museum- a huge space with scaled vignettes of various times in Tokyo's history. I think that this would be a great place to start a visit to Tokyo because it provides a good introduction to the city. Great for kids. I arrived on a day when admission to the permanent exhibits was free so it might be worthwhile checking their website.
Lots of History. for those interested in understanding history of Tokyo - great placeyou have audio guides to help understand the displays.Great reconstructions & small models on display
See visit. Super like this museum, mr. Seiichi Inoue was our guide, walked us thru the history of tokyo (edo period). Good to now how tokyo evolved to what it is today

Good history museum. The Edo turned out to be a good history museum especially on the older Edo period and less so on modern Tokyo. So, it depends on what period you're interested in. In general it didn't strike me as a 5* as aears in a number of guide books.

Engaging experience. This museum is very interesting, and has some quite impressive displays, including some life size reconstructions and a lot of smaller models that give a fascinating glimpse into the city's history. The exhibits are varied and the models make it quite kid-friendly, since it's easy to be curious, ask questions and tell stories.I visited with my 9 year old son, and he was entertained for a few hours, and had a good experience. There was also many Japanese children, so I would guess it's a popular spot for families. For picky western eaters, there's a cafe in the second floor that serves European style food.

Interesting !!. Such an amazing place, big and informative. You wont feel board of the load of informations you will read about as you will be walking looking at different models and displays that are well presented. Enjoyed the english earphones as i cant read Japanese. A very good start if you are interested in Japanese history.

A good place to start your visit in Japan. many costumes, even hair dos of gaisha. the history of the shoguns. The way houses looked built in miniatures. Also watching many school children visit this museum was revealing the respect the Japanese pass on their children.

Tea Ceremony. Went to this Museum to experience a tea ceremony on the grounds. It was free that day. I only paid 300 yen for the tea ceremony. The flowers, the buildings, the idea of this type of museum is wonderful. Very peaceful once a secluded area is found.

Great History Lesson and Free English Tour Guide. Came to the Edo-Tokyo Museum to kill some time before watching the Sumo Wrestling Tournament in Ryogoku next door. Didn't think I would enjoy it as much as I would have but the tour guide made it absolutely wonderful. The admission for an adult is 600 yen. If you want there are headsets with English Translation that are rented out for free- just 1000 yen deposit but will be refunded once the headset is returned. Once you go up to the main exhibition floor there is a counter were there are different language speaking tour guides that will walk you through the museum exhibit. Our tour guide was absolutely lovely- he gave us a detailed enough history lesson without boring us. He had sure to show us all the main displays that were in the exhibit and answered all the questions that we asked about.I think that if you're up for a little learning and cultural experience the Edo-Tokyo Museum is a great place to go!

Interesting and Detailed. This is clearly a museum that has put some serious thought and effort into maximizing the experience for its guest. There's a well laid out route that follows both chronologically and thematically, interspersed with a number of kid friendly hands-on activities and photo ops. And the model cities are amazingly detailed.

Awesome Museum Experience!. I spent a couple hours in the Edo-Tokyo Museum and learned a great deal about The history and culture. The best decision i made was asking for on of the volunteer guides. As soon as you arrive on the sixth floor you will see a counter and sign about the free guides. The guide was so much better than any other museum guide i have encountered, audio or otherwise. She was energetic and well versed in stories related to the many artifacts. She answered my steady stream of questions with wonderful enthusiasm. I found thelayout of the museum thoughtful and interesting. I was amazed by the museum structure itself, as the guide pointed out was designed with special earthquake reinforcements and supports. I would highly recommend the museum and the use of the guides.

Great traditional Japanese museum . We have been here a couple of times now and it's great for a couple of hours. Get the audio tour which is free. Just need to leave a returnable deposit. On way home if you go when sumo is on you might see some sumo wrestlers. Great afternoon out.

Wonderful introduction to old Tokyo. This museum is dedicated to Edo, which was the original name for Tokyo, and give the visitor a very interesting glimpse into Tokyo's past. You enter the 6th floor exhibition via a replica of Edo's original wooden bridge, and look down upon the old city, which is very impressive. I really enjoyed my visit to this museum.

One of the best museums I've been to!!. Loved this museum!! Very interactive, lots of English captions. Free guided tours are also available, although we didn't have one and learned a lot simply by reading. This museum stands out because there are so many 3D models -- it's more than just looking at artifacts behind glass. 600 yen per person, about 2-3 hour trip. Well worth your time and money!

Great museum of Tokyo history. We were really pleased with our visit to the Edo-Tokyo museum, there was a great range of exhibits with plenty of English translations. We especially liked the ancient pottery and the history of books & printing in Tokyo. We spent about an hour and a half here and got around all of the exhibits.

Interesting insights into old Tokyo. This museum is housed in a modern, highly futuristic building. It shows what life was like through the years for the residents of Tokyo in a fascinating way. The area dealing with the last war is quite harrowing, with details of the bombing and how it affected the people. Wonderful souvenir shop- all very good prices. A good half day trip.

Shows the Many Sides of Tokyo. The first thing that struck me about the Edo-Tokyo Museum was the building’s design. It’s a giant structure supported by four pillars, and to enter the museum, you have to go under it and ride up an escalator in a tube. The museum itself isn’t half-bad, either. Its exhibits are divided in half between Tokyo and Japan’s older and modern history (Before and after the Meiji revolution of 1868). The displays include life-size artifacts in addition to many smaller-scale models of buildings and neighbourhoods. They even have binoculars set around them for you to examine them up close. Some, but not all, of the descriptions are written in English in addition to Japanese, but even so, anyone with an interest in Japanese history must give this museum a try.

reccommended. Next to the sumo stadium, this excellent museum is well worth the visit.We focused on the excellent Ghibli exibition, so well done! The permanent exibition is gorgeus as well but we were too tired to fully enjoy it.Plan ahead and get there with plenty of time and rested, this place deserv it.

Worth a visit if history of Edo-Tokyo interests you. . ¥600 per adult to get in. Open from 0930 to 1730 and closed Monday. Train Station is Ryogoku E12 on the Oedo Line. Exit A4 turn left on the street and the stairs to enhance is about 50 metres away. Very easy to get to. Walking up the stairs you reach the third level where you can buy your ticket. Escalator or lift will take you to the 6th floor where the permanent exhibition is kept. I recommend that if you are there between 1000 and 1500 use the voluntary guides as most of the signage had minimal English explanation. I enjoyed the exhibitions and the attempt to make some of it a hands on. Great photo opportunities make it a personal experience but I still rated it a 4 and not a 5 because I felt like I was in a warehouse. My favorites were the printed matter and wood block prints and the recreation of some housing etc. The museum store on the 5th floor has some great souvenirs.The first floor had a lovely little tea room. The Ryogoku Sarara, the ladies there were lovely. There was a larger store and a special exhibition on the new movie from Studio Ghibli called " When Marnie was There", tickets were ¥1200.

Interesting displays. Very educational for those who want to understand japan culture from way back. Their displays or artefact are very interesting. Kids love the maps, old items from before which they haven't seen today. There are also performances inside from Japanese traditional dancers

The most interesting museum on Tokyo history. Amazing museum describing the origin of Tokyo as the imperial city, first, and Capital city of Japan then (from Edo to Tokyo, in fact). The museum offers a free guided tour service, which everyone should choose to attend. Guides are Japanese/English-speaking professionals, extremely well prepared on the content and history of the Museum itself. Guided tours can be arranged as far as language and duration of tours. The Museum allows visitors to also "physically touch" some items, to better understand. Shows on music and performances are available.Strongly recommended to anyone visiting Japan, it's worthwhile a visit (tickets not expensive at all).

Informative and great replicas. I enjoyed this museum a lot - there was a replica of a kabuki theatre, and there were many interesting artifacts from the Edo-Tokyo period all the way up to modern day. The layout was great and was a timeline up to the upcoming Olympics memorabilia. This is definitely a good choice for a museum while you are in Tokyo!

Not easy to do on your own. I went by myself to this museum. It was more difficult than I expected to understand all of the exhibits. The free English speaking guides were not available when I was there. So, I checked out a set of headphones. Unfortunately, English explanations of exhibits were available for only a handful of the permanent exhibits and none of the special exhibits. I felt the museum was more for Japanese visitors than American visitors.

Definately cannot miss!. Great museum to learn about the history of Tokyo.However, it is only two floors. There do have special exhibitions - which really attract people to come, but this special exhibition costs extra.

Really Interesting Museum of Edo/Tokyo's History. This is a really special, wonderful museum of Tokyo's history from its early days as Edo to current times. Unlike many history museums which can be staid and boring, this one really brings the history to life through use of artifacts, recreations, films, etc all laid out in a very interesting manner. Highly recommended. The museum is right near the JR and Toei Oedo Ryogoku train stations. Note for English speakers: there are many signs in English although also easy to sign up for an English speaking guide

Great Miniatures and Beautiful Building Re-Creation. This Edo Tokyo Museum is my first stop in Tokyo.. I don't have high expectation and yet, I was surprised by packed content inside the building. The museum is filled with a lot of character miniatures and beautiful building replicas.. When you entered the museum, you will go to the top level (6th floor), then you'll be greeted with the beautiful hall with wooden bridge connecting the two side of the building.. With relatively cheap entrance ticket (only 600 yen per person, even free admission for children below 5 y.o), you get a great experience of Tokyo in the past.. For non-Japanese speaker, it is recommended to either rent an audio-speaker guide (for free, but you need to deposit cash in the locker) or you could "hire" a english-speaking volunteer on the 6th level entrance.

See this early in your visit and profit. Less well known than other places, this museum would be a great place to see early in your visit as it situates Tokyo-Edo in time and place. A modern museum with full scale reproductions and maps and miniatures, you can get a real sense of the city as it grew over the centuries, how it came to be laid out as it was, and thus improve your experience of the city while you are there.Pluses are: excellent reconstructions and artifacts from every era especially the WWII period, a sample Kabuki theater building and demonstrations of entertainment, maps and miniatures of neighborhoods and how they functioned. Minuses are less than intuitive directionals and limited English signage. Free English speaking guides are available, though. Fine gift shop at the end.

Worth seeing. If you want to get to know the history of Tokyo and japanese culture - it's the right place to go. You can find there many miniatures of castles or natural-size reproductions of ancient houses. Many interesting things and a lot to read (almost every piece of exhibit is accompanied by description). Unfortunately for me after some time it just got a little boring and tiring. Also lack of more interactive exhibitions. Also very crowded place.To see everything carefully, you should prepare for a few hours (and maybe take some snacks!).

A blast from the past. This is a wonderful museum centred around the history of Tokyo but with displays from other parts of Japan dating back thousands of years. The museum offers a free guiding service for different languages that overcomes the feeling of so much to see, so little time. Yamamoto-san, who was born in 1929, is a spritely English-language guide who brought the museum to life for us and provided a lot of history and insight over and above what was on display.The model cities and walk-in displays are superb and we can highly recommend spending at least half a day here.

Must do while in Tokyo!. Great museum with many different mediums to look at. Need 3~4 hours to see it in full. Near the end we were so tired we were rushing through things I wouldve normally found interesting. Definitely don't need to read every single thing and skim things that aren't super interesting to you! In the same area there is a small and free sumo museum with a variety of things and some English. There was no sumo going on while we were in town but it's still worthwhile to go have a look around. Edo-Tokyo museum is very well done!

Fun museum with lots of history. Of in the Sumida ward of Tokyo, you can get there by taking the subway. Taxi from central Tokyo may be bit expensive because this museum is located on the east end. If you are staying in the west end like Shinjuku, forget taking a taxi.. it will cost you as much as one night hotel stay and take over an hour.The place is very big but during hot summer, it's so nice to be in this air-conditioned museum. Lots of history of Edo, which is what Tokyo used to be called. Edo was the capital of Japan in the Shogun days. They have all kinds of displays and even miniature model of central Edo and life size replica of Japanese bridge. Lots of fun with children. It may be helpful if you read beforehand a little bit about the history of Japan especially the period of the Tokugawa Shogunate when Edo/Tokyo was the seat of government.Only about $5 for entry fee. Audio guide in English was free!
Back in the past. This museum was huge. You will feel a little bit back in that Era. Good to see and understanding a Asian history and culture. You will enjoy and relax while strolling through.

Great museum.. This museum was really nice... I really learnt a lot about Tokyo and as it was called Edo, there are lovely scaled models of the street scape dotted around the museum with binoculars so you can get a closer look... I thought I would get around the museum in 1 hour but I think I was there for 3 hours. The more I write this the more I remember.  Very well worth the visit,,, but don't go on mondays as it is closed for invitation only (don't quote me) I went there on a Monday.

Awesome Museum. What a fantastic museum for me and my son. It is right around the corner from where the sumo fights are held. Made a go place to visit while we waited for the sumo fights to begin. Lots of history on the beginnings of Tokyo from the city of Edo.

Facinating Insight. This museum is a must see for any visit to Tokyo. It gives great insight into the history and culture of the country. I thought it brought back the past to life. I recommend booking a guide. We had a lovely English speaking Japanese lady who explained the exhibits to us and answered our numerous questions. It made a huge difference to our enjoyment.There is a traditional Japanese restaurant in the museum which is excellent and quite reasonably priced.

Great History of Tokyo - Much Better Than We Expected. For history buffs and anyone interested in the history of modern Japan, this is a great museum. I really wished that this had existed when I lived in Japan 25 years ago, as it explained so much that I didn't understand then. This is more of a modern museum with plenty of life-size reconstructions and dioramas taking visitors through the history of Tokyo, from its founding as Edo under the Tokugawa Shogunate through to the modern day. This includes some unique insights into life in the lead-up to and during WWII.There are some amazingly detailed reconstructions of street scenes from Tokyo's history and daily domestic life. There is enough English signage to make the visit worthwhile if you don't speak Japanese. Apparently the English guides are good if you are nervous about the amount of Japanese, but speaking both languages, I though the English signage was just fine.  The museum provides insights into daily life and who the Japanese are that as a tourist you can't normally get by visiting the temples and shrines. There are some interesting insights into the commuter and "salaryman" cultures which dominated so much of 20th century Japan.There is enough to keep kids interested and if you relate them back to your own country then it will be quite an educational experience.

A lot to take in!. Firstly, I would definitely recommend getting an audio guide- they don't cost anything other than a returnable deposit, and although they basically tell you what is written on the stands, it means you can peruse at your leisure. There are also some foreign language tours, which we were unable to attend as we were at the mercy of an 18 month old's attention span!There are some very interesting artefacts and models which give an insight into life in Edo, the origin of the Tokyo we know now. However, towards the end of the visit I started to feel like my brain was trying to process too much information, I'd recommend skipping bits if there's an exhibition futher on that you know you want to look at. Personally I found the Tokyo at war section really interesting and poignant. It was interesting to hear about the war from a Japanese perspective.There's a really nice gift shop (one of the nicest we found actually) selling souvenirs.Top tip! They are very strict about no eating or drinking, even for babies, so don't make the mistake we did and try to sneak your child a quick snack to keep them going if you want to avoid a telling off by the eagle eyed attendants!

Just Okay. The Edo Museum is a large building that has only two floors of exhibitions illustrating some of the history of Tokyo. Some of the exhibits are large reproductions that are grand on nature, while others require a lot of reading. Overall, it's a decent place to spend two hours on a rainy Tokyo day but it definitely is not a must see attraction.

Great Historic Value. Spent a few days in Tokyo back in 2008 as I was visiting friends while I was living in Nagoya doing the typical foreign aspect of teaching English. This was by far one of my highlights while visiting Tokyo as I didn't expect much from this museum as I had been to a lot of temples, shrines and a few other museum since my arrival to Japan and they simple left me wanting more. This museum gives great insight to the Edo area and somewhat leans into why Japan is still very different from other countries around the world and why the Japanese seem to be multiple people at times. As they say two faced, public face and private face. I am so coming back to this museum on a future visit to Japan as I was so interested and it was a lot of information to take in all at once. A bit overwhelming. Warning though this is not a artifact Museum but rather a history museum but by far worth the visit. For Artifacts visit the prefectures Castles that are spread out across Japan.

Good overview of Tokyo/Edo history but few artifacts. As others have noted, this museum gives a good overview of Edo-Tokyo history. Wow is the history and structure complex.The museum does a good job of walking through the history up until modern day. My wife and I enjoyed the history lesson.Reason for "average" review is two: (1) there are few "original" artifacts in the museum [many items are reproduction] and (2) the museum is geared heavily towards adults and difficult to keep attention span of non-Japanese reading elementary or middle school children.Sumo museum is a short walk from this museum.
Terrific historic museum. Shows what Tokyo would have been like in the imperial days of yore. superbly done and easy to get around in.

Important start to a visit. The museum is organized into 2 sections - Edo Period and Tokyo's history. We took a volunteer guide tour in English through the Edo period and found it very interesting. Our guide was knowledgable and friendly. We found that what we learned helped us with the rest of our tour through Japan and its historic sites, given how important the Edo period was to establishing everything from crafts to industry to civic infrastructure and more. Some exhibits are better than others but overall there is enough to keep everyone in the family engaged. Do consider using a guide for some of your visit - they are free and very good.

Not to be missed. This is not a museum of paintings. It has wonderful models of old Tokyo (Edo) including market places, theaters, and more. There is a smaller exhibit of daily items from the 1920s and a small but interesting display on WWII that focuses exclusively on the bombing of Tokyo. Nevertheless, even if you find some museums boring, you will like this one as the exhibits are full size and a great way to learn about the history and culture of Tokyo.

Nice exhibits detailing the history of Tokyo.. This is an oddly shaped looking museum, where the exhibits are all located up the building. There is sufficient English exhibits and as its name suggests, the museum mainly focuses on Edo and Tokyo. Of greater interest to me were the period from the post great earthquake to the world war period segment. Overall, you can easily spend 1-2 hours here looking at the exhibits, and definitely more time if you plan to use the English audio guide. As the exhibits are too specific simply on Tokyo, i would recommend skipping this and visiting the national museum if you are more interested in understanding the history of the nation as a whole.

Essential to understand the history of Tokyo. A large, wonderful museum for adults and children alike with magnificent models of old Edo, interactive exhibits and cultural information. We were there for 3 hours and could have easily spent more time. The reproduction of Nihonbashi near the entrance is magnificent.

Wonderfully arranged and full of detailed information. This is a large museum that is extremely well organized with information, artwork, dioramas , clothing of the times and more. One can easily spend several hours in this museum and not see it all. Many of the exhibits are interactive with explanations in both Japanese and English. The set up of the actual museum building mimics an old elevated warehouse and you cross the replica of the Nihonbashi bridge with life sized buildings on the side, to enter. There are two zones on two floors...the Edo period and the Tokyo period. There are clean bathrooms throughout and a wonderful gift store. I suggest going early as it does get crowded.

Great museum into edo era and wwII time. Nice place to spend 3-4 hours if you like his ory stuff. They have great reconstructions, models and actual buildings inside.lots of WWII Stuff as well. While it might not have all signs in English they have a miniature part of the city from the Edo period with individual people. They give you binoculars to look closely at it. That w8ns it for me

Beautiful museum. Large and beautiful museum. I got the audio tour device, which gave me a lot of good information. Although this museum is better for adults and older children with a good attention span, my 4-year-olds enjoyed the interactive pieces and even learned some Japanese history.
Fascinating account of the Japanese history. Interesting and fascinating displays. It is advise to join one of the guided tours as there are details that have to be explained to non-Japanese.

Only worth it if you have time to kill. I was rather disappointed with the museum as despite the building being very large, the actual number of genuine items on display was really quite limited and many consisted of replicas or model exhibits. Some of the displays cover the Kanto Earthquake of 1923 which perhaps explains the lack of items as along with the WW2 bombings much of the Edo historical items have been sadly lost. The best aspect of the museum was the architectural design of the building which is quite futuristic and striking when viewed from behind. For me it was only worth visiting as I was going to the Sumo stadium next door. If you are interested in the history of Tokyo / Japan I would suggest visiting the Tokyo national museum in Ueno park instead, which has a far greater collection and has the longest history of all museums in Japan holding 87 national treasures.

Vast in historical scope. For anyone who wants to know even a little about the history of Tokyo, this is a must-see attraction. The scope of the museum is vast, covering every era of Edo/Tokyo (from 1590 until present day), so there is sure to be something of interest. Do allow yourselves a good 3+ hours to take everything in.On display are numerous dioramas - scaled models of entire areas of the city to life-size windows on daily life - historical items and (scaled) replicas of boats and carriages etc. It is worthwhile taking the audio guide option upon entering as there is little in the way of English translations throughout. This is a fascinating museum, one that feels far more lively than some of the cold and austere museums elsewhere (howsoever good they may be), suitable for adults and children alike.

Museum with personality. Many museums were visited during our brief stay in Tokyo and the Edo-Tokyo Museum was one of the highlights. It is easy to access via the rail system and only a short walk easily signposted for non-Japanese speakers.When the security officer suggests you use the escalators to access the entrance, do. It's a wonderful way of going up the building.The museum itself has been designed to be explored and time can be spent reading about various elements of the city and period - from all levels of life. There are also performances by musicians as well as in the recreated theatre. There are interactive/allowed to touch parts of the exhibits. We arrived late and didn't stop to use any of the food/drink venues but did go to the souvenir store had a good range of items.

Loved it. As adults with high interest in Japan history we loved this museum. It's very interactive- has miniature streets and shops depicting Edo era life, large indoor houses and buildings you can look or walk into and other cool things.There's an audio guide option at the desk where you buy the tickets. From what I noticed most of the recorded guide is a voice reading of the plaques next to the exhibits. We liked it anyway, it's nicer to examine the exhibits while listening to explanations instead of reading a long essay written on a plaque. We recommend it!Beautiful souvenir shops, and a tasty Italian restaurant outside.

Short on storytelling . My children, 5 and 7, engaged with the big objects, enjoyed the bicycles and rickshaw. But found little else to teach them inside, where there is little in English. Lucky there was a music demonstration when we were there. And the brutalist building complex was a lot of fun to play around outside.

Excellent museum. Excellent museum looking at the fascinating Edo Period. There are life size structures/buildings and the exhibits have English translation albeit in limited form but this did not detract from my overall enjoyment. A well thought out museum and I would highly recommend a visit.

A Must See Museum About Tokyo. This Museum gave us a better understanding of the beginnings of old Tokyo. The dioramas were excellent and the English descriptions well written. I only wish more temples and shrines in Japan would do the same. There are several great restaurants in the upper floors above the museum with typical noodle dishes for a relaxing lunch with views from the spacious windows.

History of Tokyo in an Interesting Way. The museum is quite large and has a lot to see. It shows the history of Tokyo (former Edo) through various expositions and artifacts, including some live size buildings. Interesting sight if you're into history of Japan.

Allow plenty of time. This is a fantastic museum, divided into two sections: Edo and Tokyo, and both are fascinating. There are full size replicas of some buildings, and a number of incredibly detailed models. There are a number of 'hands-on' opportunities. We didn't have a guide, but the signage is very clear. We stopped half way through, between Edo and Tokyo, for lunch in the café. There's so much to see; leave plenty of time!

Cool for history. Great Museum if you like to know the cultural history behind Tokyo. There are free tour guides available in English, but we arrived late so the tours had already ended. I think the last tour might be 3:30 or 4pm. Check the website. Lots of exhibits and models with English translation to read. Metro is really close by and you can't miss the museum (unless you are facing the wrong direction) so its pretty easy to get to.We got there after watching sumo wrestling next door and had adequate time to walk through the museum at a comfortable pace. If you have a post secondary student ID that still looks recent, bring it! It offers a discount on admission price.

excellent museum - highly recommended. an interesting museum of the past housed in a very modern building. the museum offers free English guides......was pleasantly surprised to find that our guide was a lovely human guide and not an audio guide! we were allowed backstage of the kabuki theater because we were with this guide and encouraged to try out the instruments used in kabuki plays.there are a few exhibits here that you can climb on (rickshaw) or carry.(heavy coin box, leader's flag). the model displays were very detailed and interesting.one of the best museums we have visited.we spent about three hours here before tearing ourselves away......well worth the entry fee.

A do not miss stop in Tokyo. The Edo Museum in Tokyo is not to be missed. This is a huge museum. Plan on spending at least three-to-four hours minimum and wear comfortable shoes. Please take advantage of the free guides they offer. Our guide was outstanding, extremely knowledgeable and spoke English very well. Focus of this museum is the history of Edo & Tokyo area and culture. Self paced, easy going and highly enjoyable.

Understanding the last 200 years. There are very few examples left in Tokyo of the "Old Japan" but if you want to get a good understanding of the cultural journey Japan has been on in the last 150 years then the Edo Museum is well worth a couple of hours of your time. Fascinating artifacts, models and restored buildings all under a cavernous space, Plenty of seating to rest your weary legs, metro station nearby or walk back up the river path to Asakusa and the Kanimari Gate. Signs are in English so its easy to understand the story.

Now I understand Japan better. This is our first visit to Japan and after the visit to this museum I have a better understanding of the Edo, Meiji and Industrial periodes. The exhibitions explain the developement of Japan very well. It may not be very complete but well worth the visit.The audio-guides were very usefull.The lunch on the seventh floor was an experience with a great view of Tokyo.

A must see to appreciate Japan and it's culture. A worthwhile visit and must do if you in the area or a new visitor to Japan like I was. Explains the history and culture of this fascinating land. Beautiful displays and interactive items. They have an excellent section on the recovery from the tsunami as well that leaves you humbled as to the strenght of this country and it's inhabitants.

THE CHANGING TIMES OF TOKYO. WE were taken to the museum by Japanese friends and found it very informative. We went after a lovely tempura lunch in a place near the station and the line of people waiting to get tickets into the museum was very long but the ticket sellers were pretty efficient and soon got us in. I was even able to use my Australian pension card to get the concession price which was very nice.We elected to have an English speaking guide and that was well worth while , she explained the history and changing times of Tokyo very well. They have some marvellous exhibitions. It shows the change from the Eddo era to the Meiji era which was the end of the Samurai times then the modernization of Japan. There are some old transport items there like bicycles and carts which you can sit on, good for a photo. We then visited another section of the museum where they had an excellent exhibition of Ukiyoe Art. This is an ancient art form that has been done in Japan for centuries . Beautifull work some of it very old and extremely valuable. The exhibition had been put together from Museums and private collectors from around the world. There were literally thousands of people filing slowly past these great works of art. There was a shop there where you can buy copies of most items. A interesting place to see some history of Tokyo and how it has changed from era to era, well worth a visit.

Top 10 attraction. Excellent museum with informative displays, life size repro buildings and fantastic model towns. Interactive and really interesting museum that is a must visit, especially if on a short visit to Tokyo.

Check the special exhibitions. We visited the museum to see a special exhibition of Japanese prints and it was excellent. Special exhibitions change about every two months. Information about them is on the museum's English website.The permanent collection is an introduction to Tokyo's history, growth, and change.Ryogoku station and the sumo station are right next to the museum. If you visit during a sumo tournament it might be a little crowded around the station.

an excellent and fascinating museum. We had a guided group visit but as we prefer studying exhibits at our own speed we rejoined our guide at set time for coach. Each floor held its own fascination and flowed well in terms of narrative of epochs and their clothes architecture and uniforms etc. It gave us a unique insight into the Edo period which had its own culture and customs. The models of city quarters are brilliantly made and the models of warriors etc extremely lifelike. It was lovely to see the many schoolkids and students lap up the history. Do not go on own unless you speak Japanese as curators and people in coffee bar and shop speak little or no English

Excellent museum of Tokyo History. Many of the exhibits had English language signs. The museum tells the full history of Tokyo form small ancient town to modern day. I particularly liked some of the WWII exhibits including the "Instrument of Surrender" that ended WWII. It was great to see a copy of this historic document in person. I highly recommend this to any tourist who is visiting Tokyo for the first time.

Well presented but not outstanding. The museum's main space is a huge room with various exhibits positioned around it. These vary from full scale reproductions of buildings and the Nihonbashi bridge, to swords and dioramas. There are English descriptions but they are often only a few words where the Japanese text is much longer, so you can't help but feel that you're missing out a bit. Also we visited at the same time as some school groups which was incredibly annoying. Japan doesn't seem to discipline school kids at all so they just run around screaming.I'm not sure I'd recommend this museum, it's quite out of the way and I think of only superficial interest to those who don't read Japanese or have a grasp of Japanese history.

Japanese history has some holes. Beautiful building and intelligent design.Too little about the reasons why Japan went to war with the Russians at the turn of the century and then the Chinese and thenWorld War 2 . The whole culture of not losing face seems to permeate their teaching of history.Japanese children must grow up being absolutely dumbfounded at the reaction to their history because they are not taught about the whys ..just the bare skiiming over of the facts .

Nice presentation of the fascinating history of Tokyo city. I enjoyed this museum and as other reviewers have said it is refreshingly different from the standard museum. I'd recommend non-Japanese visitors take advantage of the English speaking volunteer guides who will take you around the museum for free!The models they have built of life in Tokyo at various times in history are simply amazing with incredible attention to detail, lots of moving parts and surprises,

Good museum - except WWII (Pacfic War) exhibit disappointing. As other reviewers have stated, the museum provides an excellent overview of the history of Edo and Tokyo including extensive artifacts, models and other descriptive materials. Very good English signs and both guides and audio-self guides are available.I was disappointed with the WWII/Pacific War exhibit however. They had a detailed depiction of the bombing and of destruction of Tokyo which was a horrifying event. However, there was a complete lack of context for why this happened. It was presented as if the Americans just decided to show-up and destroy their capital. Nothing was mentioned about Pearl Harbor and that Japan started a war of aggression first against China and then a sneak attack on the US. Nothing was mentioned of atrocities committed by Japan against Chinese civilians and US service men and women. I'm sure many school children visiting this museum will get a very distorted view of history which is quite disappointing for an institution like this. There was also very little on occupation and reconstruction and I don't think MacArthur was mentioned once.
