It would be great if they readdress this aspect of their history a bit more before the 2020 Olympics.Anyway, it's definitely worth a few hours while in Tokyo.

Wonderful. The way the museum is structured is an excellent one, to give a nice idea of how was the Edo era when compared to Tokyo. It is quite surprising to see that all the ancient details are preserved so long. The English guide who accompanied us did a very good job.

Not just a rainy day attraction. The Edo -Tokyo museum offers a refreshing change to most museums that seem to be rainy day attractions that one would otherwise avoid. This is one that you'll want to visit for its own sake. The exhibits area fascinating- and depict life in Tokyo (Edo) across the centuries from early feudal to modern times. The scale and detail of the recreations is impressive; from a partially rebuild Nihonbashi bridge inside the main museum, to incredibly detailed models of street scenes, castles and compounds. The special exhibits change regularly; we were lucky enough to see an exhibition of woodcut prints, including those done by Hiroshige (including his famous Views of Mount Fuji series). A must see on the list of things to do in Tokyo.

Interesting museum. Very interesting museum detailing the whole history of the city of Tokyo (formally know as Edo), especially fascinating given that Tokyo is the most populous city in the world!The museum is well designed and as been split into two major sections, Edo and Tokyo, which is essentially 'traditional' and 'modern' Tokyo. English explanations are dotted around the museum and it generally contains excellent models and a few unique artefacts, including some from the Tokyo 1964 Olympic games and the Japanese Instrument of Surrender.Admission to the permanent exhibition is ¥600 (Jan 14) with additional fees for special exhibitions. Approximately 5 minute walk from the Ryogoku metro station.

Tokyo's 400-year ascent from fishing villiage to megalopolis. We were greeted by a kind volunteer guide named Mariko, who guided us through the entire museum.The dioramas, models and artifacts were all exquisite. They really transported you back to the Edo period.You also learn how Tokyo evolved over the centuries, and the critical role of the Nihonbashi bridge. This massive, open structure also houses a full Kabuki theater, and explorations of block painting and other traditional Japanese crafts.If you're interested in the history of cities, or in Tokyo, this is a must-visit!

Nice Museum. Nice museum with many exhibitions from old Tokyo with a lot of writings to learn from. Interesting to the clothing from back in the days and the houses and transportation means. A few hours and you have covered about everything unless you want to read everything. The museum is situated just next to the sumo stadium. Very nice lunch restaurant at the top of the building that serves excellent Bento boxes and has a beautiful view of Tokyo.

Very Nice Museum Showcasing History of Tokyo area. Nice museum to spend about two hours. If you go to the Sumo tournament, this is a good thing to do before the tournament gets really started in the mid-afternoon. Or it is something you can do to take a break from the tournament, as it is right next to the stadium. There are many displays of different things, including art, sculptures, models, uniforms, silk screens and much more. It has things from many different time periods including Edo, Meiji and World War II era.Big enough museum for kids to walk around and strollers are no problem here either. The admission is very cheap, about 600 yen per adult and young kids are free.

Great museum. Nice experience and learning opportunity for those that wants to understand more about Edo(old Tokyo) Not particularly crowded and good signage to guide your walk. It was a highlight of my short tripConveniently located next to Ryogoku station. Sumo arena and museum just next door if you are keen

Edo Tokyo Museum 12/2013. very interesting museum about the history and life from the time Tokyo got japanese capital, over 2nd world war destruction until recent times. All displays are niceliy set up and also in english language. there are also interactive displays and games for children to learn history while playing, will come back next time

Interesting. A spaceship building, with excellent models of Tokyo from earlier times. Good for kids and adults. Go early to avoid the tourist buses. Ideal to combine with sumo at the stadium at the back. Sumo is on 6 times per year.

A different exhibition in a different building. You will spot the Edo-Tokyo Museum as a building with a different exterior than most buildings. It is actually standing on 4 high columns, on top of which the actual rests.With a peculiar exterior the exhibition inside is also a little bit different, at least from exhibitions I'm used to. There is a few, what feels like full-sized buildings, inside the museum building itself. There is also a Japanese wooden bridge inside. Except these stranger things there is also a lot of other historical objects on display from the history of Tokyo, formerly known as Edo. You get a good sense of the history although as usual much information is in Japanese.This museum with its peculiarities is of course worth the visit. From here you could walk either to the Sky Tree or to Asakusa.
A bit of history. Very good presentation of the transition from the Edo period to modern Tokyo. The city models are very detailed and informative.

Good introduction to Tokyo history. Very nice museum housed in an interesting building. It gives a good impression of Edo and its enormous transformation into the modern city of Tokyo. Some horrifying descriptions of the effects of American bombing during WW2, but interestingly little about the causes of the war. It is hard to follow the exhibits without the audioguide that we used. Alternatively there are live volunteer guides (free) who will help you.

Ukiyo-e: A Journey Through the Floating World. Until March 2,2014, Edo-Tokyo Museum is hosting its 20th Anniversary Special Exhibition of the opening of the museum with the best of Ukiyo-e (woodcut prints and paintings flourished in Japan in the 17-19th centuries). Also, its Second Special Exhibits room (in the permanent gallery) is showing until 2nd February the 53 Stations of Tokaido of Utagawa Hiroshige, all of them (except a couple which is presented at the Special Exhibition Room).Many of the very best examples are shown. Very impressive.It's a special occasion, so if you come to Tokyo, don't miss it.

Tokyo through the ages. As a visitor to Tokyo, it's often overlooked how dramatic its transformation has been from swamplands to a bustling metropolis. As Japan's most cosmopolitan city, this transformation is laid out really well in the Edo-Tokyo Museum. We decided to go here on a whim after visiting Asakusa / Tokyo Sky Tree. It's about a 25 minute walk from there.The building itself is interesting architecturally, apparently modelled after a storehouse. The exhibits range from intricate dioramas to large replicas of historic buildings and bridges. More interestingly, you get a great sense of what Tokyo was like during the Edo period, and incredibly, how many times Tokyo has been rebuilt. I'd recommend getting the audio guide. It's free with a deposit. You'll need at least half a day to see everything. The restaurant we went to is definitely a pass.

Excellent volunteer guides. I was lucky to be given a private tour of the museum by one of the volunteer guides, Mr. Kunio Sanui. He is a superb storyteller with excellent English and impressive knowledge of history. I think this was the best history and culture lesson I've ever had!
Excellent museum with the right guide. We could see Japan history beautifully represented, the old and the new. The edo period the modern time and tokyo through world war II. Intersting and teaching

Really nice. It's really big museum we were there for 2 and a half hours and it's really amazing everything is written in English too and if you are interested in Japan history this is a place you must visit :-)

Excellent. I really love history, so this place was a must see I stayed in Shiodome so an easy Station to Station trip, traveling on the Tokyo Subway is cool, be careful with the ticketing thoughThe Museum is just around the corner from the Ryogoku station and well signposted When you walk in, for me the size and scope, was Wow!!Not busy so got a Volunteer Guide to show me around, her English was quaint and she was totally sweet, her love and pride for the Museum was very apparent, a pleasant hour or soProbably not necessary but as not much English on the labels, it made the visit more enjoyable , The bridge was cool, especially underneathThe Theatre was a must, the actor on the day was a riot, my Japanese is tourist only but his performance was so funny it transcended language The life in the city exhibits were informative and well presented, especially the infrastructure bitsI could rattle on, but I won'tIf you are interested in history, go
Free half-a -day trip!. On October 1st the entrance is free for everyone because of the holiday. I will take about 1-2 hours to see everything.

Fascinating historical view of Tokyo. The museum is easily accessible via public transportation. It is housed in an interesting futuristic building. We took a break from touring the museum to have tasty lunch in one of the three (or more?) Restaurants within the complex. We only visited the permanent collection of artifacts and dioramas related to the history of Tokyo. My wife and I were fascinated by the manuscripts, textiles, weapons and other items which have survived and been preserved through the centuries. Dioramas were used to illustrate the architecture, clothing and lifestyle of the various classes of citizens of ancient Edo period. The dioramas and supporting items also illustrate the growth of the city through its early life. A guide was not immediately available when we arrived but that did not interfere with our enjoyment of the museum. Many of the exhibits had descriptions in English as well as Japanese. The museum is very engaging visually but has only a few interactive exhibits. It would not be of interest or suitable for younger children. It has several small gift shops.

Very informative history of Tokyo. Simple, but very visual permanent exhibition. There are volunteer guides available in English, and on the day I visited there were guides in German and French. When I stopped by the desk no other tourists were there, so I got a personal guide who talked nonstop for 2 hours. Without guide it wouldn't be the same. I think it's a perfect way to learn and understand Tokyo's history. If you travel with kids it's a must.

Excellent history of Tokyo in English. This is a well displayed museum of the history of Tokyo with English descriptions for the exhibits, though there are also guides available who will shown you around without charge. Some of the exhibits are a little simplistic, more oriented towards kids, but there's plenty for both adults and children. It doesn't take more than 1-2 hours to go through the main places of interest, though you can get more out of it if you take more time, and I'd say it's very appropriate for families.

A museum in which you can learn history and culture of Edo-Tokyo. In a rainy day it was a good idea to visit the Edo-Tokyo Museum. It is a very large modern building, spread on 7 floors, with permanent exhibitions, special exhibits, library and many cafe and restaurants.The museum has a variety of reference materials and reconstruction models showing the life and culture of Edo and Tokyo.The voluntary guides do their best to explain the history of Japan at that time.

A must see in Tokyo, if like understanding the city you are visiting. This Museum gives a very good overview of the transition of Tokyo from Edo period to a modern city.It has a considerable number of objects and models that gives a clear picture of how was life in past years in this amazing city. It is some how interactive as well, with some equipments, old transportation means...that you can even try.It is quite rich on information and quite big. So it is advisable to reserve time to see the museum properly.

Ok if you have time on your hands. The overall experience would have been meaningful if museum guides were many. At the time of our visit, there was only one. A small group of Dutch women were lucky enough to enjoy the services of the volunteer guide. Anyway, the place is huge and it going to take you several hours to cover everything. I love that there are parts where its "interactive" that you can actually be in a traditional Japanese house and free to roam about inside. If you are only in Tokyo for a few days, and not exactly into history, well, this can be missed.

An Excellent Overview of Tokyo History. The museum covers the time period from the shogun time, to the Meiji Restoration, through World War II, followed by the postwar years. Admission very reasonable - something like 6 dollars or so and maybe even less for seniors. If you're lucky, you can even snag an English guide (like I did) but generally, you have to reserve them in advance. I highly recommend for all you history buffs out there.

History of Tokyo. I was very lucky to visit this museum on citizens day since it was free entrance. I took the subway which stopped about a block or so away. The dioramas of life in the edo period are done very nicely. There are hands on activities to experience that are great for kids as well as adults. It took about an hour and a half to see but could take longer. There are nice gift shops. the one on the bottom floor takes credit cards.
A must-see.. The main exhibition chronicles Tokyo's transition from an Edo period city to a modern metropolis. There is live entertainment and a top-notch gift shop.

As the name suggests, about Edo... We heard that this is a wonderful Museum displaying the history of Tokyo through models, photographs and original artefacts from old Edo days. It is easy to reach via the subway, just next to the Sumo stadium.We paid the normal fee of 600 Yen and started the tour by taking the lift to L6. They also have free volunteer guided tours, available in English and other languages (just inquire about their availability at the ticketing counter or at the 6th floor). Once enter visitors will walk along the large-scale reconstructed replica of Nihonbashi bridge. 日本橋. The museum provides, in a fairly compact space, a hands-on introduction to "Edo" as the capitol was during the Meiji era. It features mainly reconstructed miniature models of Edo castles and surrounding residential quarters of Tokyo. There are also artefacts from the period and some interactive displays. In all it illuminates a great deal about Japanese life and customs - not just the city. Exhibits include replicas of an ancient Kabuki theatre and the Edo screens is a real visual treat!In addition to the permanent exhibition, special exhibitions are held periodically. During our trip they were having the Katsushika Hokusai (葛飾 北斎?) paintings exhibitions. Hokusai is best known as author of the woodblock print series 36 Views of Mount Fuji (富嶽三十六景 Fugaku Sanjūroku-kei) which includes the internationally recognized print, The Great Wave off Kanagawa, created during the 1820s.Our visit took just under 3 hours. However I find that the signage/explanation in English is still not too sufficient, though audio guides are available. Before parting we ate at the small cafe (good udon noodles) at L1. There’s also a few museum souvenir shops which sells good traditional craft, T-shirts and cutie collectibles. A good grab for interesting-theme shorts that is not available elsewhere. :>A Bonus - one can also make a short detour to the Ryogoku Sumo museum just about 10 minutes from the museum.

One of the best museums in Tokyo! Must Visit!. There is a lot to see, try (with your hands), and enjoy in this museum. Many models are very detailed and carefully made so that they tell stories very good (even though most of the time you don't know what they are from reading the explanation, .... because they are mostly in Japanese!) The artifacts are either carefully made to duplicate the original one or the original one itself. There are English speaking guides available but I haven't tried them. This is an enjoyable museum for all ages and genders, one of the best I've ever visited.
Average. An ordinary museum in a fascinating building. I found the building structure more interesting than the museum itself but if history is your interest its worth a look.

Decent museum. We are a family with a 5 and 8 year old who love museums. This museum was fine to visit. We arrived 2 hours before close so didn't have a volunteer tour guide to assist us and didn't use the audio tour. The signs had enough English that we could understand most of what we saw. The kids liked that the place had a lot of space to run around, some items to touch and try out and interesting life size models to see. My husband and I enjoyed learning about how Tokyo was formed and what hardships it went through. We only got 3 days in the city and I think spending some time here to better understand the city was worth it. Small fee of 600 adults to enter.

Tokyo Edo Museum-a must do. I love taking people who vist me to this museum. I am never dissapointed. It is all about the history of Tokyo. This time we had a free guide who escorted us through the museum, and pointed out things we would not have known, and also added personal stories. A heads-up, please tell your guide how much time you have to visit the museum, as we had to tell her when we were there for 2 hours that we had to be somewhere else. There is a wonderful gift shop, and the restaurant on the top floor has Japanese food-actually quite good. It is also fun to stroll the neighborhood, as you often see a sumo wrestlers. I also swing into the Sumo stadium to show them that museum and they have a sumo-themed gift shop.

A cool place to kill an hour or so.. This museum was ok. It had some cool stuff, but being the "Edo" or "new era" museum, it did not have a lot of the cool old artifacts that I was hoping to see, such as samurai swords and armor. There were definitely some cool things in there, but most of it was from fairly recent history. It looks like the do some performances there, also, which may be cool, but i did not see them, so I cannot really comment on that.

Not as interesting as the city. I got a better taste of the culture by running around the old temples and shrines interspersed throughout the city, it was a history museum that would probably appeal to families or students.

The whole view of Japan’s history.. Felt like living in the past of Japan. With the fee just was 600 Yen and an english speaking guide. A lot of things about the history of Edo – Tokyo were appeared in front of your eyes, reality and lively.Beside that, you should try to catch a traditional music in the old Japanese theater. It sound great, right?Just check it out!!!

Tokyo 101. To fully appreciate a great city one needs to know something of its history, this is the perfect place to start when visiting Tokyo! This museum covers the history of Tokyo (Edo) from approximately 1600- to post war reconstruction and does so in an interesting and entertaining way. There are a number of scale models, dioramas and hands-on activities that keep even young children from getting too bored. (however, this is not a children's museum)The museum is fairly large, even if you are not that into history it is good to allow at least a few hours to go through the whole place. There is adequate signage in English, but you are better off getting an audio-guide to fully appreciate what you are seeing. There are also volunteer guides available if you want a more personal tour. These guides are available in a number of languages including French, German, Spanish, Russian, Chinese and Korean (besides Japanese and English) but for many of these languages you need to reserve in advance so check their website. The audio guide is free and requires no reservation, just get one on either the 1st or 3rd floor information counters (must give a refundable 1000 yen deposit) These are only in Japanese, Korean, Chinese and English so plan ahead if these languages don't work for you.The main permanent exhibits are on the 5th and 6th floors, if you start on the 6th floor and work your way down to the 5th, going from the "Edo-zone" to the "Tokyo-zone", you will follow things in chronological order. The other reviewers and photos posted basically tell you what you need to know

Fascinating. Tons of cool historical exhibits from different era's in the Tokyo area (previously Edo). Took longer than expected, so be prepared to spend more than a few hours there. We went back twice, once for the main exhibit and once for the special exhibit, but still did not see all we wanted to. By the end we were rushing through because we had to meet others at a specific time. Basically make sure you give yourself a full day (open-close) to see everything at a leisurely pace.Favourite exhibit was the WW2 exhibit, very detailed and full of information. Full of thought provoking reading material, I did not realize a few things before I went to the museum that I know now.All in all, go. If your going to visit a couple of museums make sure this is one of them.

One of the Best Museums I Have Ever Visited. If you are a museum person and typically put such visits at the top of your agenda when you travel, this place should be your first stop in Tokyo. I put this facility in the top 10 museums I have ever visited. This is partly because I tend to be a history buff but also because this place is so well done. This museum presents the chronology of the city of Tokyo and, somewhat by default, the nation of Japan as a whole. It is superbly presented. I have visited this museum three times. The first time was on my own and the second was with my family when we brought them to Tokyo. This most recent visit was with four colleagues who had never been here. This occasion was a little different as it was the first time I used one of the free volunteer guides. This gave the experience a wholly worthwhile added dimension. Having a native interpretation that gave information not available on the placards was invaluable. Beyond this, however, the displays in this museum were top notch. Upon entering, the replica of the old Nihonbashi bridge greets you with an invitation you cannot refuse. The Kabuki theater re-creation below the bridge also is impressive to view. The three dimensional miniatures showing various aspects of Old Tokyo are worth studying. Various areas of the museum are dedicated to different eras of Tokyo. The display on the war years was particularly fascinating to me. I would highly recommend this museum to anyone wanting to learn more about the history of this fascinating city. Take half a day to experience this gem!

History of Tokyo. It's an interesting museum that would take you through the ancient years of Tokyo: from Edo era until WWII. There are miniature models, maps, objects, etc. The limited English description is enough for you to understand the history of Tokyo. It's worth the visit if you are into history..

volunteer guide at museum. My family and I were in Japan just over a month ago. We visited the Edo-Tokyo Museum while there. We didn't have any reservations for the English guide; we just simply walked up to the volunteer guide desk and asked if anyone was available. A lady guide took us around the museum, explaining the displays to us, and even conversing with us about other things. She was probably the only person in Japan that gave us a little insight to everyday, normal life in Japan. The tour took about 11/2 hours. Very enjoyable.

Nice introduction. We are in Tokyo with four adult children (23-28 years old) and I'd read all the great reviews about the Edo-Tokyo Museum. I agree that it is a good place to learn about Tokyo, but I wasn't as thrilled as the other travelers. The miniature models were great, and the explanation of history was good. There were enough signs in English to understand. The display on WWII was poignant, sad. Seeing the destruction caused by the fire bombing was, well, a good reminder of the horrors of war. Overall a good introduction to Tokyo. Right next door to the Sumo stadium.

Perfect place to know about Tokyo and Japanese history. The museum introduces the history of Tokyo and Japan by Diorama, full-size model and many unique installations. It's easy to understand and very interesting!

A good view to japanese history. It's a nice and beautiful experience the visit to Edo Tokio museum, Why? Because you will learn the japanese history in a beautiful place, full of colors and details but most of it is because you can be guided by an old japanese person, retired people, who works in the museum and explain to the turist the history of their country. Is a very good visit, you must do it if you are in Tokio, dont you even hesitate...

Best possible introduction to Tokyo. We went there first 6 years ago, and this time took our teenage kids to it as a first introduction to Tokyo and Japan. Great choice as they marvelled the broad range of aspects, explanation given and the excellent display of this city's development. Especially the second part, the transformation from a local powerhouse to the modern capital is striking. It is almost as well done as the Singapore National Museum.

Getting to know Samurai- Shogun-even Sushi!. Whether you are a history buff or not. This museum is definitely worthwhile to go! The museum is huge and filled with replicas of the Edo era, fyi Edo is what tokyo is called in the olden days :p Here are some tips: 1. First thing first, get your tickets at the lobby- it's only 600 yen per person- so cheap!2. There are 2 options for non-japanese speaker, either rent an audio electronic guide next to the ticket counter for free (deposit of 1000yen) or I ---Highly--- recommend getting a volunteer english guide on level 6. They are so professional, they will tell you the history of edo-tokyo (all about samurai and shoguns) while guiding you around the museum, they can answer all of your questions and... its free of charge too! I find this service amazing!3. Take lots of photos on the 5th floor with the olden days bicycles- its so cute. 4. Just enjoy your time at the museum, browse thru the collections slowly. 5. They also have two japanese cafes that serves traditional bentos one on the top floor and the other on the bottom floor. Just a couple of hours at the museum really broadened my knowledge about the history of Tokyo, the temples, the shogun and samurai Era, even.... why do japanese like sushi so much! :)
A superb museum. Very interesting, colourful display of Tokyo's history! Very interactive and captions are in English too.

Get your audio guide before going up!. The building is gorgeous, both on the outside and inside. You go up to the top floor after buying your ticket, and the lift take you up into an enormous, open room with a life-size replica of a Kabuki theater and the Nihonbashi, the bridge that lead into Tokyo. There are models of Edo-era streets that will blow your mind with the level of detail. One had over 10 000 models of people, each with different expressions. The information is interesting, but the museum is enormous. It'll take you several hours to go through it all if you have the guide. They are handed out on the first floor, which you can easily miss if you take the lift from outside. Circle around before going in.

Amazing Museum. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Tokyo. It is a fantastic museum especially if you have young children. It has many interactive features and the kids have multiple opportunities to experience what life was in that time. Not to be missed.

Amazing History Museum. This museum tells the history of Tokyo by putting it in the context of it's times. The exhibitions are nothing short of magificent. Each exhibit includes many different kinds of presentations, artifacts, life-sized displays, maps, etc. The museum really goes out of it's way to bring each period in Tokyo to life in the mind of the viewer. Each part explains everything in detail, from what the daily life of Samurai retainer was like, to the economy of the Edo Period, to how the city changed during the Meiji Restoration, to the daily life of a family in the 1920/30s and so on. '

Interesting display of history. I dont much go for mueseums but this was an interesting one worth the 600 yens entrance fee. The building itself is really sci-fi like with its huge monumental structure. Inside there are really great replicas, maketts of japanese stuff in all sizes from small to large. You can take flash photos almost very exhibition item and go in a traditional japanese home.

Excellent museum!. Even for people who don’t like museums, Edo-Tokyo is definitely worth a two to three hour visit. Its great visual displays bring history to life. If possible, see this museum early in your Tokyo visit because it puts Edo-Tokyo history in perspective and gives you a greater appreciation for what you will see in Tokyo and other areas of Japan. Take advantage of the free English speaking guides available. Guides give you an hour or so overview of the exhibits including interesting historical and cultural details on several of them. When the guided tour is done, you can revisit the exhibits you want to study more in depth. We learned so much and the interaction with our guide was very enjoyable. Edo-Tokyo is a first class museum for a bargain admission price of 600 yen.

A visual treat!. Fantastic! However a lot of information is in Japanese without translation. If you want more than just looking, then get an audio guide WHEN YOU GET YOUR TICKET. Even if you don't end up using it. I regret not getting one and remain curious about so much :( I went back but the ticket line is much too long. Otherwise cheap, interesting, well laid out, comfortable sitting places, restaraunts, replicas you can touch/go inside & very visually stimulating.

spectacular museum. An amazing museum in a dazzling modern building. It spans the era from the time when there was only a marsh, through the history of all Edo and then Tokyo, and basically ends with the 1964 Tokyo Olympics.What I liked most was that this was not focused only on the life of the mighty and aristocrats but showed how the little people (us) lived. And it is large but not overwhelming. In 2-3 hours you can cover nearly all of it. One of the best museums I have ever seen.

Very Amusing. The museum is excellent in every aspect. It is very close to Ryogoku Station and Kokugikan Sumo Stadium. Admission fee is only 600 yen and many English guides are available for free. Besides there are some great dioramas and hands-on experience items and so much fun! Actually, I don't like museums very much, but this one is an exception. I can recommend this museum to any visitors to Tokyo.

Tokyo National Museum is better. Tip: student discount.Cons: very info in English. And the guides have a very poor English.Lonely Planet listed this museum as one of the most interesting things to do in Tokyo which I feel that is unfair.The museum doesn't have info in English. Instead of this one I would recommend the Tokyo National Museum. I really loved it.

Best Museum in Tokyo. Not to be missed. Easy to access from the station and right next to the Sumo stadium for a combination trip. It holds a great collection of models and artifacts showcasing the development of the city. Plenty of things to touch and you can get inside buildings and vehicles for photo opportunities unlike many 'hands off' museums. A decent gift shop too.

If you were interested enough to read the reviews, you should go. Once you read a few of these reviews, you get the idea... this is a first class museum. The exhibits are excellent. You will probably spend more time here than you expected. Go here early in your visit to Tokyo. You can go to the Tokyo National Museum later. This is not an art museum. It is a history museum. It will enrich the rest of your visit to Tokyo. This was my second trip to Tokyo and I don't know how I missed it on my first visit.The building itself is really cool. From the outside it looks like an Imperial Cruiser from Star Wars. The best place to get your tickets is on the open air third floor. Here is where you can also get an audio guide. If you don't go with one of the free volunteer English speaking guides, get the audio tour. The escalators will take you up then to the actual museum on Level 5 & 6.

Insight to Tokyo life during time of the Shoguns. Free English speaking guide very knowledgable and added a great deal of value to the experience.Liked - authentic artefacts from Edo period and to scale Edo bridge replica.

Great introduction to Tokyo's history. I think this is one of the 'must-sees' in Tokyo as it explains the history of Tokyo through models, maps, replica rooms/houses etc. Well presented and most of the exhibits have an English explanation. It's easy to get to by subway and you come up in the lift from the station and are outside the museum. Neat touch: numbered racks to leave your umbrella outside!

Tokyo History, Excellent Museum. The Edo-Tokyo Museum is a must do. See it before you do anything else in Tokyo. The museum presents a panorama of Tokyo history through maps, dioramas, models, and replicas of buildings. It really provides a context for touring Tokyo. The best thing about the museum are the free volunteer guides. My guide spent about an hour leading me through the exhibits, discussing the history and perspectives of the people. At the center of the museum there is a reproduction of the original Nihombashi bridge and a reproduction of a Kabuki theater. You'll learn a lot about the Japanese and the evolution of Edo-Tokyo.

A Journey in Time. Very well-done, this museum starts with a full scale reproduction of the Nihonbashi, a 17th century Tokyo bridge which brings you to the fascinating world of Edo. Many interesting exhibits and the café has wonderful "bento" lunch-boxes. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit there.

A museum worth visiting. Huge museum showcasing Tokyo's history. I explored the 5th and 6th floors which are connected warehouse style. Has many models complemented by interactive exhibits including a pallaquin which was popular for photos. Also had a kibuki theater with several mini-shows. Was a fun afternoon and could have spent more time there.

I don't like museums - But this one was good!. It felt good on our very short trip to Japan to visit one museum and this was a great choice. Its a general history museum with interactive exhibits. You do need to read the plaques to get a good understanding of what is being displayed. The Kabuki theatre inside the museum puts on performances too so its almost like a one stop cultural and history stop in Tokyo. It was also great to see war history from the Japanese perspective. It really dosent take long to get through the exhibits - if you dedicate about 2-3 hours you will see everything. The admission fee was cheap too... about AUD$6 I think for an adult. We did this museum on the way back from the fish markets because it was still quite cold.

The first stop in Tokyo. I found this museum after 3 days in Tokyo and it should have been at the top of the list. An excellent museum for all travelers, kid friendly and mother approved! The history of Edo -Tokyo, interactive exhibits, accessible English language translations and special exhibits make this a must do. The small restaurant attached to the museum, Finns, had good choices and was decently priced.

A true must do.. The museum was easy to find and upon entering the architecture is breathtaking. Tickets are very reasonable at 600ypp or 480y for students. When we got inside we noticed that there was a booth for free tours from volunteers. You can book it in advance, but we just showed up and were able to get an english speaking guide all to ourselves. The museum was very well done with full size reconstructions of historical theaters and other buildings. It also had an extensive collection of miniature models of certain parts of Tokyo at different points throughout history. The miniatures were extremely detailed, for example one miniature of a village had over a thousand figurines of villagers all based on actual photos from that village. They were so detailed that binoculars are provided by all the miniatures for you to zoom in even more. Truly a great way to spend a morning.

Lots of Histrty from Edo Period. You can see scale models of life from the Edo Period, a replica bridge from the time period, You can also see how Japan looked like right after the Edo period. I was not expecting this stop but I am glad I did go!! Self Audio tours are available. JR train stops near by. right next to Sumo Arena

Fantastic place!. Loved the museum! The exhibits on the 6th floor are amazing and scale models are stunning! We spent there 3 hours and didint realize how quick time went. A free volunteer guide is a must in my oppinion. Ours was very funny and we got to get inside the kabuki theater. Highly recomend

Take a guided tour!. My guide made the trip to the museum alot more interesting, and had all sorts of answers to any questions we threw at him. The woodblock prints of Mt Fuji were amazing. I just wish they had an english brochure so I could read about the pictures.

Worth to visit museum. It's Japanese.. So means very detail museum.. Spending day here it's like downloading Wikipedia to your head! The replicas were very detail! I still wondering why the lady in ticket counters we don't have to pay entrance fee hence it's mentioned the fee is ¥600 for permanent exhibition.. Maybe we were more than lucky.. Free entrance for a very top quality museum... Don't forget to ask translator if you want to have a tour inside.

Excellent Place to Visit. This was an excellent visit. The museum provides a great insight into Japanese history in a fascinating building and using a layout that re-creates the feel of the Edo period. Good value too.

Entering this museum over the replica of the original wooden, arched Edo bridge is an exceptional introduction. During the 17th century the original Edo Bridge was a terminus of the Nakasendo Road through the mountains between Edo and Kyoto. Subsequently the wooden bridge was replaced by a stone bridge, which still stands today, though now lost in the midst of the Tokyo big city concrete structures around it. Traditionally, all distances in Japan are measured from the centerpoint of the Nihonbashi Bridge, this custom began in the Edo Period; road signs showing the distance to Tokyo actually state the number of kilometres to Nihonbashi.The museum is photo and explore friendly with directional signs incorporated in the carpet which is helpful to avoid missing exhibits in such a large place. The exhibits both full size and miniature are meticulously presented; hours can be spent in both learning and admiring the craftsmanship and quality of the exhibits. After leaving the Museum stroll around under the base of this huge, elevated structure to get a sense of the size of this massive building.

Outstanding Museum. I can't say I'm a huge museum fan. It's not that I don't enjoy them, but often my kids lose interest after awhile and start racing along. Not here. This museum ranks amongst the best I've ever seen for a local museum, and I highly recommend an easy trip here from most areas of the city. It's a few minutes by train from Ueno for example, and the museum is right outside the station. Depending on the season you're in Tokyo, a rainy day could hit. We had sun yesterday, and heavy drizzle all day today. So this museum makes an excellent substitution, or a nice half day in connection with other nearby areas. I didn't expect the museum to be as large and comprehensive as we found it to be. The displays and models are simply remarkable. There are plenty of items behind glass cases, which are very interesting. But the models of Edo and the recreations of houses, stores, and many other buildings really take you inside another era in grand fashion. My kids enjoyed it, and we weren't in a mad rush to get through as a result. So keep it in mind, especially if you have a bad weather day or days you'd like to mix up your sightseeing routine. I don't think you'll be disappointed, and that's from a non-museum guy!!Also as you're headed out of the station to your right there's a large restaurant, an izikaya really. We stopped there on our way back after a morning at the museum, and it was perfect for our family. Nice character, private tables, big menu and selection, and a good break before grabbing the train back to Ikebukuro. Just a thought...

Fascinating Cultural Museum. This was my second visit to the Edo Tokyo Museum and I was surprised that I enjoyed it just as much as the first visit (which was admittedly some years ago during a High School trip). We took the Oedo Subway line to the Ryogoku stop which drops you almost to the entrance of the building, which from the outside looks more like a sports stadium. The entrance fee to the permanent exhibits in the museum was ¥600 for adults - which I think is very reasonable for a Tokyo attraction. Once on the 6th floor (accessed via an elevator), before you cross the bridge there is a desk where you can ask for a volunteer tour guide.I would really recommend getting a guide as we asked so many questions and got so much insights on the exhibit items and Japanese culture/history in general. You just won't have the same experience without it. Our tour guide was so obliging, answering all questions and was obviously very passionate/knowledgeable about the subject. He even has his own website where you can refresh your memory on some of the information, along with photos of all the people he's taken for a tour through the museum. The tour takes about 1.5 hrs - and doesn't seem to matter about the size of your group whether you're a sole person or bigger group. The best thing is that the guide service is absolutely FREE! We noticed that apart from English, there were volunteer guides in languages such as French, German, Spanish, Russian, Chinese etc.If you have a spare few hours in Tokyo, have a general interest in history or traditional Japanese culture - I would recommend a visit to the Edo Tokyo Museum.

Interesting. If you have any interest in Edo era in Japan, you must go there.It's so interesting. I knew people in Tokyo(Edo) around 300-400 years ago had a great culture and cool life style. It was surprising.Not completely English friendly but you can enjoy.

Perfect experience withh a freely available volunteer guide. Anyone visiting this LOVELY museum can enjoy the free volunteer guided tours, available in English, Spanish and a couple of other languages. Inquire about availability at the ticketing counter or in the beginning of the exposition on the 6th floor.Also try to catch a traditional music & dancing performance at the replica of an old Japanese theater building - a great way to experience authentic Japanese folk customs without buying a Kabuki or No theater ticket.

Fascinating Insight into Tokyo history and culture. We spent about 3 hours here on the last day of our stay in Tokyo and it was really worthwhile. As soon as we stepped into the museum a japanese man walked up to us and offered to act as a volunteer guide, which was free of charge. We took him up on his offer and it was excellent as it was much better than walking around looking at the exhibits - much more of a personal perspective. As we were coming to the end of the tour I started to think about whether we should offer him a tip, but he said goodbye and dissappeared before we had the chance to do so - which was a relief.I would put this museum down as a must-see in Tokyo if you want to find out about history and culture. If you're not interested in this stuff, then why go to Tokyo?

Before the HighTech Japan... back to the Old Edo Era!. The Edo Tokyo Museum is definitely worth going if you are a history buff. Long before Japan became this high-tech country with automatic toilet bidet or automatic car park, here's your chance to check out the Era of Edo period. It's pretty fascinating really. There were lots of miniatures of the old neighbourhood of Tokyo. You can see ow Japanese used to dress up, what the traditional houses with futon and tatami looks like. I suggest for foreigners to sign up for a guide from the 6th floor, it's a free service and they speak many languages. Our guide was so passionate about telling us the history of Japan, about the Era with Shogun and Samurai. We learned so much in one trip. The location of the museum is perfect, just 5 minutes from Ryogoku Station and the ticket price is so cheap 600 yen. If its the right season, you can also go see a sumo match at the Ryogoku major sumo stadium about 10 minutes from the museum. *highly recommendable* I reckon this is one of the best museums in Tokyo, definitely worth to go!

Great history. I didn't know much about Tokyo before World War 2, so this museum was really interesting to me to see what the area was like before westernization. They have things you can touch and some manikins that move for a play.

Context to our time in Tokyo. Not knowing much about the history of Tokyo or the systems of government (samurai, traders etc) this was a great place to start. It took a few hours to get through, and at times felt a bit long, but of course you can go at your own pace and the headsets in English were nice to have.Definitely recommend for those who want a bit of context to their stay in Japan.

Good place to learn about the history of Tokyo. We came out of the museum knowing a lot more about Tokyo and the replica buildings were particularly impressive. It is very much look at an artifact or replica and read a description. There is very little interactive exhibits so small children (and adults) may get bored.If you are interested in history it is a thorough museum with a range of artifacts however if not i dont think its an essential destination.

Excellent historical museum. Really enjoyable visit to the permanent exhibition of Edo and Tokyo up to the 1950s. Favourite exhibits were the excellent models of Edo castle, the Edo screens and the demonstration of how woodblock multicolored prints were made. Also interesting to see c18 cartoon books (showing that Manga was nothing new) and a temporary exhibit of woodblock prints of warriors. The document of WW2 surrender by the Japanese is also on display, if in a rather understated context within the Tokyo section of the museum which also showed its development into a city and constant vigilance for earthquakes. The whole visit took about 3 hours. Enough signage in English to understand exhibits, and audioguides were also available. We ate at the small cafe ( good udon noodles ) but a wider choice of Japanese food was available on the top floor. Easy to reach via the subway, next to the Sumo stadium ( if you are fortunate enough to time your visit to see a basho).

Tokyo Edo-museum. Museum features mainly reconstructed miniature models of Edo castles and surrounding residential areas of Tokyo. There are also artefacts from the period and some interactive displays for kids. Interesting but not a must see.

A brilliant way to sepnd a morning. Ok so you cant miss this place... Its HUGE (with good reason as you will discover when you go in). The Kabuki theater is immense inside, as all the models of tokyo through the ages, and all the exhibits there. Anyone with a curious mind will enjoy the museum. The added extras of having people dressed in period costume mingling with museum attendees really makes it fun. We learnt so much there (in a fun way..) and would go againAlso - the gift shop DOWNSTAIRS is brilliant - much bigger than the one on the main museum floor. And we got some great stuff there for not a lot of Yen
Great fun! Our children recommend we go! . Our children recommend we go! So much to see. Particularly liked the bookpages and daily life displays.

Excellent Modern Museum displaying history of Tokyo. This is an Excellent Modern Museum displaying the history of Tokyo through models, photographs and original artefacts, with full explanations given in English. Visitors follow a route that broadly takes them through the chronological development of the city, but also illuminates a great deal about Japanese life and customs - not just the city. This is highly recommended as a general introduction to Japan.My only criticism is that it stops at 1964, and the massive development of Tokyo into a world city since 1945 is very much skated over.

good place to check out the history. I had an amazing guide who walked me through the entire museum and told me every detail, I loved it. they have reconstructed smaller versions of the significant structures and loads of maps of different generations of the city and how it was developed. the interesting thing was about how they used to recycle so much of their material since the early days.

Edo Heaven. If you are interested in the Edo times of Japan then you will absolutely love this museum.Let me start by saying that I am a huge samurai fan, whether it is on the Battle of Sekigahara, the Book of Five rings by Miyamoto Musashi, or anything samurai related I love it.There is definitely a lot to see and the museum even offers guided tours in English. At certain times they even have actors doing a show.I have uploaded many pictures for you to see of the museum.

Very interesting. An interesting place showcasing the history of Tokyo. Lots of the displays are scale models of the original which is a bit different to most museums.If your interested in history and the story this is a better bet than going to the tokyo museum in ueno park.

Ideal for Japanese culture and history buffs. If you have any interest in the history of Japan, then the Edo-Tokyo Museum is a must. First of all, it is a stunning building and the exhibits are extremely well laid out. The models of the ancient city and the displays are quite superb. The Samurai warrior costume is interesting as quite how they fought wearing all that clothing and armour is amazing. The group I was with only had about ninety minutes for a relatively quick look round, but you could comfortably spend a full afternoon or even a day if you really took your time wandering around.

Perfect for a rainy day!. We went to the Edo-Tokyo Museum on our first day in Toyko after visiting Asakusa Senso-ji and the Sumida River. It was raining quite heavily when we exited the Ryogoku Subway Station on the Toei Line, but the covered walkway all the way from the Station to the Museum kept us dry.The Museum itself is amazing! There are life-sized replicas of the orginal wooden Nihom-Bashi bridge and Kabuki Theatre facade, and scale models of Edo-era Tokyo with superb details - the tiny "people" in the city models all have unique facial features and clothing and poses (see photographs).There is so much to see and absorb that the information and visual overload can take its toll on a body and mind that has arrived in Tokyo on an overnight flight at 5.15am - but it was worth every yen of the entry fee!

Great for everyone. We spent almost an entire day here- it was completely worth it. The size is huge and they have very large exhibits inside, replicas of Kabuki theatre, parade floats, bridges, stagecoaches, and more. Very educational and interesting, absolutely worth a stop.

Rain day event. RECOMMENDED: An atypical museum, the building itself is impressive in size and a marvel of engineering. Both young and old will enjoy a visit here. I'd highly recommend you hold this as a RAIN DAY visit as there are no windows (to remind you of the outside conditions) and it's directly above the Ryogoku subway station. The museum details the history of Tokyo with many large displays and replicas. The huge size of this museum ensures that even on a busy day, it doesn't feel that busy and the extremely large ceilings make for an airy feeling. The majority of the signage is in English and on many days they offer volunteer English tours. Entry price is inexpensive.

Great for kids. This impressively sized museum is easy to find on the Tokyo Metro. There are so many scale models of houses, towns, parades, Japanese people etc it gives a good idea of life in those times. There's a stage in the centre of the museum with shows (we saw musicians) which you may be able to catch.
Worth it. I am usually not into museums but this one has full size replicas of historic houses, kabuki theater and many others... :)

Fun museum. This is a museum with life-size replicas/panoramas of Japanese buildings and history. It is fun but not as informative as I would have hoped. I enjoyed a special exhibit at the museum (separate fee) on the history of the Nihonbashi area, so I would suggest keeping an eye on their special exhibits. The gift shop is very good.
Super iteresting!. Took a tour with one of their free guide which was quite helpful. Helped my wife and I get a good understanding of Tokyo's history. Definitely worth going to.

Interesting historical travel through Tokyo history.. This museum gives you a historical walk though the history of Tokyo. It is arranged chronologically and there is an English audio commentary available, which is a must for the non Japanese.the 17th and 18th century eras were very interesting and enlightening. Unfortunately, IObviously they're not too proud of their WWII history, which I thought were a little sparse. As a Westerner I had hoped for more info. How does this look for a Japanese?i would also recommend the Japanese Box menu at the restaurant overlooking the Ryoguko Kokugikan sporting arena.

A wonderful introduction to Tokyo. I spent a couple of hours here towards the end of my trip (here on business so little time to explore). I thankfully opted for a volunteer tour and was treated to a lively introduction of Edo/Tokyo's history and that of Japan. Can't recommend enough.

Beautifully presented and informative. This museum is a definite must for first-time Tokyo visitors. There is a lot more to the city than shopping, crowds, and food. There is an incredible history that deserves some awareness and understanding in order to fully appreciate what Tokyo is today. This is not simply a museum about a city, but about how that city shaped and dominated an entire culture.The museum's exhibits are beautifully and artfully presented. The space is quite grand, with a massive main gallery containing life-size re-creations of some buildings and streets. Other exhibits give detailed information about the Edo period and the development of modern Tokyo. I found the displays to be of the highest caliber and well-maintained. The only real drawback is the lack of information in English. What English signs there are give just the bare minimum facts. It would be helpful to go with someone willing to translate for you, if you can. I was lucky to have Japanese friends who explained a lot to me. That said, it's still worth visiting even if you don't have a translator.

Great place to start your Tokyo stay. This is the place to orient oneself to Tokyo/Japan. While the Tokugawa Lords ruled, Tokyo was called Edo. The museum is about cultural history of Edo/Tokyo during the Tokugawa Shogunate era (when the samurais ruled Japan from their Edo headquarter, and the emperors were figureheads in Kyoto) and the Meiji period (when the emperor became the ruler of Japan again). Few key features of this museum: 1) a reconstructed Nihonbashi bridge. The apex of the bridge is considered the epicenter of Japan; all roads lead to Nihonbashi. 2) a kabuki theater. 3) Edo lifestyle models. 4) 1923 Tokyo Earthquake We went early (10 am) and got one of the volunteer museum guide to give us a private tour (in English) for nearly two hours. Without her we would not have nearly appreciated the museum as we had. She explained very clearly how the Tokugawa Lords set up the society and the samurai hierarchy. The first Tokugawa was definitely a very clever man. He set up system to make sure that his descendants would never be without a male heir. He set up his government and subordinate structure such that nobody could ever rebel against him or his successor. And he set up the society such that the rich merchants would be below the poor farmers in hierarchy. Etc, etc.This is not the museum for young children. They can see the swords and the displays, but they will have no understanding of anything else.

Great way to learn about Tokyo History. This museum chronicles the history of Tokyo from the Edo period to today. The displays are excellent, and there's something for every age group. The gift shop is also wonderful. Take advantage of the volunteer English guides, who will greatly enhance your visit.

Interesting and historical!. I loved this museum, it depicts a lot of what Japanese history and culture encompasses. There are videos, models and many photo opportunities, as well as many life size displays. I you have any interest in Japanese traditional culture, then this place is well worth a visit.
この博物館はとても面白かったです。日本の文化と歴史についた物がたくさんあります。モデルとか小さい文楽とか伝統的な服や芸術が展示されています。日本の文化に興味があれば、ゼヒ。

Great overview of Tokyo history and some lovely replicas.. We chose this as the only museum we would visit in Tokyo. Having a 7 year-old son meant it needed to be visually interesting, not too big and maybe a bit hands on. This place met the brief. It's a lovely building with all displays well set out. Lots of gorgeous models of life in the Edo period. We had a free English guide, which was terrific and she was with us for nearly 2 hours! We especially loved the replica rooms and houses - the 1970's Tokyo house is great because you can go inside. There are some carts you can get into and a model Kabuki Theatre that explains all the special effects they use - fascinating! On leaving we walked under a train bridge on the way to the station and found a lovely bakery/pastry shop where we had lunch. Perfect.

Very interesting!. But keep in mind that you should either know some japanese, or get a free guide with you. You can get a guide at the museum for no charge. Much of the stuff there is in japanese, including storytelling from the scene.

Interesting Tokyo history museum & good value for ¥600. Using the access information on the musuem website, this museum was really easy to find (it's right by Ryogoku station on the Metro Oedo line and the JR Sobu line and is signposted well).I paid for access to the permanent exhibitions only which was ¥600 and this entitled me to see plenty of things in the museum and overall I felt was excellent value for a museum of this size/standard. The special exhibits seemed expensive to me (an extra ¥680) and I wasn't really attracted by the current special exhibit topic so I did not pay the extra to go into it. Having looked at a museum map, the size of the special exhibit looked quite small in comparison to the whole museum so I was glad I didnt pay the extra to visit it.If you do not read Japanese, I would strongly recommend that you try and book a volunteer tour guide to take you around the museum. Details on how to do this are on the museum website and you need to book ideally at least 2 weeks before your visit. However, I think it is also possible to just get a guide on the day if there is one available but they were all fully booked when I visited (a busy Sunday). If you cannot get a guide then I would instead recommend that you use the audio guide. It requires a ¥1,000 redundable deposit. I think that the museum would still be enjoyable without either a guide or an audio guide, however you will probably miss out on things if you don't use either.This is a very 'hands-on' history museum about the history of Tokyo during the Edo period and up to the 20th Century (it finishes with a section on the 1964 Olympics). Try and follow the arrows on the floor as this takes you around in chronological order. I visited alone but I think this museum would be great for families as there are many exhibits which you can 'try' e.g. you can climb inside the old imperial Palanquins , you can climb onto old bicycles and you can have a go at carrying water buckets. There is also a traditional Japanese house with tatami flooring that you can go inside (providing you take your shoes off of course!). You are also allowed to take photos (no flash) so can get some good shots of trying out the exhibits!I visited the museum alone and spent about an hour and a half just mooching around. I am sure that if I visited with a friend/partner then I would have spent much longer here as trying out the 'hands on' bits would have been more fun!The museum shops have some great little souvenir items so are well worth a look if you are on holiday and want some mementos/souvenirs/gifts. The prices are generally reasonable. Toilet facilities are also good here.I had planned to eat at the museum restaurant and the cafes/restaurants all looked reasonably priced. However, they all had big queues so I instead nipped over the road to the McDonalds opposite Ryogku station and had lunch for half the price and in a quarter of the time! The museum ticket allows you to go in and out during the day of validity, however I did not go back in after lunch as I had seen everything.Overall a nice museum and not a typical boring history museum. Well worth a morning of my time in Tokyo!

fascinating recreation of life in old edo. the museum has models of various sizes showing life in old Tokyo, including a model of a Kabuki Theatre and a reconstruction of the old wooden Nihonbashi bridge
Very good Museum. It's a very good place to go if you want to know about Tokyo from the old era until the modern one.This Museum has so many exhibits and things that you can see with your family.

Free personal tour and great history.. One of the better museums around. When you enter there are voulenteer tour guides that will take you around and spoke perfect English. The muesum I fascinating and offers a wonderful view of the Edo period. I learned a lot and it was fun. Well worth a visit.

Excellent place to know old Tokyo!. This is a place to spend a whole afternoon at! We enjoyed the life size displays, and models of Edo period. Definitely a wonderful place to relive and and immerse in old Tokyo atmosphere, while getting to know more about this city's past.

The best museum to visit in Tokyo. Being very interested in history, I enjoy visiting museums and the Edo-Tokyo Museum is the one I picked as the most appropriate to see in Tokyo. I wasn't disappointed but without a volunteer personal guide, we would have been struggling to fully understand the implication of some of the exhibits. I am a bit reluctant normally to go on guided tours, preferring my own pace, but I would recommend it in this case. Our guide's English was excellent and her knowledge of Japanese history was very good.The highlight of the museum for me was the reconstruction of buildings inside. Very well done and enjoyable. One negative was the short signs and written explanations in English. An audio guide, as in Europe, would be handy as I imagine on busier days there wouldn't be enough personal guides for every visitor.

Really Weird Building but nice introduction to Edo. I like this museum. It is not a glass cases and small exhibitions type of place, but rather an immersive representation of life in Tokyo from the Edo through the early post war years. There are reconstructions of typical houses and work spaces as well as a great Edobashi bridge.If I had to recommend one museum to a first time visitor to Tokyo this would be it.

A Bit Boring. If you are really interested in Japanese history (and I am) you might find this interesting. I did not. Alot of the signs are in Japanese so don't expect to be able to read much. There are alot of things to see though. I usually like museums, but honestly I found this one to be quite boring.

One of the greatest Museums of All Time. Japan indeed has a beautiful culture going back centuries and this museum has a lot of interesting artifacts to showcase; its mainly split into two section the Edo & Tokyo sections.The Edo goes back to ancient times showcasing the daily life of ancient Japanese citizens, Business and Commerce, and a lot of interesting culture lifestyles such as a life size version for the kabuki theatre re-created. The Tokyo section is about when Japan began to open up to the west in the Meiji Era to the recent events of WW2. The museum is also very foreigner friendly as almost all of the displays have explanation in English, it is also right next to a subway line making it easy of access. This has been by far the best museum I've been to, I am not to keen on museums as i find it to be a waste of time and money, but the Edo-Tokyo Museum is an exception.

Terrible if you don't read Japanese. I've been to good museums in Japan. This is not one of them if you don't read Japanese. Probably 10% of the exhibits have English signage, and even the few that are signed have been abridged - you know you're missing out when the Japanese explanations are 10 lines and the English ones are just a paltry 2 lines long. In a museum where you really have to understand the context of what you're seeing, this deficiency significantly degraded the experience. I would not recommend this unless you go with a competent bilingual guide.

Immersive. The permanent exhibition here is great for all ages. The dioramas pull you in and the written material in both Japanese and English. the exhibits on the great Kanto earthquake and the war are particularly good.

A fabulous museum. This is is one of the best museums I have ever seen. A faboules city history museum. A goog english signage and a accesible varied exhibition. The architecture is also very interesting. A good stay for a rainy day, you can spend a half day there.
learn about history. If you like learning about history and culture you'll enjoy yourself at the Edo Museum. Lots of great stuff in there and the guided tours are very informative.

Gorgeous artifacts and helpful staff. This museum is huge so allow plenty of time. The staff speaks pretty good English and the tours are very informative. There is so much to see from all periods of Japanese history in the Tokyo area. The restaurants are also excellent and the gift shops have some wonderful items.

Off the beaten path but worth it!. Out of the way subway ride, but a great find. Enough English signs and directions in museum to understand and appreciate.Superb exhibits, antiques and recreations of the history of Tokyo. 600 yen is worth it.

spaceship on stilts. Looking at the museum from the outside you would not expect what is inside. It is a history of Tokyo with excellent models, street scenes and artifacts. It is a large museum with a lot of history to cover. English is sparce in some of the exhibits but there are flyers and aids to help. Kind of place you will go back to again
Learn about Tokyo. You can learn everything there is to know about Tokyo here.

Lovely museum. This museum is well worth visiting. Its very impressive from the outside, and the entrance is very good!Inside you will find history on the Edo period of Tokyo which contains lovely works of art.THere are free tour guides avbailable in several languages which was very usefull as a lot of the objects you could look at but not understand what they actually were.Also, with a tour guide you can go inside the actual theatre, where normal visitors are not allowed.A great experience and i would recommend it!

Great museum for history fans - English guides available. I visited quite a few museums during my stay in Tokyo, and this was my favorite.The displays of life in Tokyo throughout it's history are fascinating, and nearly every display has an explanation in English, which is a rarity in Japan.What really made this a great experience was my tour guide, who spend nearly two hours walking us through the displays, explaining them, and sharing his own experiences of living in Tokyo since the 1930s.I ended up spending the better part of an entire day here. Check out the restaurant on the top floor for a great city view, and the open area on the 3rd floor to get some fresh air.

A brief look into the history of Tokyo (Edo). This museum offers a nice introduction to the history of Tokyo (old name Edo). By 1721, Edo had grown into the world's largest city with a population of 1 million. Various historic items testify the flourishing of urban culture under the Tokugawa Shogunate. Also, how people's life changed dramatically after the Meiji Restoration of 1868 is vividly shown. I felt that some parts of history are not represented strongly enough, such as class discrimination under the Shogunate and the underclass; the aristocracy under the Meiji Regime; Tokyo as the metropole of the Japanese Empire and Colonialism; the killings of the Koreans, Chinese, and Socialists by the vigilante groups in the aftermath of the Great Kanto Earthquake of 1923 (which is explained in brief, but does not explain in depth as to who where responsible and why they were targeted); Women's liberation movement and ban of prostitution in Yoshiwara; the occupation and the problematic reforms after WW2; The US-Japan Security Treaty and the Anpo Riots of 1969-1970. Perhaps the general conservative to rightist political tendencies of Tokyo mayors have had some indirect effect on what to display (and what not to) in the museum, and I find that a bit disconcerting. That said, this is a pretty good museum that should be interesting to many people unfamiliar with Tokyo's history. Also, the museum shops on 5th floor and at the basement has items suitable for souvenirs at reasonable prices. Recommended.

A huge, informative museum. It's taken me two visits to see this museum. Each time I used a volunteer English-speaking guide who was very helpful. This is a huge museum. There are reconstructions of entire large buildings and bridges and excellent panoramas as well as the excellent exhibits. If you want to know about Tokyo, this is the place to start.

A great way to spend half a day. There are so many interesting things to see in this museum that even a person with no knowledge of Japanese or Tokyo history would enjoy the exhibits.I do recommend coordinating your visit with the times of the English-language tours (or those in other languages), since the English labeling of exhibits is rather limited. I was only disappointed with the food offerings on the premises, but you can plan to have lunch before or after your visit, as there are numerous eateries in the neighborhood.I would like to see the museum expand its section on early post-war Japan (the 50s and 60s), which is so important to the rise of Japan to the modern society and economy of today.

Interesting but.... If you are really interested in Japanese history, you may enjoy this Edo-Tokoyo Museum very much. There are quite many interesting exhibitions and excellent replicas which you can see the old time in Japan. BUT if you're not interested in Japanese history, you might find here quite boring.

Reserve an English tour before you go. We showed up at this museum one afternoon without much forethought. We began walking through the earliest history period section and were very disappointed to see how very little was translated to English (this is fine because we are foreign tourists, but in a history museum I think objects are just objects unless you know their significance). My husband and I walked around a little bit forlornly, realizing we would not get the full experience. BUT WAIT, what is that I hear? English! We found a female volunteer dressed in kimono providing an English tour to two British tourists and began basically stalking this tour. The stories she was telling were just so interesting that we would inch our way behind the group as they moved from display to display. Finally we asked the British tourists if we could join their tour and they were very gracious and said yes. Our experience immediately improved 100% and we heard a lot of wonderfully colored stories from the volunteer tour guide. Her English was very good and she was very hospitable. We learned later that you can request a tour several months in advance and up until 2 or 3 pm based on availability (you might want to look into this more if you're planning a trip). The museum has many very interesting displays and we found that as the museum moved into more modern eras, more of the displays were translated into English, though we still learned more from our guide than what was printed out. There is plenty to see a few things to actually do--you can sit inside a rickshaw, try to ring the fire alarm, etc. The section on WWII was what I found most interesting. This was a great way to spend an afternoon.

Well designed treat. Super building and layout - you go to the top to start your tour and work your way down - a lot of models of buildings with some life size ones - that makes it good even you read no Japanese.

Edo Museum - A Look at the history of Tokyo.. This is a remarkable museum that comprehensively displays the history of Tokyo and the Edo shogunate. English guides are available. Many floors of magnificent displays. And the architecture of the museum is also something you want to experience.

Old-school Tokyo. Nice architectural museum in the middle of a big beautiful park. If you are interested in the old style buildings this is worth the trip. You can visit traditional homes, a little nomi-ya (drinking spot), and even a bath house. Beautifully preserved. Good English information.

Good historical museum. A good historical walk through life in tokyo from the edo period to modern day. Has a many intricate and detailed displays including a life sized front of the Nakamura Kabuki Theater. I loved their minature models of different scenes and the whole of Edo! So much of detail has gone into them, its simply amazing. They have English speaking guides who are friendly and very very patient.

Massive, but poor audio guide. This is a massive museum covering pretty much the full history of Edo as it transformed into Tokyo and beyond. Pretty good stuff although I’ve found that I’m far more interested in 19th and 20th century than further back - the shoguns and the daimyo’s and all that kinda blur into one for me. The only weak point in the museum was the audio guide which was basically just some dude reading off about half the placards that were beside each exhibit. After a while, I turned him off cos he. was. reading. so. slowly. Luckily though, the audio guide is free (a 1000 yen deposit is returned when you return the guide), so I guess it’s more for people of a certain age and not fresh faced youngsters like myself.

Top place to go in Tokyo. The Edo-Tokyo Museum is a must see in Tokyo. Firstly, it will give you an in-depth understanding of the historical background of Tokyo, something that will be an advantage to any trip to this fascinating city. Secondly, it is a brilliantly designed museum, with amazing displays that are well set out and in some cases quite amazing - a whole kabuki theatre recreated, intricately designed scale models, shops and houses. Finally, if you can organise one of the free volunteer guides, do it - we had one, who firstly apologised for only being able to spend an hour showing us around (!) and then we had a great tour full of information that was not on the signage throughout the museum (though the signage, in both Japanese and English, is excellent).The museum is very close to the train station, and right next to the Sumo stadium (bouts were on when we went past and we got to see Sumo walking around). It is extremely good value for the price, and you could spend hours walking around. Make sure to check out the gift shops as well.

Great Historical Information. Great historical information on the Edo times in Japan. Plentiful of displays and informative reads that keeps you interested. Rather deceiving building exterior comparing to the displays inside the museum. Nevertheless, a worthwhile visit.

A great place to start!. The Museum was our first stop on our trip, and it was a good thing. We had one of the volunteer guides guide us through the museum. She brought the museum to life for us! Between her explanations and the intricate exhibits we learned the history of Edo Tokyo and Japan. I highly recommend getting the free guide. After you enter the main exhibit on the upper floor, inquire at the counter on the right. It took us about two hours.

Worth the visit as part of your overall Tokyo plans. This was nicely done with plenty of interactive options as well.The museum walks you through a chronological order of the history so make sure you follow the arrows.

Fascinating and fun. This museum is fascinating and fun. There is a cadre of volunteer guides who give personalized tours of the museum in multiple languages. My guide was an energetic older woman who spoke very good English and made my visit to the museum very enjoyable. This would be a good place to bring kids. There are many things to touch, buttons to push, animatronic exhibits, etc. Nice gift shop, nice tea shop for a snack (but kind of expensive, 500 yen for a cup of tea!)There is a station right at the museum for easy access.

A stunning museum.. Access: Toei Oedo subway to Ryogoku exit (main exit). The museum will be on your left exiting the station and is quite easy to find.This museum is easily one of the top five I have been to during my travels. It offers something for everyone, from casual observers to aficionados and from children to adults. It is roughly divided into two parts, the “Edo” section and the “Tokyo” section.The “Edo” Zone: The escalator brings you to the 6th floor, where you can walk across a life sized version of the Nihonbashi bridge while viewing the Nakamura Kabuki Theater and Choya Newspaper Publishing Co. from afar. Small dioramas of town life along with a model of Edo castle are on the other side. On the lower level the “Edo” zone continues, covering daily life in the city and including culture, commerce, and entertainment among other topics. This is mostly done in the context of life-size dioramas, all of which were quite comprehensive. The “Edo” zone ends at the Nakamura kabuki theater and leads into…The “Tokyo” Zone: This covers the Meiji restoration, Great Kanto earthquake, modern Tokyo, and the air raids from B-29s during WW2 among other topics in the same excellent fasion.Summary: I went here twice during my week in Tokyo, it was that good. The English signage is adequate and there are numerous interactive exhibits along the way (palanquin, rickshaw) that kids would enjoy. They have English speaking guides (!) that I believe are readily available although I got along just fine on my own. No visit to Tokyo is complete without seeing this museum.
Don't miss it. One of Tokyo's best attractions -- an absolute must for history buffs. The life-size Nihombashi, theater and Ginza building are quite fun, as is the giant model of Edo.

good fun and way interesting. we had a great time here. the museum is huge and took us quite a while to get around everything - and that is in the limited english. If you can read japanese you would be in here for days! They have reconstructed many lifesize versions of houses and theatres etc as well as small diaramas. there are artifacts dating back (supposedly...I can't really verify) 15000BC. There are photos, scrolls, videos and hands on displays. They have a special section that changes every two months - ours was on the Asakusa area. they try to cover all aspects of Edo life - food, business, entertainment, fire, history. They also cover the Kanto earthquake and WWII in very objective, simple ways that are impactful and you really understand the impact of these events. i recommend for a different style of museum experience

A trip back in time - OUTSTANDING!. FABULOUS MUSEUM - DON'T MISS IT!See what it was like to live in Tokyo (Edo) in ancient days right up to WWII .. ..Easy to get to with a JR Line & Subway stop right at the museum .. .. And, there are ENGLISH-SPEAKING guides available when you enter the museum .. .. Wonderful Overview of the History of the City. I'm not a big museum-goer, but I've gone twice and would go back again. The museum is best appreciated after you've been in Tokyo for at least a couple of days, so you've begun to understand a little about the present-day city.Exhibits tell about the rise of the city from a fishing viliage on the mudflats to the largest in the world, and its resurrections from fire, earthquake, politcal upheaval and war. There are dioramas of the palace and everyday neighborhoods that are so big and detailed that binoculars are provided. Plenty of clear signs in many languages.

Fascinating and Educational. The museum is very unique and has wonderful displays and reproductions. The headsets are pretty much a waste of time because they really only narrate what is already posted in English and the signal isn't so great, however they are free (you have to pay a deposit which you get back) so it couldn't hurt to try it. If you can join a tour do so. There are volunteer tour guides who conduct tours in several different languages. I would really recommend this because not every display has an English discription.
